excerpts: For Entrees (appetizers) we had Escargot Bourguignon, Soupe à l'Oignon, Salade Verte Vinaigrette, and Foie Gras.
The escargot tasted only of butter - not even a hint of garlic.
The onion soup looked good, but had very little taste - the broth was almost like water.
The salad was fine, but it is hard to mess up mixed greens from a box with a vinaigrette.
For Plats we had Bourride Provençale; Steak Grillé, Beurre Maître d'Hôtel, Pomme Frites; and Boeuf Bourguignon.
The guest having the fish stew could only describe it as "interesting."
He was unwilling to provide any further details.
The Boeuf Bourguignon was mediocre at best.
I'm used to Boeuf Bourguignon having a gravy that is red from the wine- not brown.
Plus it is generally served with peas, onions, and potatoes, not potatoes and carrots which is more American.
In addition, it had not been prepared recently.
Dessert included Tarte Tartin à la Poire,  Fraises Balsamic, and Profiteroles.

The dough for the  
Profiteroles was so tough that it required a knife to cut them - enough said.
The Fraises Balsamic was made with strawberries that were so far from ripe that they had no taste whatsoever.
The Tarte Tartin was described as "tasteless and boring.

"

Service went from one extreme to the other.
The joint opinion on the meal was "meh."
We won't be back.
salade verte vinaigrette.author: Scott M.
salade verte vinaigrette.review:
If tasteless food is what you crave, you'll find it here.

There were three of us for dinner.

For Entrees (appetizers) we had Escargot Bourguignon, Soupe à l'Oignon, Salade Verte Vinaigrette, and Foie Gras.  The escargot tasted only of butter - not even a hint of garlic.  The onion soup looked good, but had very little taste - the broth was almost like water.  The salad was fine, but it is hard to mess up mixed greens from a box with a vinaigrette.  The foie gras was well prepared, but the most remarkable thing about the dish was the fruit spread and the grilled grapes.

For Plats we had Bourride Provençale; Steak Grillé, Beurre Maître d'Hôtel, Pomme Frites; and Boeuf Bourguignon.  The guest having the fish stew could only describe it as "interesting."  He was unwilling to provide any further details.  The Boeuf Bourguignon was mediocre at best.  I'm used to Boeuf Bourguignon having a gravy that is red from the wine- not brown.  Plus it is generally served with peas, onions, and potatoes, not potatoes and carrots which is more American.  In addition, it had not been prepared recently.  The steak seemed to be the best of the choices made - a sad reflection on a French restaurant.

Dessert included Tarte Tartin à la Poire,  Fraises Balsamic, and Profiteroles.  The dough for the  
Profiteroles was so tough that it required a knife to cut them - enough said.  The Fraises Balsamic was made with strawberries that were so far from ripe that they had no taste whatsoever.  The Tarte Tartin was described as "tasteless and boring."

Service went from one extreme to the other.  Either they were always at the table or they totally ignored you.

The joint opinion on the meal was "meh."  We won't be back.

excerpts: My wife got the Salade Verte Vinaigrette and it was plain compared to ours.
salade verte vinaigrette.author: Alan F.
salade verte vinaigrette.review:
Met the wife and a friend for dinner here last night and we had a really good meal.   

Two of us got started with the Salade de Chèvre Chaud and it was excellent, with a warm walnut-encrusted patty of goat cheese.  My wife got the Salade Verte Vinaigrette and it was plain compared to ours.  

The others got the sea bass which was served in a garlicky dressing over a round patty made out of cauliflower.  SCRUMPTIOUS!   Sea bass was great, but who knew cauliflower could be so delicious?  I got the boeuf bourguignon and it was hot, tasty and filling.  Perfect for a winter evening.  

The service was French, which I love but apparently isn't for everyone.  They don't hover or bother you until you let them know you'd like something.  The food came out in a good time frame...not too fast and not too slow.  If you want to quickly scarf down a quick meal so you can get back to your busy life, then a French restaurant isn't for you.  On the other hand, if you want to enjoy a relaxing dinner with friends and converse comfortably without bullhorns, then I highly recommend Baker Street Bistro.

excerpts: I got the Oeufs Benedicte (Canadian Bacon, poached eggs, English Muffin, Hollandaise sauce) and Alex A. got the Croque Monsieur (Ham & melted Swiss cheese in toasted pain de mie with béchamel sauce).
They were both amazingggg.
If you don't like cheese, though, stay away from the Croque Monsieur and the Croque Madame.
oeufs benedicte.author: Jamie C.
oeufs benedicte.review:
This place is so quintessentially San Francisco. Good thing you get to make reservations here otherwise we would never have gotten seated. 

As you can probably tell from the other reviews, the food is pretty amazing. I got the Oeufs Benedicte (Canadian Bacon, poached eggs, English Muffin, Hollandaise sauce) and Alex A. got the Croque Monsieur (Ham & melted Swiss cheese in toasted pain de mie with béchamel sauce). They were both amazingggg. If you don't like cheese, though, stay away from the Croque Monsieur and the Croque Madame.

For dessert, we got to try the Tarte Tartin à la Poire (Warm pear tart, strawberry coulis) and Crème Brulée with our cousins. The desserts were pretty huge, especially the Crème Brulée. It was so yummy, but I recommend sharing it with your party.  

One thing - The service was adequate, but not very good. They were very accommodating with the baby in our party, but they took forever to get us our dessert menu and check.

excerpts:
Meal: brunch
Service: seated quickly only with a reservation; dessert menu and bill took forever
Ordered: Croque Madame and Crème Brulée; tried others' Oeufs Benedicte and Tarte Tartin à la Poire

Personally preferred the Oeufs Benedicte to the Croque Madame, but only because the latter was a little too oily for me and I realized I don't like Swiss cheese as much as I thought I did.
oeufs benedicte.author: D. A.
oeufs benedicte.review:
Meal: brunch
Service: seated quickly only with a reservation; dessert menu and bill took forever
Ordered: Croque Madame and Crème Brulée; tried others' Oeufs Benedicte and Tarte Tartin à la Poire

Personally preferred the Oeufs Benedicte to the Croque Madame, but only because the latter was a little too oily for me and I realized I don't like Swiss cheese as much as I thought I did.  The portions were generous and both desserts tasted absolutely amazing!

excerpts: Croque Madame was on point, oeufs florentine was bland.
Decor and interiors are very pleasant.
oeufs florentine.author: Alex B.
oeufs florentine.review: Brunch service was below satisfactory- one waitress and one busboy waiting 13-15 tables. When observing other patrons, you could sense the same sentiment of slow, inattentive service. Croque Madame was on point, oeufs florentine was bland. Decor and interiors are very pleasant.

excerpts: There were three of us, we had Oeufs Copenhague, Oeufs Florentine, and Pain Perdu.
Oeufs Copenhague is a smoked salmon "Eggs Benedict" with a buttery hollendaise that was intoxicating.
I regretfully did not get a bite of my friend's Oeufs Florentine, that greedy gus!
oeufs florentine.author: Theresa M.
oeufs florentine.review:
This charming little French bistro was the perfect end to my weekend in San Francisco.  A tasty Sunday brunch before driving back to Los Angeles was exactly what I needed.  There were three of us, we had Oeufs Copenhague, Oeufs Florentine, and Pain Perdu.

Oeufs Copenhague is a smoked salmon "Eggs Benedict" with a buttery hollendaise that was intoxicating.  I regretfully did not get a bite of my friend's Oeufs Florentine, that greedy gus!  Next time for sure!

Both Oeufs dishes came with a side salad that was a nice spring mix lightly tossed with vinaigrette, and tender roasted potatoes with herbs.

The Pain Perdu (French Toast) was delicately egg battered with cinnamon sugar, maple syrup and came with creme fraiche and strawberry coulis artfully swirled on the plate for dipping and a side of fresh fruit.  We all agreed that the maple syrup could have been served on the side rather than drizzled on top, that way there was the option to choose between the different sauces available, but the combination of maple syrup and strawberry / cream was actually pretty darn delicious.

There is outdoor seating, very reminiscent to Parisian cafe, and an extremely friendly and helpful waitress.  If you want to practice your French she'll gladly oblige, or answer questions about what the dishes or just help with translation or pronunciation if you wish.  

I have to admit, the decor is a little old and funky.  Oversized Christmas ornaments, random vintage clocks and an odd wall sculpture featuring ducks.  I also spotted Julia Child's "Mastering the Art of French Cooking" among the spices in the tiny kitchen.

Baker St. Bistro is quirky but it's completely endearing.

excerpts: After looking at the menu and making our choice, Oeufs Copenhague which is poached eggs and Salmon  and Pain Perdu which is cinnamon French toast, we attempt to order and the server says we're all out of Pain Perdu.
Well that's a disappointment
so we decide to split the Oeufs Copenhague with some coffee.
Time goes by and nothing is brought to us, no coffee no water, nothing.
The couple next to us was seated at the same time and already had their coffee and water.
We had to flag someone down and ask for our coffee.
We finally get our poached eggs and Salmon and the taste is good but nothing out of the ordinary.
We drink our average coffee
but we're never offered refills.
oeufs copenhague.author: Joseph F.
oeufs copenhague.review:
Baker Street Bistro was a disappointment. My husband and I like to try out different brunch places around the city and we were in the Marina area so we thought we would check it out. 

The wait wasn't too long on an early Sunday afternoon so that should have been a hint that it wasn't going to be too great. After looking at the menu and making our choice, Oeufs Copenhague which is poached eggs and Salmon  and Pain Perdu which is cinnamon French toast, we attempt to order and the server says we're all out of Pain Perdu. Well that's a disappointment so we decide to split the Oeufs Copenhague with some coffee. Time goes by and nothing is brought to us, no coffee no water, nothing. The couple next to us was seated at the same time and already had their coffee and water. We had to flag someone down and ask for our coffee. We finally get our poached eggs and Salmon and the taste is good but nothing out of the ordinary. We drink our average coffee but we're never offered refills. There are still no servers around so we have to go to the front for the check. 

With so many options in San Francisco we won't be coming back to this restaurant.

excerpts: I naturally gravitate towards any smoked salmon+poached eggs combo and their Oeufs Copenhague was just what I had in mind.
Their home fries were a nice addition to the meal along with the mixed greens.
I wish I tried more off their menu but for a no-fuss breakfast early in the morning, this was a lovely place.
oeufs copenhague.author: Alice N.
oeufs copenhague.review:
This quaint little place was literally right next to my hotel, it must have been fate right?  The weather was gorgeous that morning and perfect for their outdoor patio seating.  We were the only people there at the time as it had just opened for the day so their service was fairly quick and the hostess was very friendly and attentive.   

I naturally gravitate towards any smoked salmon+poached eggs combo and their Oeufs Copenhague was just what I had in mind. Their home fries were a nice addition to the meal along with the mixed greens. I wish I tried more off their menu but for a no-fuss breakfast early in the morning, this was a lovely place.

Oeufs Copenhague is a smoked salmon "Eggs Benedict" with a buttery hollendaise that was intoxicating.

excerpts: I recommend the Oeufs Copenhague: smoked salmon, poached egg, English Muffin, & Hollandaise sauce-$13.50
oeufs copenhague.author: Xtina R.
oeufs copenhague.review: I recommend the Oeufs Copenhague: smoked salmon, poached egg, English Muffin, & Hollandaise sauce-$13.50

excerpts: My friend had a similar poached egg dish (called "Oeufs Copenhague"), only this had hollandaise and salmon.
oeufs copenhague.author: Andrew K.
oeufs copenhague.review:
Charming French restaurant perfect for your Saturday brunch. They do accept some reservations although their website might claim otherwise. Not very big so I'd recommend it for parties of 4 or smaller, but I did see a group of 7 waltz in without a rez and they seemed to have no trouble getting seated. 

The centerpiece of the menu, I think, is the eggs. I had a poached egg on English muffin drenched in ratatouille and a light tomato sauce. Superb! Came with a side of perfectly roasted potatoes and greens dressed in a tangy vinaigrette. My friend had a similar poached egg dish (called "Oeufs Copenhague"), only this had hollandaise and salmon. She loved it. 

The service is friendly and prompt and the coffee is dark and good. 

I believe we had 1 coffee and 1 orange juice as well. Our bill before tip was just over $30. Not bad considering both the quality and quantity of food! 

Give this spot a try, won't ya?

excerpts: We shared the Croque Monsieur and the Oeufs Copenhague (smoked salmon benedicts).
Both were mediocre, but nothing you can't get at other brunches.
May need to come back and try the dinner sometime.
oeufs copenhague.author: Angela S.
oeufs copenhague.review: Came here for brunch because of the cute reviews, but have to say, am a little disappointed. I really really wanted to like this place - the server was really nice, but the whole meal just didn't quite come together for me. We shared the Croque Monsieur and the Oeufs Copenhague (smoked salmon benedicts). Both were mediocre, but nothing you can't get at other brunches. May need to come back and try the dinner sometime.

excerpts: We ordered Oeufs Copenhague, Florentine and Benedicte it was good, but the wait was a bit long, and there wasn't many customers in the restaurant either.
oeufs copenhague.author: Lovetea C.
oeufs copenhague.review: We ordered Oeufs Copenhague, Florentine and Benedicte it was good, but the wait was a bit long, and there wasn't many customers in the restaurant either.

excerpts: Sandwich de Baguette $10:
sandwich de baguette.author: Dean C.
sandwich de baguette.review:
8/1/15:  I think that our infatuation with this place is over.  Still solid food, but I don't think it's anything special anymore.

1. Fresh Squeezed Limonade $3.5:  One of the better lemonades (or lime-aid?) I've had.  Very intense flavor and plenty of kick.  Not too sweet and super tangy.  Perfect.  9/10

2. Sandwich de Baguette $10:  Kinda small really.  Decent length, but it's less than 2in wide.  Standard grocery store ham.  Cheese was artisan though.  Greens salad was okay.  5/10

3. Oeufs Baker Street Bistro $14.5:  I wouldn't make this my restaurant's signature dish for sure.  The eggs benedict is pretty standard.  The poached eggs themselves were good with correctly running yolks.  But really not a fan of the tomato sauce.  I applaud them for trying to be unique, but I would work on this one more.  I suppose there's potential, but to me this is not much better than pouring canned spaghetti sauce on your eggs.  Also, the seasoned potatoes it comes with are soggy and wet--left most of it.  4/10

Good brunch, but not worth a special trip or anything.

3/5

#french #breakfast #brunch #lemonade #eggsbenedict

excerpts: My husband had Sandwich de Baguette (basically overpriced ham sandwich with some greens).
The waiter gave my dad's order to me and my mom's order to my dad and my mom ended up with my plate.
Our orders were similar, but not the same, so we had hoped the waiter will know which one goes where when he dropped them off.
After the food was dropped off at the table, the waiter didn't bother to check if he got our orders correctly.
sandwich de baguette.author: A R.
sandwich de baguette.review:
Overpriced Average Food, Bad Service.

My husband and I decided to take my mom (&dad) to this place for Mother's Day brunch. My husband had Sandwich de Baguette (basically overpriced ham sandwich with some greens). The waiter gave my dad's order to me and my mom's order to my dad and my mom ended up with my plate. Our orders were similar, but not the same, so we had hoped the waiter will know which one goes where when he dropped them off. After the food was dropped off at the table, the waiter didn't bother to check if he got our orders correctly. We no longer saw him at all during the rest of the dining hour.

So, at the end, my husband went to pay the bill. He decided to not tip for the food and service that was below our expectation. The waiter then asked my husband if there was anything wrong and he told the waiter that the food was not good. My dad also told the waiter that he mixed up our orders. The waiter told my dad "Don't Come Back". My first thought was to get in front of this little man and tell him how un-professional he was, but decided to be a bigger person and write the review here instead. Needless to say, we will NEVER go back to this place. I've shared the story with some of my colleagues today too. 

We took my mom to a nice place with good food and service for dinner to make up for the bad experience at this place.

excerpts:
Tomato basil soup
Croque monsieur
croque monsieur.author: Nathan L.
croque monsieur.review:
This review is for brunch only.

BSB is a great neighborhood spot! Solid French bistro vibes with the food and service to match.

They have a beautiful vibe at their restaurant. The front of house staff is mostly French and you can tell they take pride in showing off the bistro-style of their cuisine.

Memorable Brunch Dishes-
Tomato basil soup
Croque monsieur 
The benedicts!

-1 star for no oysters at brunch and having some accidental extra charges on the bill ;)

Can't wait to come back for dinner. I am sure this place is 5-stars all around and cannot wait to frequent it more often as we live around the block

excerpts: Had the mussels in the cream garlic sauce and croque monsieur.
The mussels were outstanding.
Almost four dozen of them in the most delicious sauce with shallots and tomatoes.
It came with a cone of french fries that were hot and crispy.
The croque monsieur was the best ever.
It was covered in cheese on top.
The sandwich was flavorful with oozing cheese inside along with ham
The waitress was very attentive even though she was the only waitstaff.
I can't wait to eat here again
croque monsieur.author: Bacon G.
croque monsieur.review:
Had the mussels in the cream garlic sauce and croque monsieur. 
The mussels were outstanding. Almost four dozen of them in the most delicious sauce with shallots and tomatoes. It came with a cone of french fries that were hot and crispy. 
The croque monsieur was the best ever. It was covered in cheese on top. The sandwich was flavorful with oozing cheese inside along with ham
The waitress was very attentive even though she was the only waitstaff.   I can't wait to eat here again

excerpts: The menu consists of a variety of 5 eggs benedict, the croque monsieur or croque madame, a variety of salads and a few entree plates of mussels and a few other options.
croque monsieur.author: Stephanie Y.
croque monsieur.review:
I was excited to brunch at Baker St. Bistro, a cute little neighborhood place with outdoor seating, a French proprietor, a simple yet delicious brunch menu, and some great company to enjoy my first meal in SF.  The menu consists of a variety of 5 eggs benedict, the croque monsieur or croque madame, a variety of salads and a few entree plates of mussels and a few other options.

We get quickly sat and handed our menus. We wait, we wait a little bit more, we still wait a little bit more (but, all this was somewhat  ok since conversation was flowing and we were having fun albeit being thirsty).  We put in our orders.  The food came out pretty fast. The fruit plate ($9) was fresh and good but teeny tiny and I wasn't impressed.  The boyfriend ordered the croque madame, boasting this may be the best croque madame he has ever had although he pretty much says that daily about almost anything that is really good. Regardless, it was a damn good croque. 
 
My eggs benedict were regular; nothing different or amazing but, the kicker were the potatoes that came with the dish. These potatoes were flavorful yet, they were cold and hard almost inedible (although I did eat them, since I eat everything that is put in front of my face clearly). These babies definitely seemed as if they were sitting around in the back for an hour or so. The coffee was nothing amazing and it took the waitress or bus boy about 30 minutes to come by and actually refill those mugs.  We waited for what seemed to be a lifetime for our check and I finally just went up to the proprietor (who seemed to be the only waitress) and gave her my credit card. I seriously think there was one waitress/hostess and one busser for this busy somewhat largish restaurant.  The service faltered.

Overall the food was at about a 3.5 type meal (I typically round up) but, the service brought this meal down to a solid 3 stars.  I'm a visitor to this delicious city so I have way too many other places to try than to come back to this place again.  Sorry Baker St Bistro, I will not be back not even for that delicious croque madame.

excerpts: I got the Oeufs Benedicte (Canadian Bacon, poached eggs, English Muffin, Hollandaise sauce) and Alex A. got the Croque Monsieur (Ham & melted Swiss cheese in toasted pain de mie with béchamel sauce).
They were both amazingggg.
If you don't like cheese, though, stay away from the Croque Monsieur and the Croque Madame.
croque monsieur.author: Jamie C.
croque monsieur.review:
This place is so quintessentially San Francisco. Good thing you get to make reservations here otherwise we would never have gotten seated. 

As you can probably tell from the other reviews, the food is pretty amazing. I got the Oeufs Benedicte (Canadian Bacon, poached eggs, English Muffin, Hollandaise sauce) and Alex A. got the Croque Monsieur (Ham & melted Swiss cheese in toasted pain de mie with béchamel sauce). They were both amazingggg. If you don't like cheese, though, stay away from the Croque Monsieur and the Croque Madame.

For dessert, we got to try the Tarte Tartin à la Poire (Warm pear tart, strawberry coulis) and Crème Brulée with our cousins. The desserts were pretty huge, especially the Crème Brulée. It was so yummy, but I recommend sharing it with your party.  

One thing - The service was adequate, but not very good. They were very accommodating with the baby in our party, but they took forever to get us our dessert menu and check.

excerpts: I ordered the French Toast, my husband got the Croque Monsieur.
The Croque Monsieur was definitely the way to go!
croque monsieur.author: Joyce C.
croque monsieur.review: Solid neighborhood find. I came across this place when I had a craving for brunch food, but didn't want to wait massive lines. I ordered the French Toast, my husband got the Croque Monsieur. The Croque Monsieur was definitely the way to go!

excerpts:
your choices: pain perdu (french toast), mussles, eggs benedict (and variations), salad or croque monsieur (ham/swiss sandwich). 

The eggs benedict and the croque monsieur.
croque monsieur.author: Nadia H.
croque monsieur.review:
2.5 stars. Lovely little spot, great ambiance, cute neighborhood. From the first moment you walk in, the one waiter/hostess/owner? sets the tone with an aggressive "Can I help you?" as if you've pig-headedly wandered into her home. 

For brunch, the menu is so petite that what is there better be spectacular- your choices: pain perdu (french toast), mussles, eggs benedict (and variations), salad or croque monsieur (ham/swiss sandwich). 

We had: The eggs benedict and the croque monsieur. 

Our friends had the eggs florentine and the french toast, so we pretty much had the menu covered (my sandwich came with a salad). 

The sandwich was good but nothing to write home about. Ham, melted swiss, butter and fresh bread. The salad was a small bunch of greens with a non-descript almost un-tasteable dressing. 

The french toast was apparently decently good, but my friend couldn't stop talking about how disappointing it was to have fancy, expensive french toast without real maple syrup.

The menfolk seemed contented with their eggs.

The french fries *were* spectacular, but that was about all that was. The coffee was strong and flavorful as well.

However, it got quite crowded for a small joint, and apparently the do-it-yourselfer owner/manager doesn't want to pay for another waiter. So there was a lot of waiting on our part, and not a lot of good service on hers. Mostly it was intermittent "I'll get there when I get there" interactions with her, and 30 minutes of empty coffee cups, 50 minutes before our food came sortof experience.

And the place isn't cheap.

Wouldn't recommend.

excerpts: Husband got the Croque Monsieur.
croque monsieur.author: Jillian K.
croque monsieur.review: Great place! French themed, and they pulled it off. Went for brunch, I got the Eggs Benedict. Husband got the Croque Monsieur. Both were delicious.  The hostess and server were both very friendly and efficient. It was minimally crowded but it was an off hour when we went. Parking wasn't too bad, for SF. Very clean. The only bad aspect was that they didn't have a single high chair for our baby, so he had to lap the meal. But, that's a common occurrence in SF. So, they may be just catering to the area.

excerpts: Croque Monsieur was bomb and the French toast was even better.
Highly recommend!!
croque monsieur.author: Callie W.
croque monsieur.review: This was one of the best brunches we've ever had! Croque Monsieur was bomb and the French toast was even better. Highly recommend!!

excerpts: The Croque Monsieur was very good, but again not extraordinary.
If you want French comfort food I think this is a reasonably choice.
croque monsieur.author: Gregg S.
croque monsieur.review: This is a 3.5, but on my first visit I always give a restaurant the benefit of doubt. Visited for lunch on a bike trip to the visit the Disney Family Museum. Solid french fare, but nothing that got us excited. The Croque Monsieur was very good, but again not extraordinary. If you want French comfort food I think this is a reasonably choice.

excerpts: Their french toast and croque monsieur are top notch.
croque monsieur.author: Caroline L.
croque monsieur.review:
I love how cute and unassuming this place is.  The food was great--I had brunch here with my siblings, and it honestly was like being transported to an charming Parisian cafe.  Their french toast and croque monsieur are top notch.  

We went here because we didn't want to wait in the ridiculous line at Mama's (I'm sure it's good too, but I really have no idea because I never have patience for that line), and it was a good call.

excerpts: The croque monsieur brought ham and cheese to a new level of consciousness.
croque monsieur.author: David D.
croque monsieur.review:
I love French accents. In food, I mean. Yeah, food. 

Mom-in-law asked us when we could go to lunch a while ago. My Lady arranged for it on a Friday afternoon, during warm weather, while the markets were slow. Off we went on the 43, just a ten-minute ride! 

At about 1 pm the restaurant was about half full. The diners around us were regulars, and told us what the "good stuff" was, while we browsed the menus over kir royales. 

Not knowing what escargot was, one of us who shall remain nameless asked for it without the snails. This immediately evoked the humor of our host, who owned the restaurant, and we had a lovely time dancing through the menu choices. Ultimately, we did order the escargot and French fries. Wait, we had entrees as well. The bourride, a fish stew, was delicious. The Caesar salad was just right. The croque monsieur brought ham and cheese to a new level of consciousness. Really, it was amazing! 

Somewhere in the middle of all this we decided to order wine. Quelle surprise! Given that we were trying to decide on three glasses, the owner suggested we share a half bottle of the Sancerre 2007 sauvignon blanc. We were delighted to discover it "was fermented without introducing cultured yeasts," and we savored its complexity. 

Dessert was mandatory, of course!  Chocolate cake, creme broulee, and profiteroles graced the table, with 2 coffees and 1 tea. The whole afternoon cost $137.43 + tip, of which $25 was the Sancerre, and $25.50 was the 3 kir royales. 

We engaged the owner in conversation, and found out he was a neighbor of ours! The rumors of a new restaurant opening in NoPa turned out to be true -- lots of exciting changes are happening in our neighborhood this year. We are eagerly looking forward to the grand opening! 

Now I want to learn French so I can speak English with that accent.

excerpts: - They make a mean croque monsieur!!
A bit on the oily side though.
croque monsieur.author: Heidi C.
croque monsieur.review:
I have mixed feelings about this place...hmm.

PROs
- Outdoor seating on a nice sunny day!
- You can bring your dog if you sit outside.
- They keep refilling your water cup.
- They make a mean croque monsieur!! A bit on the oily side though. The amount of bechammel sauce on it is delicious, and the swiss they use is good as well, but I've had better with gruyere since gruyere is saltier and has a different consistency. 


CONs
- Their grilled chicken with mustard is so small..! Doesn't warrant $12.50.
- The grilled chicken dish comes with potatoes. Only 3 half pieces...
- Service is SLOW. We waited roughly 15 mins to get our check, then I had to hold out the check booklet thing in order for the waitress to get it. I swear I had it out for 2 minutes. 

Everyone raves about their french toast which I neglected to get because I wasn't craving anything sweet. I suppose if I'm around in the area and don't have a brunch place to go to, I'll pay Baker St. Bistro another visit to try out their french toast.

excerpts: We shared the Croque Monsieur and the Oeufs Copenhague (smoked salmon benedicts).
Both were mediocre, but nothing you can't get at other brunches.
May need to come back and try the dinner sometime.
croque monsieur.author: Angela S.
croque monsieur.review: Came here for brunch because of the cute reviews, but have to say, am a little disappointed. I really really wanted to like this place - the server was really nice, but the whole meal just didn't quite come together for me. We shared the Croque Monsieur and the Oeufs Copenhague (smoked salmon benedicts). Both were mediocre, but nothing you can't get at other brunches. May need to come back and try the dinner sometime.

excerpts: Croque Monsieur were mmm-mmm G-double O-D good!
croque monsieur.author: Felicia H.
croque monsieur.review:
1 star - Super duper cute seating and atmosphere. Genuinely felt like a street cafe in Paris. And oh-so-unpretentious! It's a perfect place for lunch/brunch on a beautiful SF day. 

1 star -  Attentive service. Gotta love the cute accents and eavesdropping on the waitstaff as they banter in French - and by eavesdrop, I mean occasionally catching an English word thrown in the furry of French.

2 stars - Delightful food! Croque Monsieur were mmm-mmm G-double O-D good! Each bite left me wanting more. 

I am absolutely looking forward to returning here for dinner! I wish my neighborhood had a gem like this one!

excerpts: The croque monsieur was apparently to die for as well.
croque monsieur.author: Glenn M.
croque monsieur.review:
Ok I think I can honestly say this was the best meal I had in SF. Each breakfast/brunch I would have French Toast and potatoes at every restaurant. They all said they were famous for it and here the french toast was by far the best! Each thick slice of bread was very moist and full of flavor. The orange cinnamon syrup was a perfect combination with the fruit, french toast and fruity french whipped cream it came with. The potaoes were seasoned with just the right amount of herbs and cooked perfectly. The croque monsieur was apparently to die for as well. My partner practically licked his plate clean.

The wait staff was very friendly and it's on a great street to watch people walk by.  It's a little bit away from the hustle and bustle so it provides a nice atmosphere. A++++!

excerpts: and I got the Croque Monsieur which was one of the best CMs that I've ever had in the city, the Pain de Mie was nice and crispy on the bottom and the cheese was melted just right
croque monsieur.author: Brian J.
croque monsieur.review:
If you had to get one brunch item here it would have to be the French Toast. As my wifey and me were waiting for our table we must've seen a dozen French Toasts come out. When we sat down and finally ordered, I Iet my wife get the FT and I got the Croque Monsieur which was one of the best CMs that I've ever had in the city, the Pain de Mie was nice and crispy on the bottom and the cheese was melted just right, i think what would've made it incredible is if they used real Jambon ham instead of  what looked like pre-sliced ham. The FT my wife had (also made with the Pan de Mie) was incredibly tender and tasty, served with fresh fruit, creme fraiche and cinnamon syrup.
The service can be spotty if they get slammed.

excerpts: I got to taste the croque monsieur, the french toast and the risotto, as well as having eggs florentine myself.
The croque monsieur and the french toast with creme fraiche were both sinful for lack of a better description!
The french toast was thick but very light and fluffy.
I'm sure it had absorbed pointy of butter, combined with he creme fraiche and what I think was a light raspberry sauce made me feel more like I was eating a warm pastry.
I only had one bite of my friend's croque monsieur, but that was enough for me to question having ordered anything else.
croque monsieur.author: Rob S.
croque monsieur.review:
We met some friends at the Baker Street Bistro for Sunday brunch and it was a wonderful experience! We were immediately seated outside at one of  the sidewalk tables after being given a choice of that or one of the inside tables. Although my quick look inside indicated that it was quite inviting in there, we opted to eat outside on such a beautiful morning. This table availability is worth noting as it was 11:00AM on a Sunday, and one of our friends who had walked up Chestnut noted that many of the "regular" places had crowds waiting out front. 

Now to the food; it was simply delicious! I got to taste the croque monsieur, the french toast and the risotto, as well as having eggs florentine myself. The croque monsieur and the french toast with creme fraiche were both sinful for lack of a better description! The french toast was thick but very light and fluffy. I'm sure it had absorbed pointy of butter, combined with he creme fraiche and what I think was a light raspberry sauce made me feel more like I was eating a warm pastry. I only had one bite of my friend's croque monsieur, but that was enough for me to question having ordered anything else. I did also enjoy my eggs florentine as the eggs were cooked perfectly and the sauce was rich and delicious and the spinach was plentiful.

We went expecting a simple cafe/bistro experience, and that is exactly what we got, along with great food and a pleasant and attentive waitress.

If you are looking for a simple, delicious brunch in the marina, but don't want to deal with crowds, then this is the place!

excerpts: My second choice was the croque monsieur, and I'm certainly going to go back to try it.
I'm sure the person at the table next to me was wishing I'd stop staring at their dish over their shoulder too!
My cafe au lait was just fair, nothing spectacular.
And I'm sure that some wheelchair accessibility could be made if you called ahead and/or asked the wait staff for help.
Best of all, we were able to enjoy a nearly 2-2/12 hours at the table with no one breathing down our neck to leave.
That's what you want in your Sunday brunch!
croque monsieur.author: Jennifer C.
croque monsieur.review:
Met some friends here for brunch this morning. We were able to be seated immediately (started at 10:30) and enjoyed a long, leisurely brunch. We chose to sit inside, though the tables outside were perfectly covered in sun. 
3 of the 4 of us had the french toast, and the odd man out had the nicoise salad. I loved the french toast, but needed to have a stomach the size of Paul Bunyan's to finish my dish. The pieces of bread looked like Wonder Bread on steroids! So much goodness, but so filling. 
My second choice was the croque monsieur, and I'm certainly going to go back to try it. I'm sure the person at the table next to me was wishing I'd stop staring at their dish over their shoulder too! 
My cafe au lait was just fair, nothing spectacular. And I'm sure that some wheelchair accessibility could be made if you called ahead and/or asked the wait staff for help.
Best of all, we were able to enjoy a nearly 2-2/12 hours at the table with no one breathing down our neck to leave. That's what you want in your Sunday brunch!

excerpts: The croque monsieur is a hit.
I went here once with my entire French class and it was great.
Eating brunch outside on sunny mornings is very delightful too.
Good service with a French accent, and yummy food..
ahh.. Paris!
croque monsieur.author: O K.
croque monsieur.review: This place is great.. REAL French waiters and waitresses. Meow! The croque monsieur is a hit. I went here once with my entire French class and it was great. Eating brunch outside on sunny mornings is very delightful too. Good service with a French accent, and yummy food.. ahh.. Paris!

excerpts: Hubby got the Croque Monsieur, it looked tasty and covered in cheese and bechemel, yum.
I had the French Toast.
Made with 2 slices of Pan de Mie, it was extremely soft and tender and custardy on the inside and crispy on the outside.
On the side was a fruit salad, creme fraiche and strawberry jam and the citrusy syrup was just the right touch.
croque monsieur.author: cora j.
croque monsieur.review: My hubby and I came here for brunch on a Sunday. Kinda busy, the servers looked harried and didn't seem like they were communicating with each other. We got a seat outside on the sidewalk. Hubby got the Croque Monsieur, it looked tasty and covered in cheese and bechemel, yum. I had the French Toast. Made with 2 slices of Pan de Mie, it was extremely soft and tender and custardy on the inside and crispy on the outside. On the side was a fruit salad, creme fraiche and strawberry jam and the citrusy syrup was just the right touch. I can't say much about the coffee because I had tea instead but the couple beside us seemed to enjoy their coffee and brunch as well. All in all it was a nice place to go to with good food. The restaurant wasn't completely full on this day but I would hate to see what it would be like if this place were in full swing with the service seeming so weak as it is. I would still go back though, for the food and the location (quiet, sleepy little street).

excerpts: The coffee was as delicious as I've come to expect from French cafes, and the champagne to oj ratio on the mimosas was perfect.
I had the croque madame which came with salad.
The salad was also what I'd expect of a french cafe- simple and refreshing.
champagne.author: Hannah S.
champagne.review:
My bf's parents had dinner here and highly recommended it, so we checked it out for brunch. My bf was initially disappointed because he realized that the dish his mom had told us was so exceptional isn't on the brunch menu, but just means we'll have to visit again for dinner!

The cafe was small and fairly full but somehow maintaining an airy feel, and we were seated outside immediately with no reservation (on a Saturday morning). No reservation necessary+walking distance from our friend's place in the Presidio=winning combo! The fixtures and decor are minimal but charming. The service was friendly and helpful.

The coffee was as delicious as I've come to expect from French cafes, and the champagne to oj ratio on the mimosas was perfect. I had the croque madame which came with salad. The salad was also what I'd expect of a french cafe- simple and refreshing. The croque was generously sized with perfectly toasty cheese.

I'd recommend Baker Street Bistro to anyone seeking an delicious French-cafe style meal. Next time I'd like to try their specialty Pain Perdu or that dinner bf's mom was raving about!

excerpts: We usually start with champagne and move on down the wine list which includes some nice chardonnays and Bordeaux.
champagne.author: Aneesh B.
champagne.review:
I've had three outstanding dinners at Baker Street Bistro over the last few years, and my latest experience was every bit as good as the first.  This is classic French bistro fare that is consistent and tasty, and a place I know the missus will enjoy anytime. Gold stars all around.

Food:
I've enjoyed the Onion soup, Moules Poulette, Escargots, Charcuterie Plate, Navarin d'Agneau (lamb stew), Tournedos (beef tenderloin), grilled lamb chops, and smoked duck breast salad. My favorites are the charcuterie plate, the grilled lamb chops, and the smoked duck breast salad. One talented chef cranks out all of these dishes and more, night after night, with precision and care.  Perfectly-balanced dishes with loads of flavor.  We usually start with champagne and move on down the wine list which includes some nice chardonnays and Bordeaux. 

Service:
Always excellent, including the time we had to wait an extra 30 minutes even though we had a reservation, because we were given complimentary glasses of wine and thanked for our patience.  The servers give great recommendations in case you aren't sure what will work with your choices, so no need to fear the wine list.  Really great service.

Vibe:
Eat-and-drink-the-night-away-chic.  Time seems to stop when we go to Baker Street, and all I want to do is order yet another bottle of wine and another charcuterie plate.  Outdoor seating is great on a sunny day, with heaters perfect for chilly nights. Dress up if you like, or not; it doesn't really matter.

Family-friendly:
Seulement si les enfants adorent la cuisine Francaise.  But if they aren't into French food, either bring them for brunch or just leave them at home and save Baker Street for date night.

Summary:
Baker Street is one of a few restaurants that has restored my faith in French Bistro fare, and for that I am thankful.  I always leave happy, and I want to come back. Which I will do again and again.

excerpts: We ordered a bottle of champagne at the end of  the meal and it was quite sweet when we tasted it; hot what we were expecting.
champagne.author: Janelle C.
champagne.review: Delicious food, very cute restaurant and very professional and courteous service.  We ordered a bottle of champagne at the end of  the meal and it was quite sweet when we tasted it; hot what we were expecting.  Our server said, no problem!  Let me have you try this rose sparkling wine.  That was perfect and we had that bottle instead.  Would definitely come back...the food was fantastic and the portion sizes were VERY generous.  5 stars!

excerpts: He is so nice and accommodating and if you hit it off he might hook you up with a complimentary champagne or kir.
Fabulous!
champagne.author: Jen L.
champagne.review:
This place is adorable and a great choice for brunch, lunch, or dinner. The restaurant itself is a little cramped - cute, but it makes me feel like a combination of an obese person and Andre the Giant. The Bourride Provençale is amazing, as are all of their salads (endive in particular). Another positive - very affordable, especially for the neighborhood. 

I'm not sure if Laurent is still there. He is so nice and accommodating and if you hit it off he might hook you up with a complimentary champagne or kir. Fabulous!

excerpts: The Sophie takes a nap at Baker Street Bistro while mom & dad have brunch & champagne.
Finally, we all slowly walk up the hill to home!
champagne.author: Eric W.
champagne.review:
1. Sophie walks (w/mom & dad) from lower Pac Heights through Presidio.
2. Then we go to Crissy Field beach which is unbearably exciting and fun! The water, the sand, the stinky stuff embedded in the sand! Yay!
3. The Sophie takes a nap at Baker Street Bistro while mom & dad have brunch & champagne.
4. Finally, we all slowly walk up the hill to home!

excerpts: My dish consisted of: chardonnay wine, soup of the day, duck Breast with potenta, braised fennel, orange Bigarrade (fabulous entree by the way!), more wine, one slice of creme brule and some champagne.
champagne.author: Will C.
champagne.review:
Was here in the Marina for a runner friend's birthday and we had a group birthday dinner. At the end of the night I can say I was not disappointed at all with (a) the food, (b) the service and (c) the atmosphere. The menu selection did appear somewhat limited but hey sometimes change isn't necessary? I walked out of the restaurant with a full and satisfied feeling in my stomach  :)

My dish consisted of: chardonnay wine, soup of the day, duck Breast with potenta, braised fennel, orange Bigarrade (fabulous entree by the way!), more wine, one slice of creme brule and some champagne.

At some point I may go back to this place and try their Sunday brunch after a morning road bike ride into Sausalito/Tiburon.

Good times, thanks Dan for introducing me to this place!

excerpts: All is well, and we have fabu glasses of champagne and a nice cheese platter, and THEN, they ask us to move to that f-ing corner table!
but they promise us free wine and dessert--a deal we can't pass up.
So, we move.
Let's just say that the night went downhill from here.
We proceeded to wait and wait and wait for some semblance of service, but all we really got was bumped up against, ignored, menus dropped on us, and water glasses left empty....not ideal.
champagne.author: Lisa H.
champagne.review: So, here I am with fellow yelper Jacinta J. We ate at the bistro this evening. hmmmm, where do we start.....how about with the fact that there could potentially be fish remnants in my but crack right now. Yeah, you might think this sounds crazy, but I am not kidding. Okay so now that I have your attention, I will tell you about our night......we walk in and the place is looking super cute...not totally full and they tried to give us this table in the corner----but nobody puts baby in a corner!!!!!!! anywho, so we ask for the booth, which they gladly gave us. All is well, and we have fabu glasses of champagne and a nice cheese platter, and THEN, they ask us to move to that f-ing corner table! but they promise us free wine and dessert--a deal we can't pass up. So, we move. Let's just say that the night went downhill from here. We proceeded to wait and wait and wait for some semblance of service, but all we really got was bumped up against, ignored, menus dropped on us, and water glasses left empty....not ideal. then, as we were waiting for our entrees,  they offered us dessert, perfect timing if you ask me ( I'm being sarcastic). After that they tried to serve us the wrong entrees...finally we got the right entrees and just as we were beginning to enjoy our meals, a waiter was walking by with plates he had just cleared and a freaking dirty fish knife dropped onto my coat, and fell into the back of my pants, slipping right into my ass crack...perfect spot for a dirty fish knife, right? Ughhh! kill me. so not my idea of a nice night out! anyway, we already had free dessert and wine, so what else could they do for us? Well maybe they just gave up because they sure seemed to stop trying to make it better. You would think after a dirty knife goes into your ass, they would try to make nice, but NO, not these peeps. I really think that they are good people, but I am just not sure what happened. I mean come on! anyway, our free dessert came, but oddly we had no choice in what type of dessert we got. As we watched the next table over reading their dessert menus, we ate out preselected flan, which I personally don't like. the waitress, however informed me that "everyone likes flan" I said, well I don't. she brought choc cake. whoopdie doo. whatever it is hard to recover from being fish knifed in the butt. Gotta go clean up now!!!

excerpts: Eggs Benedict and mimosa were perfect, outdoor seating for brunch was great,  small, friendly, local walking families stopping in.
Dinner of Mussels and french fries were fantastic and over the top in flavor, preparation and size of portions!
mimosa.author: Diane A.
mimosa.review: Dined here three times over the course of a month and each time it met and exceeded my expectations.  Eggs Benedict and mimosa were perfect, outdoor seating for brunch was great,  small, friendly, local walking families stopping in.  Dinner of Mussels and french fries were fantastic and over the top in flavor, preparation and size of portions! Waitress was super and efficient and friendly.  Definitely go here.

excerpts: That said, they were kind to me and happily served me a mimosa while I waited.
mimosa.author: Andy S.
mimosa.review:
I met some friends here for my birthday brunch.  Hands down, the best food with no wait you can get in that area. 

My friends ran a little late so I asked to sit inside.  They had no problem with it.  I was a little surprised since I think I snagged the last 4 top.  My friends underestimated how late they'd be, so I saw a few tables clean out.  That said, they were kind to me and happily served me a mimosa while I waited.

The food is your basic French fare, but the food was absolutely delicious.  Due to the comments here, I got the French toast.  It was delicious.  When a restaurant doesn't serve it with syrup on the side, you know they've got the recipe down and exactly how much would be too much.  

My friends got a few scrambles and they both thought it was fresh and just the perfect amount.

The service was also great.  French accents WITHOUT the pretension is always welcome.  The host was kind, charismatic, and had a great smile.

Thanks for this and I'll be coming again real soon!  My new brunch place!

excerpts: Perfect place for a mimosa on a sunny day.
mimosa.author: Mimi T.
mimosa.review:
To add on to all the positive reviews...I LOVE this place! It's cozy and quaint. Perfect place for a mimosa on a sunny day. I came here for lunch and had the seafood stew which was delicous--a blend of saffron, seafood broth, fennel, mussels, fish of the day, and all that with a side of risotto shaped like a rice crispy :-)

I vow to come here more often.

excerpts: Take a seat outside on their patio and order a Mimosa.
All their food is tasty and affordable!
I have never been for their prefix menu, but look forward to trying it out.
My favorite menu items are always the soups.
mimosa.author: Megan M.
mimosa.review:
Great place, service and food. My favorite brunch spot on a weekend. Take a seat outside on their patio and order a Mimosa. All their food is tasty and affordable! I have never been for their prefix menu, but look forward to trying it out. My favorite menu items are always the soups. The salmon salad is good, but I prefer the one at La Terasse in the Presidio. 

Overall, a worth while dining experience!

excerpts: I stared with a Bellini, and we all had the onion soup...
Amazingly delicious.
Not at all overly salty like most other places.
You could tell they cared about the dish, enough to garnish it with fresh chive.
I ordered the duck breast and man...
YUM!
We each got a different dessert, one Strawberry balsamic ice cream, Chocolate Mouse and Vanilla cream which was like eating clouds.
Absolutely delicious.
The waitress was kind, courteous and attentive.
Not once did we feel rushed.
It was like being in europe.
I highly recommend.
And they have out-door seating too, so if you have a pet you can enjoy your meal with your four legged buddy.
bellini.author: Brian C.
bellini.review: Our friend Eva saw this place on Check Bay Area a while ago, she frequented it once and said it was great and we should try. Boy am I glad we did. I stared with a Bellini, and we all had the onion soup... Amazingly delicious. Not at all overly salty like most other places. You could tell they cared about the dish, enough to garnish it with fresh chive. I ordered the duck breast and man... YUM! We each got a different dessert, one Strawberry balsamic ice cream, Chocolate Mouse and Vanilla cream which was like eating clouds. Absolutely delicious. The waitress was kind, courteous and attentive. Not once did we feel rushed. It was like being in europe. I highly recommend. And they have out-door seating too, so if you have a pet you can enjoy your meal with your four legged buddy.

excerpts:
The diners around us were regulars, and told us what the "good stuff" was, while we browsed the menus over kir royales. 

of which $25 was the Sancerre, and $25.50 was the 3 kir royales.
kir.author: David D.
kir.review:
I love French accents. In food, I mean. Yeah, food. 

Mom-in-law asked us when we could go to lunch a while ago. My Lady arranged for it on a Friday afternoon, during warm weather, while the markets were slow. Off we went on the 43, just a ten-minute ride! 

At about 1 pm the restaurant was about half full. The diners around us were regulars, and told us what the "good stuff" was, while we browsed the menus over kir royales. 

Not knowing what escargot was, one of us who shall remain nameless asked for it without the snails. This immediately evoked the humor of our host, who owned the restaurant, and we had a lovely time dancing through the menu choices. Ultimately, we did order the escargot and French fries. Wait, we had entrees as well. The bourride, a fish stew, was delicious. The Caesar salad was just right. The croque monsieur brought ham and cheese to a new level of consciousness. Really, it was amazing! 

Somewhere in the middle of all this we decided to order wine. Quelle surprise! Given that we were trying to decide on three glasses, the owner suggested we share a half bottle of the Sancerre 2007 sauvignon blanc. We were delighted to discover it "was fermented without introducing cultured yeasts," and we savored its complexity. 

Dessert was mandatory, of course!  Chocolate cake, creme broulee, and profiteroles graced the table, with 2 coffees and 1 tea. The whole afternoon cost $137.43 + tip, of which $25 was the Sancerre, and $25.50 was the 3 kir royales. 

We engaged the owner in conversation, and found out he was a neighbor of ours! The rumors of a new restaurant opening in NoPa turned out to be true -- lots of exciting changes are happening in our neighborhood this year. We are eagerly looking forward to the grand opening! 

Now I want to learn French so I can speak English with that accent.

excerpts: The last time we were meeting friends here for dinner(two weeks ago or so), we'd made reservations, but when we arrived our table wasn't quite ready, so they offered us complimentary kir royales out on the patio while we waited.
kir.author: Julia R.
kir.review:
This is one of my absolute favorites!  I've been here many times and am always impressed with the wonderful French food at reasonable prices. Bonus: the waitstaff and owners speak French, so you feel as though you're on a mini-vacation and may actually have left the country for a brief interlude!  

The last time we were meeting friends here for dinner(two weeks ago or so), we'd made reservations, but when we arrived our table wasn't quite ready, so they offered us complimentary kir royales out on the patio while we waited.  As it was a bit brisk that evening, they turned the overhead heaters on just for us--very nice.

We split salads (the goat cheese was delish), and I had the duck confit, which was absolutely fabulous!  My husband chose the mussels and left not a speck.  The recommended wines perfectly complemented our dinners, but sadly we had no room for dessert.

Conversation was lively over coffee and we hadn't seen our friends in ages.... I'm afraid we stayed a bit late.  Kudos to the staff who were quite gracious as we were the penultimate party to leave the premises that night.

We love, love, love this place! :-)

excerpts: He is so nice and accommodating and if you hit it off he might hook you up with a complimentary champagne or kir.
Fabulous!
kir.author: Jen L.
kir.review:
This place is adorable and a great choice for brunch, lunch, or dinner. The restaurant itself is a little cramped - cute, but it makes me feel like a combination of an obese person and Andre the Giant. The Bourride Provençale is amazing, as are all of their salads (endive in particular). Another positive - very affordable, especially for the neighborhood. 

I'm not sure if Laurent is still there. He is so nice and accommodating and if you hit it off he might hook you up with a complimentary champagne or kir. Fabulous!

excerpts: I ordered a Chimay and they brought and poured me a Duvel.
chimay.author: Johnny B.
chimay.review:
Three and a half stars, on the three side for my particular review. Close though.

Saw this place on "Check Please!" and had to "check" it out.  Got a nice window seat with pillows which was really spacious and comfy.  Ordered a bottle of the best rose they had.  He offered for me to taste it and I said to just pour and he made me feel like a turd for not tasting the wine.  It was a fifty dollar bottle do we really have to go through with this?  Oh how the French can unknowingly make us feel like the uncultured animals that we are lol.  He was cool but there you have it.  My mom is a French native and I have been to France and Paris more times than I can remember so our "Parisian Style" server was exactly that to the T.
After the wine came he fired all of our app's and loaded up our table like it was a Chinese food restaurant.  It worked out well since two of our app's were molten straight from the broiler but it was his call to bring out four dishes all at once.  

We had four app's and I had no problem finishing my steak frite salad.

The goat cheese salad had a great vinaigrette and diced tomato garnish.  It was good.  The goat cheese was bread crusted and deep fried in their frier. Portion was good to big.

The half dozen oysters were sweet and delicious.  Served on a bed of Ice with lemon and a mild mignonette.  Sweet small tasty fresh oysters shucked with no shell broken into the meat.

My wife loved the escargot.  I thought it was good too.  I noticed that they use tarragon in the butter which I was ok with but IMO is too sweet for escargot.  I still had no problem eating this buttery delicious dish.  

The onion soup was perfect.  Not too much crouton inside, cheese all over the bowl and toasted nicely.  Perfect gratin.  Excellent savoir.  Lots of broth.  Not too many onions.  Overflowing and spilling all over the soup charger when you crack into it.  Best balance of onion soup ingredients in a bowl in SF for sure.  Not like a chowder like often results even when I make the stuff.  

My wife had the mussels and the tarragon was completely blowing the dish away. Cream in mussels is already pushing it for me but the tarragon was a deal breaker for me at this point.  No mussel envy as I ate my entire steak frite salad.  I think even the compound butter on my steak had tarragon but it was not killing the steak which I happily ate up with a side of french mustard.  I love steak frite salad.  I think it is one of my favorites.  The steak here was a bit on the smaller side no more than 8oz. for sure.  Trimmed more than I like but it was good.  Excellent Frites.  Good salad.

My wife loves dessert so she ordered one for each of us.... I ordered a Chimay and they brought and poured me a Duvel.  No complaints from me but, heyo?

The creme brulee was good to excellent.  Vanilla beans on the bottom and all.  Snappy and not too eggy with a strawberry garnish.  

The Chocolate mousse was excellent.  I took one bite of it and the whole meal pretty much kicked in and I was KO'ed for the night.  I slept so good after this meal.  Better than I had in a long time.  That says a lot.  I will be back for sure to try their brunch maybe.  The photos of the Steak with a slice of foie look incredible.  

With tip we easily spent over $200 eating like royalty.  

I will be back for the $22 prix fix chefs choice menu for sure as well.  Good value I would have to think for this level of food.

excerpts: I asked for a Chimay, but i am told their is only Duval ,, ok.
so I wait,
order taken I order chicken, wife salmon, son burger.
Others seated, wifes french onion soup comes, still waiting for the beer, others get wine, refills, still no beer.
Finally I ask for it, and the server says "oh" and then brings it out.
As the dinner crowd thins out Daniel stares out at our table and then brings the food, My chicken lifeless tastless hunks that anyone could cook up.
My wife likes her salmon, son hates the burger.
i hate the service most of all, the thing I hate the worst, to be forgotten while others are laughing wine-ing and dining.
chimay.author: Toren V.
chimay.review: On vacation strolling around our hotel, we come upon a bistro, seems nice so we take a seat. A man comes out and pushes the tables together, because our large party of three needed more room. Menus, bread and water follow quickly. I asked for a Chimay, but i am told their is only Duval ,, ok. so I wait, order taken I order chicken, wife salmon, son burger. Others seated, wifes french onion soup comes, still waiting for the beer, others get wine, refills, still no beer. Finally I ask for it, and the server says "oh" and then brings it out. As the dinner crowd thins out Daniel stares out at our table and then brings the food, My chicken lifeless tastless hunks that anyone could cook up. My wife likes her salmon, son hates the burger. i hate the service most of all, the thing I hate the worst, to be forgotten while others are laughing wine-ing and dining. French bistro please,  I have been to France, where the servers were pleasant and the food good, this was a so so restaurant with a guy running around talking in a French accent.

We checked it out when we went on a "bistro kick" after we read an article in the SF Chronicle all about our bistros in our town & we made the rounds & Baker Street got top billing in our book .

The staff is professional & caring &

Not that I am a pro

The dishes are big enough to share as "we can not eat like we used to...say hi to Chantelle

& do not miss the "sautéed strawberries  with vanilla bean ice cream .....

I observe how the guests are treated & seated & find it a pleasure to watch  The food is wonderful and classic French . Not that I am a pro but we know what we like & we keep going back for more & have brought our family & friends!

& do not miss the "sautéed strawberries  with vanilla bean ice cream .....it is a fantastic surprise to end your meal!!! 
Phyllis & Roger

excerpts: I first came here with a small group for their exceptionally priced prix fixe menu which was originally $20 (now $25 as of Aug 2018) for a soup of the day +  plate of the day + mixed greens + dessert of the day.
Because of its great deal, it's only offered Tuesday-Thursday and Sunday nights.
.author: Andrew H.
.review:
Baker Street Bistro is a small, medium-high cost, sit-down French restaurant on the west side of the Marina neighborhood that serves French classics in a uniquely decorated, homey environment.

The restaurant is very cute with lots of decorations everywhere, warm tones, and soft seating. 

I first came here with a small group for their exceptionally priced prix fixe menu which was originally $20 (now $25 as of Aug 2018) for a soup of the day +  plate of the day + mixed greens + dessert of the day. Because of its great deal, it's only offered Tuesday-Thursday and Sunday nights. Sadly we were told that they only served a limited number of them and could only offer us 1 prix fixe course for our group of 6 which disappointed us. 

We had the boeuf bourguignon ($30, beef stewed in red wine w/ veggies), the cassoulet Toulousain ($32, beans, tomatoes, sausage, and a duck leg), the Bourride Provencale ($25, seafood stew), and a prix fixe course here and while nothing was "bad", everything besides the prix fixe felt like a poor value.The portions weren't large, nothing seemed very labor intensive nor were the ingredients particularly special. In addition our server forgot an item on our order and it took longer than expected to have that item removed from our bill.

Conclusions: I would highly recommend Baker Street Bistro for their neighborhood prix fixe menu but otherwise I would advise spending just a bit extra to go to a high-brow establishment like Jardiniere in Hayes Valley or saving money and going to Chez Maman in Potrero.

excerpts: We were a party of 8 last Saturday night.
We had a wonderful meal and excellent service.
We chose this restaurant because we could walk to the Palace of Fine Arts from here, but it was very good and we would definitely go back again.
Thank you Doriane for taking such good care of us!
.author: Sassy M.
.review: We were a party of 8 last Saturday night.  We had a wonderful meal and excellent service. We chose this restaurant because we could walk to the Palace of Fine Arts from here, but it was very good and we would definitely go back again. Thank you Doriane for taking such good care of us!

excerpts: How is it this place has 4 stars, it seems all of the accurate reviews for some reason didn't make it the Yelp cut and they're hidden.
Although service was fine the food left a lot to be desired.
I ordered salmon tartare, onion soup, and beef stew all less than ok.
Soup and stew were served barely warm.
Also portion size on stew incredibly small (turns out that was not a big problem as it was not interesting or delicious enough to eat)
Salmon was over dressed with herbs.
Thought a restaurant at this location would be better because possibly they catered to the local Pac.
Heights/Predsidio neighborhoods, not so it turns out.
Cute space but the food is not worth your time or money.
