excerpts: This quaint little place was literally right next to my hotel, it must have been fate right?
The weather was gorgeous that morning and perfect for their outdoor patio seating.
.author: Alice N.
.review:
This quaint little place was literally right next to my hotel, it must have been fate right?  The weather was gorgeous that morning and perfect for their outdoor patio seating.  We were the only people there at the time as it had just opened for the day so their service was fairly quick and the hostess was very friendly and attentive.   

I naturally gravitate towards any smoked salmon+poached eggs combo and their Oeufs Copenhague was just what I had in mind. Their home fries were a nice addition to the meal along with the mixed greens. I wish I tried more off their menu but for a no-fuss breakfast early in the morning, this was a lovely place.

excerpts: Based on yelp review, I took my mom here for sunday dinner yesterday.
We had
Salade de Chèvre Chaudand, Bourride Provençale, Traditionnel Boeuf Bourguignon accompanied by mascato wine.
It was delicious!
We are certainly coming back here.
The service was great.
.author: Sona K.
.review: Based on yelp review, I took my mom here for sunday dinner yesterday.  We had  Salade de Chèvre Chaudand, Bourride Provençale, Traditionnel Boeuf Bourguignon accompanied by mascato wine.  It was delicious!    We are certainly coming back here.  The service was great.

excerpts: Authentic Parisian bistro.
We were sad they were out of beef  bourguignon, loved the duck confit, but found the duck  l'orange, good but not quite the smooth complexity we were looking for.
The value to flavor and portioning was excellent, right along with the service!
.author: Greg F.
.review: Authentic Parisian bistro.  We were sad they were out of beef  bourguignon, loved the duck confit, but found the duck  l'orange, good but not quite the smooth complexity we were looking for. The value to flavor and portioning was excellent, right along with the service!

excerpts: This place is charming, service was excellent, food was delicious and decent prices !
Very happy we found it !
.author: Mellissa H.
.review: This place is charming, service was excellent, food was delicious and decent prices !  Very happy we found it !

excerpts: I've had three outstanding dinners at Baker Street Bistro over the last few years, and my latest experience was every bit as good as the first.
This is classic French bistro fare that is consistent and tasty, and a place I know the missus will enjoy anytime.
One talented chef cranks out all of these dishes and more, night after night, with precision and care.
Perfectly-balanced dishes with loads of flavor.

Service:
Always excellent, including the time we had to wait an extra 30 minutes even though we had a reservation, because we were given complimentary glasses of wine and thanked for our patience.
The servers give great recommendations in case you aren't sure what will work with your choices, so no need to fear the wine list.

Vibe:
Eat-and-drink-the-night-away-chic.
Time seems to stop when we go to Baker Street, and all I want to do is order yet another bottle of wine and another charcuterie plate.
Outdoor seating is great on a sunny day, with heaters perfect for chilly nights.
Seulement si les enfants adorent la cuisine Francaise.
Baker Street is one of a few restaurants that has restored my faith in French Bistro fare, and for that I am thankful.
I always leave happy, and I want to come back.
Which I will do again and again.
.author: Aneesh B.
.review:
I've had three outstanding dinners at Baker Street Bistro over the last few years, and my latest experience was every bit as good as the first.  This is classic French bistro fare that is consistent and tasty, and a place I know the missus will enjoy anytime. Gold stars all around.

Food:
I've enjoyed the Onion soup, Moules Poulette, Escargots, Charcuterie Plate, Navarin d'Agneau (lamb stew), Tournedos (beef tenderloin), grilled lamb chops, and smoked duck breast salad. My favorites are the charcuterie plate, the grilled lamb chops, and the smoked duck breast salad. One talented chef cranks out all of these dishes and more, night after night, with precision and care.  Perfectly-balanced dishes with loads of flavor.  We usually start with champagne and move on down the wine list which includes some nice chardonnays and Bordeaux. 

Service:
Always excellent, including the time we had to wait an extra 30 minutes even though we had a reservation, because we were given complimentary glasses of wine and thanked for our patience.  The servers give great recommendations in case you aren't sure what will work with your choices, so no need to fear the wine list.  Really great service.

Vibe:
Eat-and-drink-the-night-away-chic.  Time seems to stop when we go to Baker Street, and all I want to do is order yet another bottle of wine and another charcuterie plate.  Outdoor seating is great on a sunny day, with heaters perfect for chilly nights. Dress up if you like, or not; it doesn't really matter.

Family-friendly:
Seulement si les enfants adorent la cuisine Francaise.  But if they aren't into French food, either bring them for brunch or just leave them at home and save Baker Street for date night.

Summary:
Baker Street is one of a few restaurants that has restored my faith in French Bistro fare, and for that I am thankful.  I always leave happy, and I want to come back. Which I will do again and again.

excerpts: After following the reviews for two years and finally being in the area, I wanted so much to love this place.
Service was welcoming, attentive and accommodating since we didn't have a reservation.
Repeat faithful customers evident through out the evening.
But we found the food underwhelming, bland or unusual combination of flavors.
The seared foie gras wonderfully presented but lacked the customary rich buttery taste.
The cassoulet with duck leg confit was made with an unusually sweet tomato sauce and the duck overly dry.
However, the sausage and a preserved ham was tasty.
The French onion soup was the saving grace of the night.
Tasty broth, lovely melted cheese, and croutons well done garnish.
The pan seared duck breast lovely presented but again lacking flavor or crispy skin.
Given the high reviews we may have ordered the wrong entrées such as the many orders of mussels we saw.
Perhaps next time.
.author: Julia S.
.review: After following the reviews for two years and finally being in the area, I wanted so much to love this place.  Service was welcoming, attentive and accommodating since we didn't have a reservation.  Repeat faithful customers evident through out the evening.  But we found the food underwhelming, bland or unusual combination of flavors.  The seared foie gras wonderfully presented but lacked the customary rich buttery taste.  The cassoulet with duck leg confit was made with an unusually sweet tomato sauce and the duck overly dry.  However, the sausage and a preserved ham was tasty.  The French onion soup was the saving grace of the night.  Tasty broth, lovely melted cheese, and croutons well done garnish.  The pan seared duck breast lovely presented but again lacking flavor or crispy skin.  Given the high reviews we may have ordered the wrong entrées such as the many orders of mussels we saw.  Perhaps next time.

excerpts: Service is always lovely.
I adore the creme
brûlée-
not too eggy.
No hipsters in sight.
You could have a meal at Chez Papa
that's about the same price, with slightly better food, but not the same kind of experience.
I'm giving Baker St. four stars because it offers really nice, relaxed dining....
Place to go to have dinner, a conversation, and linger over coffee/dessert without  pressure to give up your table.
.author: El B.
.review:
Kind of an old fashioned French place with consistent food. If you order steak rare it will come rare. French onion soup is really good, and a pretty good wine selection. 
Service is always lovely.  I adore the creme brûlée- not too eggy.
No hipsters in sight. 
You could have a meal at Chez Papa that's about the same price, with slightly better food, but not the same kind of experience. I'm giving Baker St. four stars because it offers really nice, relaxed dining....Place to go to have dinner, a conversation, and linger over coffee/dessert without  pressure to give up your table.

excerpts: I called ahead and told them this was a first date.
Scored the window seat.
Very romantic.
Service is excellent; attentive but no pressure.
I was surprised to see foie gras on the menu as it was banned in SFO for awhile; seared to perfection.
Scallops and Salmon dishes were perfectly prepared.
.author: Barry G.
.review:
I called ahead and told them this was a first date.  Scored the window seat.  Very romantic.  Service is excellent; attentive but no pressure.  I was surprised to see foie gras on the menu as it was banned in SFO for awhile; seared to perfection.  Scallops and Salmon dishes were perfectly prepared.  Evey my Napa Chardonnay bias was neutralized by an exceptional Puligny-Montrachet, Louis Latour Chartonnay from France.

Great place to eat well and fall in love while taking a walk through the Presidio in the evening fog.

excerpts: I was excited to brunch at Baker St. Bistro, a cute little neighborhood place with outdoor seating, a French proprietor, a simple yet delicious brunch menu, and some great company to enjoy my first meal in SF.
all this was somewhat  ok since conversation was flowing and we were having fun albeit being thirsty).
We put in our orders.
The food came out pretty fast.
The fruit plate ($9) was fresh and good but teeny tiny and I wasn't impressed.
The boyfriend ordered the croque madame, boasting this may be the best croque madame he has ever had although he pretty much says that daily about almost anything that is really good.
Regardless, it was a damn good croque.
My eggs benedict were regular; nothing different or amazing
but, the kicker were the potatoes that came with the dish.
These potatoes were flavorful yet, they were cold and hard almost inedible (although I did eat them, since I eat everything that is put in front of my face clearly).
These babies definitely seemed as if they were sitting around in the back for an hour or so.
The coffee was nothing amazing and it took the waitress or bus boy about 30 minutes to come by and actually refill those mugs.
We waited for what seemed to be a lifetime for our check
and I finally just went up to the proprietor (who seemed to be the only waitress) and gave her my credit card.
I seriously think there was one waitress/hostess and one busser for this busy somewhat largish restaurant.
Overall the food was at about a 3.5 type meal (I typically round up) but, the service brought this meal down to a solid 3 stars.
I'm a visitor to this delicious city
so I have way too many other places to try than to come back to this place again.
Sorry Baker St Bistro, I will not be back not even for that delicious croque madame.
.author: Stephanie Y.
.review:
I was excited to brunch at Baker St. Bistro, a cute little neighborhood place with outdoor seating, a French proprietor, a simple yet delicious brunch menu, and some great company to enjoy my first meal in SF.  The menu consists of a variety of 5 eggs benedict, the croque monsieur or croque madame, a variety of salads and a few entree plates of mussels and a few other options.

We get quickly sat and handed our menus. We wait, we wait a little bit more, we still wait a little bit more (but, all this was somewhat  ok since conversation was flowing and we were having fun albeit being thirsty).  We put in our orders.  The food came out pretty fast. The fruit plate ($9) was fresh and good but teeny tiny and I wasn't impressed.  The boyfriend ordered the croque madame, boasting this may be the best croque madame he has ever had although he pretty much says that daily about almost anything that is really good. Regardless, it was a damn good croque. 
 
My eggs benedict were regular; nothing different or amazing but, the kicker were the potatoes that came with the dish. These potatoes were flavorful yet, they were cold and hard almost inedible (although I did eat them, since I eat everything that is put in front of my face clearly). These babies definitely seemed as if they were sitting around in the back for an hour or so. The coffee was nothing amazing and it took the waitress or bus boy about 30 minutes to come by and actually refill those mugs.  We waited for what seemed to be a lifetime for our check and I finally just went up to the proprietor (who seemed to be the only waitress) and gave her my credit card. I seriously think there was one waitress/hostess and one busser for this busy somewhat largish restaurant.  The service faltered.

Overall the food was at about a 3.5 type meal (I typically round up) but, the service brought this meal down to a solid 3 stars.  I'm a visitor to this delicious city so I have way too many other places to try than to come back to this place again.  Sorry Baker St Bistro, I will not be back not even for that delicious croque madame.

excerpts: Finally a French restaurant that doesn't empty your wallet and isn't pretentious.
We split the escargot starter and seafood stew.
Both were done to perfection.
Highly recommend this place.
.author: Judy C.
.review: Finally a French restaurant that doesn't empty your wallet and isn't pretentious.  We split the escargot starter and seafood stew.  Both were done to perfection.  Highly recommend this place.

excerpts: Great neighborhood bistro where you'd feel comfortable dining alone.
If you get seated inside, it almost feels like you are in Montmartre in France.
Without any fancy stuff, this places offers the most 'French' experience you can have in the city.
.author: Peaceful S.
.review: Great neighborhood bistro where you'd feel comfortable dining alone.  If you get seated inside, it almost feels like you are in Montmartre in France.    Without any fancy stuff, this places offers the most 'French' experience you can have in the city.

excerpts:
I had a terrible experience here - the only thing that saved this joint from one (or no) stars was a friendly and attentive wait staff,

Where to begin?
"  "Isn't he precocious, opening the door with the handicapped push-plate - and keeping it open so all that nice, cool fog could come into the restaurant?"
Until my wife yelled at the little monster to close the door!
Some people have no courtesy.
Or common sense.
So, let's get on to the food.
I had the boeuf bourguignon.
It's a dish I've made dozens of times and enjoyed in bistros all over the world.
Not here.
First of all, the beef was tough and flavorless, sure signs of it having sat on the stove, simmering, for the better part of hours.
The dish tasted strongly of celery and undercooked wine, which tells me the chef doesn't have a clue about how and when to add his aromatics.
but I'd be lying if I did.
She was presented with a beautiful plate but the scallops were brutally overcooked.
What flavor was left was sharp and astringent, with a tough and unforgiving texture.
The only dish at the table was our dinner companion's steak frittes - it's pretty hard to screw that up.
I dined here maybe 20 years ago and remembered it as being half decent.
Today, I'd cut that 50% by 90%.
Not Recommended.
.author: robert l.
.review:
I had a terrible experience here - the only thing that saved this joint from one (or no) stars was a friendly and attentive wait staff,

Where to begin?  Well, let's start not with the food but with the ambiance, a funky "Paris-bistro" decor marred only by the unwillingness of the oh-so-trendy couple who were unwilling to even suggest to their bratty hooligan 8-year old that he restrain himself. "Isn't he cute, climbing the bar and spilling the drinks?"  "Isn't he precocious, opening the door with the handicapped push-plate - and keeping it open so all that nice, cool fog could come into the restaurant?"  Until my wife yelled at the little monster to close the door!  Some people have no courtesy.  Or common sense.  Of course, when they (finally) left they were replaced by a group of millennials who were unbelievably loud - I'm sure there were a few in Burlingame that didn't hear them.

It would have helped if the restaurant staff politely suggested that such behavior could, just possibly, interfere with the other guests' enjoyment of the premises but maybe that's a bridge too far.

So, let's get on to the food.  I had the boeuf bourguignon.  It's a dish I've made dozens of times and enjoyed in bistros all over the world.  Not here.  First of all, the beef was tough and flavorless, sure signs of it having sat on the stove, simmering, for the better part of hours.  The dish tasted strongly of celery and undercooked wine, which tells me the chef doesn't have a clue about how and when to add his aromatics.  It was as insipid a dish as I've ever had, an effort that my children could easily surpass.

I'd love to tell you that my wife's scallops were better but I'd be lying if I did.  She was presented with a beautiful plate but the scallops were brutally overcooked.  What flavor was left was sharp and astringent, with a tough and unforgiving texture. They were presented on a puree of potatoes and broccoli, which I thought was a rather odd combo for scallops - and it didn't work.

The only dish at the table was our dinner companion's steak frittes - it's pretty hard to screw that up.  And, no, we didn't accept the dessert offerings.

I dined here maybe 20 years ago and remembered it as being half decent.  Today, I'd cut that 50% by 90%.  Not Recommended.

excerpts: After a trip to the North Bay we got back into the city and wanted a spot for brunch so we stopped at Baker Street Bistro.
It was a great day
so we couldn't get a seat outside
but there was plenty of room inside.
They didn't have any highchairs
so we had to have our son sit on the bench
but it was fine
and he did well (although he did leave quite a bit of crumbs).
I ordered the smoked salmon and poached eggs.
It was pretty good but nothing I haven't had before.
My wife got the french toast and felt the same way...good but not great.
.author: Blake B.
.review: After a trip to the North Bay we got back into the city and wanted a spot for brunch so we stopped at Baker Street Bistro.  It was a great day so we couldn't get a seat outside but there was plenty of room inside.  They didn't have any highchairs so we had to have our son sit on the bench but it was fine and he did well (although he did leave quite a bit of crumbs).  I ordered the smoked salmon and poached eggs.  It was pretty good but nothing I haven't had before.  My wife got the french toast and felt the same way...good but not great.

excerpts: First of all this is one of the closest restaurant to Palace of Fine Arts / Exploratorium.
So if you are looking for a place to dine before an evening show / event, definitely check it out.
Soup of the day: Cauliflower soup.
Pork chop with white beans.
Nothing spectacular but not bad either.
It was cooked just right.
Dessert: Chocolate Mouse cake with cream and strawberries.
The portions were JUST RIGHT for a pre fixe menu.
Now for the fun part.
If you like medium to sweet white wine, be sure to ask "What are your sweeter wines?".
He'll say "We have no sweet wines".
Basically if you like your white wine sweet / medium - you are out of luck.
So unless you want to be told no, don't bother asknig.
OR ask the question, just to hear his response above.
It's actually pretty funny.
.author: Sujan H.
.review:
Been here twice now and I crack up everytime. (will explain shortly)

First of all this is one of the closest restaurant to Palace of Fine Arts / Exploratorium.  So if you are looking for a place to dine before an evening show / event, definitely check it out.  You can park around here, eat then walk over to Palace of Fine arts / Exploratorium quite easily.

Cute french restaurant with real French server (not sure if he's the owner?)

Their early dinner pre fixe menu (for $18.50) is a REAL BARGAIN.

Four of us went and we all decided to have the prefixe menu.  

Baguette & butter. Your standard fare. 

Soup of the day: Cauliflower soup.  A little spicy and a little bland but not bad.

Main: Pork chop with white beans.  Nothing spectacular but not bad either.  It was cooked just right.  Oh and it came with a side of salad. 

Dessert: Chocolate Mouse cake with cream and strawberries.  How can you ever go wrong with chocolate?

The portions were JUST RIGHT for a pre fixe menu.  Their non pre-fixe entrees looked a lot bigger - but with 3 courses we really didn't need any more food than what was given to us. 

Now for the fun part.  If you like medium to sweet white wine, be sure to ask "What are your sweeter wines?".  He'll say "We have no sweet wines".  (last time I went with some girlfriends he elaborated and said that only dessert wines are supposed to be sweet - with a face that could be interpreted as "you ignorant americans" haha)  

Basically if you like your white wine sweet / medium - you are out of luck.  So unless you want to be told no, don't bother asknig.  OR ask the question, just to hear his response above. It's actually pretty funny.

excerpts: The mussels were perfect.
Plump and not the least but over cooked.
There was a ton of them in the bowl too.
Could really go for some now.
Mmmmm.
.author: Alison H.
.review: The mussels were perfect.  Plump and not the least but over cooked.  There was a ton of them in the bowl too. Could really go for some now. Mmmmm.

excerpts: We came across Baker Street Bistro after an intense duck watching session at the nearby Palace of Fine Arts.
I shared a ham and melted swiss baguette sandwich that was simple and clean tasting.
Even with the melted cheese there wasn't grease or oil dripping out or soaking the bread.
The other part of my meal was a bowl of granola and yogurt topped with a load of fruit.
.author: Cory M.
.review:
We came across Baker Street Bistro after an intense duck watching session at the nearby Palace of Fine Arts.  Ran in with less than 30 mins before they were set to close brunch, but the staff was more than happy to take us in.

I shared a ham and melted swiss baguette sandwich that was simple and clean tasting.  Even with the melted cheese there wasn't grease or oil dripping out or soaking the bread.  The other part of my meal was a bowl of granola and yogurt topped with a load of fruit.  (Tasted even better being the first healthy thing I had eaten in three days.)

The whole experience was perfect for a Sunday brunch on the run, and if I lived nearby I'd be back in a heartbeat.

excerpts: We stopped here for breakfast and were very impressed.
It's small and we got there just in time to avoid the rush.
We both ordered the French Toast and it was AMAZING.
Probably the best I've ever had.
So glad we stopped in, and I will be going back!
.author: Kristy C.
.review: We stopped here for breakfast and were very impressed.  It's small and we got there just in time to avoid the rush.  We both ordered the French Toast and it was AMAZING.  Probably the best I've ever had.  So glad we stopped in, and I will be going back!

excerpts: Coquille st joques were not  edible ,everyone else in the place seems happy
.author: Paul G.
.review: Very busy and popular bistro, escargots were ok. Coquille st joques were not  edible ,everyone else in the place seems happy

excerpts: Excellent  food, service, and reasonably priced.
Beautiful day to sit outside.
The Chocolate mouse was to die for.
Although the the tables were slanted due to the sidewalk, it just added to the ambiance.
I would definitely recommend it.
.author: Michelle M.
.review: Excellent  food, service, and reasonably priced. Beautiful day to sit outside. The Chocolate mouse was to die for.  Although the the tables were slanted due to the sidewalk, it just added to the ambiance. I would definitely recommend it.

excerpts: We came from Benicia because Check, please! gave this place such a glowing review.
The decore was quaint and had atmosphere.
The service was attentive
but - the food!
It should be the star of the bistro
but I found it lacking.
Maybe the real cook works a fabulous dinner but our lunch was nothing to write home about.
The snails were less than mediocre because even though they were very oily, you couldn't find a buttery taste and the garlic was missing.
My friend liked her dish of duck confitte (the potatoes were better than the duck) but my fish stew was almost lukewarm and had dried parsley swimming on top.
It seemed that they warmed up last nigth's stew.
So bland.
The two tiny roasted pieces of bread were the freshest and tastiest part of the meal.
At this price, it would have been nice to get spoiled by fresh parsley!
Well, so much for the glowing reviews of Check, please.
.author: Brigitte K.

It should be the star of the bistro but I found it lacking.  Maybe the real cook works a fabulous dinner but our lunch was nothing to write home about.  The snails were less than mediocre because even though they were very oily, you couldn't find a buttery taste and the garlic was missing.  My friend liked her dish of duck confitte (the potatoes were better than the duck) but my fish stew was almost lukewarm and had dried parsley swimming on top.  It seemed that they warmed up last nigth's stew. So bland.  The two tiny roasted pieces of bread were the freshest and tastiest part of the meal.  At this price, it would have been nice to get spoiled by fresh parsley!  Well, so much for the glowing reviews of Check, please.

excerpts: Since 1991, Baker Street Bistro has been turning out classic French bistro food.
Nothing fancy.
Nothing imaginative.
Nothing over-the-top.
Topped with rich, pan-seared foie gras and flavorful smoked duck breast, the salade du sud-ouest ($14.50) makes a simple bed of mixed greens with pine nuts sing.

The classic moules Provençale (mussels with white wine, shallots, parsley, tomato, and pesto, $16.50) was delicious, while the accompanying frites (fries) lacked the correct hint of golden brown, indicating slight under cooking.
The reasonably priced wine list is almost exclusively comprised of European selections.
A warning, however:  many wines are stored in the overly warm dining room, both making the temperature at which they are served too high and potentially jeopardizing their freshness.
Service is typically French--a little brusque, slightly hurried, and not all that friendly.
(Chapeau!, for example), but this higher level of establishment comes with a steeper price tag.
For The City, Baker Street Bistro is a value, offering mostly well prepared food at reasonable prices.
.author: CJ G.
.review:
Tucked in a less traveled corner of Cow Hollow flanked by dive bars like Liverpool Lil's and Final Final, Baker Street Bistro is a véritable restaurant de voisinage (true neighborhood restaurant).

Since 1991, Baker Street Bistro has been turning out classic French bistro food.  Nothing fancy.  Nothing imaginative.  Nothing over-the-top.  Just simple, solid meals to the delight of Francophiles throughout The City.

Topped with rich, pan-seared foie gras and flavorful smoked duck breast, the salade du sud-ouest ($14.50) makes a simple bed of mixed greens with pine nuts sing.  Unfortunately, the chef was heavy-handed with both sesame oil and capers, overpowering the delicate flavor of the tuna in the tartare de thon (tuna tartare, $14.50).

The classic moules Provençale (mussels with white wine, shallots, parsley, tomato, and pesto, $16.50) was delicious, while the accompanying frites (fries) lacked the correct hint of golden brown, indicating slight under cooking.  Drizzled with a rich carrot and ginger wine reduction, the poulet sauté (sautéed chicken breast, $16.50) was moist and tasty, but the vegetables and mashed potato sides were nothing special.

The reasonably priced wine list is almost exclusively comprised of European selections.  A warning, however:  many wines are stored in the overly warm dining room, both making the temperature at which they are served too high and potentially jeopardizing their freshness.

Service is typically French--a little brusque, slightly hurried, and not all that friendly.  In other words, authentic.

Sure, one can find more innovation, a higher level of execution, and better service at other French bistros in the City (Chapeau!, for example), but this higher level of establishment comes with a steeper price tag.  For The City, Baker Street Bistro is a value, offering mostly well prepared food at reasonable prices.

excerpts: Absolutely loved this little place in the Marina!
There is outdoor seating as well as a modest amount of indoor seating.
There were 7 of us
so we sat inside.
The items ordered:  eggs benedict, a ham and cheese croque, another ham and cheese on a baguette, the charcuterie plate, cheese plate and a bowl of fruit.
The benedicts were absolutely perfect.
Sauce was quite possibly the best I've ever had - hint of lemon, not too buttery.
Eggs were poached to perfection.
The charcuterie plate: various cured meats and a duck liver pate.
I couldn't stop eating the pate, and the whole plate was devoured by several of us.
The croque sandwich was decadent beyond belief.
I only had 1 bite, but it was unctuous and cheesy and tasty.
My daughter ordered the bowl of fruit.
It as the largest most beautiful array of fruit I have ever seen in a restaurant.
so the owner (?) was dashing around wearing his stress on his sleeve.
It was unnerving and a little sad, and I say that sympathetically.
I caught his eye as he came storming in from the outside with plates in his hand.
I was sitting in such a way that could easily have been mistaken for trying to get his attention, so as he approached, he looked at me, hesitated and was about to ask if I needed anything.
I just smiled and said, "No - we're all fine."
A while later, he came back to ask if everything was ok, and my friend and I told him everything was wonderful, but that we thought he should take a moment to breathe...
He was gracious and totally got what we were saying.
While he was trying so hard to please everyone, he lost sight of the fact that he can only do one thing at a time, and no one was in a hurry to go anywhere.
At least, that was my take.
Another note:
Our usual breakfast joint in the Marina is Home Plate.
I managed to sway my husband to try a new place, and I'm SO glad to say that he loved it so much he wouldn't hesitate to go back.
Ain't nothin' wrong w/ HP, but it's just nice to have an alternative every once in a while!
.author: Stephanie V.
.review:
Absolutely loved this little place in the Marina!  There is outdoor seating as well as a modest amount of indoor seating.  There were 7 of us so we sat inside.  They don't take reservations for groups under 10, so it was a bit tricky, but it worked out just fine.

The items ordered:  eggs benedict, a ham and cheese croque, another ham and cheese on a baguette, the charcuterie plate, cheese plate and a bowl of fruit.

The benedicts were absolutely perfect.  Sauce was quite possibly the best I've ever had - hint of lemon, not too buttery. Eggs were poached to perfection.  The breakfast potatoes were quite tasty.

The charcuterie plate: various cured meats and a duck liver pate.  I couldn't stop eating the pate, and the whole plate was devoured by several of us.  There was plenty for 4 people to share.

I had very little of the cheese plate, so couldn't really speak much for that, though it did look lovely.

The croque sandwich was decadent beyond belief.  I only had 1 bite, but it was unctuous and cheesy and tasty.  The ham was sliced very thinly and I would have liked a bit more of it.

My daughter ordered the bowl of fruit.  It as the largest most beautiful array of fruit I have ever seen in a restaurant.  A wide variety of very fresh fruits.

Apparently there was no server/busboy that day so the owner (?) was dashing around wearing his stress on his sleeve.  It was unnerving and a little sad, and I say that sympathetically.  I caught his eye as he came storming in from the outside with plates in his hand.  I was sitting in such a way that could easily have been mistaken for trying to get his attention, so as he approached, he looked at me, hesitated and was about to ask if I needed anything.  I just smiled and said, "No - we're all fine."  A while later, he came back to ask if everything was ok, and my friend and I told him everything was wonderful, but that we thought he should take a moment to breathe...  He was gracious and totally got what we were saying.  While he was trying so hard to please everyone, he lost sight of the fact that he can only do one thing at a time, and no one was in a hurry to go anywhere.  At least, that was my take.  Slow down, breathe, and know it'll all get done! 

Another note:  Our usual breakfast joint in the Marina is Home Plate.  I managed to sway my husband to try a new place, and I'm SO glad to say that he loved it so much he wouldn't hesitate to go back.  Ain't nothin' wrong w/ HP, but it's just nice to have an alternative every once in a while!

excerpts: For my entree I had one of the specials - wild halibut with black truffles and zucchini.
It was cooked and seasoned perfectly.
For dessert, chocolate mousse.
.author: Keith D.
.review:
I came here for a business dinner with a group of seven and had a wonderful meal. As many other Yelper's have said, this is a small, quaint, cozy place with very good french food, desserts and wines. 

I started with a goat cheese salad and freshly made bread. For my entree I had one of the specials - wild halibut with black truffles and zucchini.  It was cooked and seasoned perfectly. For dessert, chocolate mousse. It was rich, but not too heavy. 

I didn't pay for dinner, but I thought their prices were reasonable. The service was excellent and came with a french accent at no extra charge.

excerpts: As a pescetarian, I often find French food difficult, but friends suggested we meet here.

Tomato/basil soup was excellent, as was the main dish with scallops.
Nephew had fries, they were good too.
Two at our table had dessert and were happy with it.
Good experience overall.

excerpts: I met some friends here for my birthday brunch.
so I asked to sit inside.
They had no problem with it.
I was a little surprised since I think I snagged the last 4 top.
My friends underestimated how late they'd be, so I saw a few tables clean out.
The food is your basic French fare, but the food was absolutely delicious.
Due to the comments here, I got the French toast.
It was delicious.
When a restaurant doesn't serve it with syrup on the side, you know they've got the recipe
The service was also great.
French accents WITHOUT the pretension is always welcome.
and I'll be coming again real soon!
My new brunch place!
.author: Andy S.
.review:
I met some friends here for my birthday brunch.  Hands down, the best food with no wait you can get in that area. 

My friends ran a little late so I asked to sit inside.  They had no problem with it.  I was a little surprised since I think I snagged the last 4 top.  My friends underestimated how late they'd be, so I saw a few tables clean out.  That said, they were kind to me and happily served me a mimosa while I waited.

The food is your basic French fare, but the food was absolutely delicious.  Due to the comments here, I got the French toast.  It was delicious.  When a restaurant doesn't serve it with syrup on the side, you know they've got the recipe down and exactly how much would be too much.  

My friends got a few scrambles and they both thought it was fresh and just the perfect amount.

The service was also great.  French accents WITHOUT the pretension is always welcome.  The host was kind, charismatic, and had a great smile.

Thanks for this and I'll be coming again real soon!  My new brunch place!

excerpts: Two of us got started with the Salade de Chèvre Chaud and it was excellent, with a warm walnut-encrusted patty of goat cheese.
The others got the sea bass which was served in a garlicky dressing over a round patty made out of cauliflower.
SCRUMPTIOUS!
Sea bass was great, but who knew cauliflower could be so delicious?
I got the boeuf bourguignon and it was hot, tasty and filling.
The service was French, which I love but apparently isn't for everyone.
They don't hover or bother you until you let them know you'd like something.
The food came out in a good time frame...not too fast and not too slow.
If you want to quickly scarf down a quick meal so you can get back to your busy life, then a French restaurant isn't for you.
On the other hand, if you want to enjoy a relaxing dinner with friends and converse comfortably without bullhorns, then I highly recommend Baker Street Bistro.
.author: Alan F.
.review:
Met the wife and a friend for dinner here last night and we had a really good meal.   

Two of us got started with the Salade de Chèvre Chaud and it was excellent, with a warm walnut-encrusted patty of goat cheese.  My wife got the Salade Verte Vinaigrette and it was plain compared to ours.  

The others got the sea bass which was served in a garlicky dressing over a round patty made out of cauliflower.  SCRUMPTIOUS!   Sea bass was great, but who knew cauliflower could be so delicious?  I got the boeuf bourguignon and it was hot, tasty and filling.  Perfect for a winter evening.  

The service was French, which I love but apparently isn't for everyone.  They don't hover or bother you until you let them know you'd like something.  The food came out in a good time frame...not too fast and not too slow.  If you want to quickly scarf down a quick meal so you can get back to your busy life, then a French restaurant isn't for you.  On the other hand, if you want to enjoy a relaxing dinner with friends and converse comfortably without bullhorns, then I highly recommend Baker Street Bistro.

excerpts: Very uneven meal.
There was an extremely cheap four course prix fixe, but the courses were boring (spinach soup, roast pork, light salad, chocolate cake) so we opted for à la carte.
It might be good for the neighborhood, but coming from the FiDi,
A yucky tartare.
Way too tomato-y.
The waiter claimed there was no ketchup or tomato sauce involved, perhaps they just went Tabasco happy.
Bourride Provençal: Very similar in style to bouillabaisse.
The toast offering was measly and missing the shredded cheese on top of the sauce.
Also, I think whole wheat was a bad choice to soak up the broth.
I didn't like how the salmon filet was in tiny chunks as opposed to a single large piece.
The shrimp were small and tough, a sign of being overcooked.
Cod Potato Dish: Forgot the name, but it was basically shredded cod in a mashed potato base covered in cheese.
Liked that the cod was fresh as opposed to salted.
Lamb Stew: Not memorable.
A delicate soft meringue floating in crème anglaise.
Great contrast of an almost burnt top and
fluffy/sugary egg whites underneath.
By far the highlight of the meal.
.author: Adam B.
.review:
Very uneven meal.  There was an extremely cheap four course prix fixe, but the courses were boring (spinach soup, roast pork, light salad, chocolate cake) so we opted for à la carte.  It might be good for the neighborhood, but coming from the FiDi,  I definitely wouldn't make a special trip to this place again!

Steak Tartare: A yucky tartare.  Way too tomato-y.  The waiter claimed there was no ketchup or tomato sauce involved, perhaps they just went Tabasco happy.  Despite having the traditional fixings, it was too bland and runny.

Bourride Provençal: Very similar in style to bouillabaisse.  The toast offering was measly and missing the shredded cheese on top of the sauce.  Also, I think whole wheat was a bad choice to soak up the broth.  I didn't like how the salmon filet was in tiny chunks as opposed to a single large piece.  The shrimp were small and tough, a sign of being overcooked.  It came with some risotto on the side which tasted more like a French-style fried rice as opposed to a typical creamy risotto.  

Cod Potato Dish: Forgot the name, but it was basically shredded cod in a mashed potato base covered in cheese.  Liked that the cod was fresh as opposed to salted.  Tasty in a buttery/creamy/cheesy way, though bland otherwise. 

Lamb Stew: Not memorable.  Tender as slow cooked lamb should be, but lacking on herbs and spices.

Ile Flottante: A delicate soft meringue floating in crème anglaise.  Great contrast of an almost burnt top and fluffy/sugary egg whites underneath.  By far the highlight of the meal.

excerpts: Also had the poached eggs with smoked salmon dish  - nothing special, your regular poached eggs with smoked salmon:)

excerpts: This charming little French bistro was the perfect end to my weekend in San Francisco.
A tasty Sunday brunch before driving back to Los Angeles was exactly what I needed.
Oeufs Copenhague is a smoked salmon "Eggs Benedict" with a buttery hollendaise that was intoxicating.
I regretfully did not get a bite of my friend's Oeufs Florentine, that greedy gus!

The Pain Perdu (French Toast) was delicately egg battered with cinnamon sugar, maple syrup and came with creme fraiche and strawberry coulis artfully swirled on the plate for dipping and a side of fresh fruit.
There is outdoor seating, very reminiscent to Parisian cafe, and an extremely friendly and helpful waitress.
I have to admit, the decor is a little old and funky.
Oversized Christmas ornaments, random vintage clocks and an odd wall sculpture featuring ducks.
.author: Theresa M.
.review:
This charming little French bistro was the perfect end to my weekend in San Francisco.  A tasty Sunday brunch before driving back to Los Angeles was exactly what I needed.  There were three of us, we had Oeufs Copenhague, Oeufs Florentine, and Pain Perdu.

Oeufs Copenhague is a smoked salmon "Eggs Benedict" with a buttery hollendaise that was intoxicating.  I regretfully did not get a bite of my friend's Oeufs Florentine, that greedy gus!  Next time for sure!

Both Oeufs dishes came with a side salad that was a nice spring mix lightly tossed with vinaigrette, and tender roasted potatoes with herbs.

The Pain Perdu (French Toast) was delicately egg battered with cinnamon sugar, maple syrup and came with creme fraiche and strawberry coulis artfully swirled on the plate for dipping and a side of fresh fruit.  We all agreed that the maple syrup could have been served on the side rather than drizzled on top, that way there was the option to choose between the different sauces available, but the combination of maple syrup and strawberry / cream was actually pretty darn delicious.

There is outdoor seating, very reminiscent to Parisian cafe, and an extremely friendly and helpful waitress.  If you want to practice your French she'll gladly oblige, or answer questions about what the dishes or just help with translation or pronunciation if you wish.  

I have to admit, the decor is a little old and funky.  Oversized Christmas ornaments, random vintage clocks and an odd wall sculpture featuring ducks.  I also spotted Julia Child's "Mastering the Art of French Cooking" among the spices in the tiny kitchen.

Baker St. Bistro is quirky but it's completely endearing.

excerpts: Great lunch, but bring a blanket.
We stopped into the Baker Street Bistro at about 1:45 PM.
There were two other tables occupied.
The service was largely indifferent.
The restaurant was very cold.
When I asked about turning on a clearly evident electric heater, I was told that it wasn't working and that the entire building had no heat.
Is someone trying to lower their heating bill?
It is ridiculous to erode a decent restaurant by freezing its customers.
Buy a heater or fix the one mounted on the front of the bar.
Boo!
.author: Mel C.
.review:
Great lunch, but bring a blanket.  We stopped into the Baker Street Bistro at about 1:45 PM.  There were two other tables occupied.  The service was largely indifferent.  The lunch was great.

The restaurant was very cold.  When I asked about turning on a clearly evident electric heater, I was told that it wasn't working and that the entire building had no heat.  Is someone trying to lower their heating bill?  It is ridiculous to erode a decent restaurant by freezing its customers.  Buy a heater or fix the one mounted on the front of the bar.  Boo!

excerpts: This place is "meh" defined.
and I found ourselves in the area on Saturday night and were able to snag a last-minute reservation.
My friends claimed that the lamb stew and the mussels were both very tasty.
For that, I would bump this review up to 2.5 stars, though I didn't try either of the dishes
I ordered the scallops and my boyfriend ordered the salmon.
Having tried both of them, I am shocked that the other food was tasty.
My scallops were almost entirely devoid of flavor, and the little taste they had was fishy and unpleasant.
I had 4 scallops on my plate
and I could only stomach 1.
My boyfriend's salmon was no better and the portion size was miniscule.
He finished his salmon, then ate the rest of my scallops and declared that they were much better than his salmon.
The side order of fries was very tasty.
Good thing, too,
The profiteroles filled with ice cream were delicious.
Very heavy, but delicious.
Given the experience, our bill was entirely too high.
I think we paid $30 each, and that does not include appetizers or drinks.
.author: Julie S.
.review:
This place is "meh" defined.  Though Baker Street Bistro oozes with Parisian charm, the high prices do not justify the mediocrity of the food.  

A few friends and I found ourselves in the area on Saturday night and were able to snag a last-minute reservation.  Between us, we ordered the following:
- Scallops special
- Salmon special
- Lamb Stew
- Mussels
- An extra order of fries
- Profiteroles for dessert

My friends claimed that the lamb stew and the mussels were both very tasty.  For that, I would bump this review up to 2.5 stars, though I didn't try either of the dishes so I can't confirm.  

I ordered the scallops and my boyfriend ordered the salmon.  Having tried both of them, I am shocked that the other food was tasty.  My scallops were almost entirely devoid of flavor, and the little taste they had was fishy and unpleasant.  I had 4 scallops on my plate and I could only stomach 1.  My boyfriend's salmon was no better and the portion size was miniscule.  He finished his salmon, then ate the rest of my scallops and declared that they were much better than his salmon.  Poor soul.  

The side order of fries was very tasty.  Good thing, too, since this constituted the bulk of my meal (very healthy, I know).

The profiteroles filled with ice cream were delicious.  Very heavy, but delicious.  I recommend them for dessert.

Given the experience, our bill was entirely too high.  I think we paid $30 each, and that does not include appetizers or drinks.  Our meal definitely was not worth that much.  

I think it's safe to say that I won't be back.

excerpts: I love this place and have always have great food/service here for over 15 years.
Owners have changed, but our last visit was as fantastic as it was 20 years ago.
If you looking for a small quaint bistro with high quality food and great service, this is the place for you.
.author: Dwight D.
.review: I love this place and have always have great food/service here for over 15 years.  Owners have changed, but our last visit was as fantastic as it was 20 years ago.    If you looking for a small quaint bistro with high quality food and great service, this is the place for you.

excerpts: For a long time, I used to think that going out to eat at a good French restaurant meant having to dress a little nicer than usual and having to double - make that triple - check your bank account.
This is delicious, simple, everyday French food.
Not the "ooh
la la fancy" French cuisine
(I know, I need to curb my stereotypes), but the food you'd expect to get if you came across a crowded cafe on a run-down, hidden street in Paris on a late Thursday night.
In other words, solid, everyperson fare
The woman who runs the place is charming and friendly.
The atmosphere fuss-free.
The moules Provençale avec frites (Provencal style mussels with fries for you non french speaking folks out there) lovely.
And if that's not enough for you to give it a try next time you're on the Presidio side of the city, their event specials just might convince you.
Par exemple, Free Dessert Day?
All you can eat moules Provençale avec frites during Bastille Day?
The affordable prix fixe four course dinners during Xmas and NYE?
Sacrebleu!
.author: Mo R.
.review:
For a long time, I used to think that going out to eat at a good French restaurant meant having to dress a little nicer than usual and having to double - make that triple - check your bank account.  How sad and ignorant was I in those tender, innocent days... 

My jaunts to Baker Street Bistro were often with coworkers in tow since it was one of the few good eateries within a 5 minute drive of where we worked, but from those early "professional-tinged" visits, I have grown increasingly fond of this little place.  

This is delicious, simple, everyday French food.  Not the "ooh la la fancy" French cuisine (I know, I need to curb my stereotypes), but the food you'd expect to get if you came across a crowded cafe on a run-down, hidden street in Paris on a late Thursday night.  In other words, solid, everyperson fare that's fresh and well made.   

The woman who runs the place is charming and friendly.  The atmosphere fuss-free.  The moules Provençale avec frites (Provencal style mussels with fries for you non french speaking folks out there) lovely.  And if that's not enough for you to give it a try next time you're on the Presidio side of the city, their event specials just might convince you.  Par exemple, Free Dessert Day?  All you can eat moules Provençale avec frites during Bastille Day?  The affordable prix fixe four course dinners during Xmas and NYE?  Sacrebleu!

excerpts: Went for a birthday dinner with a party of 4, and from the moment we walked in the door it was almost as if our waiter was offended that we were there.
However, despite his service, this place was a great place to have dinner.
Ordered 3 appetizers and each was absolutely delicious, Escargot, French Onion Soup and Oysters.
Everyone I was with thoroughly enjoyed their meals, and for the quality of food it is actually priced relatively affordable.
Maybe the service is part of a French schtick as CJ's review a while ago mentioned, "Service is typically French--a little brusque, slightly hurried, and not all that friendly.
In other words, authentic.
.author: Will H.
.review:
Went for a birthday dinner with a party of 4, and from the moment we walked in the door it was almost as if our waiter was offended that we were there.  I'm talking literally uncomfortable, especially since the place is a cozy dining area with maybe 12 tables indoors.

However, despite his service, this place was a great place to have dinner.  Ordered 3 appetizers and each was absolutely delicious, Escargot, French Onion Soup and Oysters.
Everyone I was with thoroughly enjoyed their meals, and for the quality of food it is actually priced relatively affordable.  ($16-$20 plates)

If I could rank the quality of food it would be 5 stars without a doubt, with the service receiving a 1 star.

Maybe the service is part of a French schtick as CJ's review a while ago mentioned, "Service is typically French--a little brusque, slightly hurried, and not all that friendly.  In other words, authentic."

excerpts:
05.07.11

Was here for brunch after nabbing some cute dresses from a sample sale.
It was packed inside, so we were seated outside.
Took a few minutes for the menu and water.
Another 10 or so for the bread.
Another 20 to get our order.
I get it, it's a small restaurant, and you're not used to all this traffic.
You have one busboy and one waitress.
What seems like an hour later (and probably was), we finally got our food.
Florentine benedict and an omelet.
Not hard, but the kitchen was obviously backed up.
.author: Jenny L.
.review:
05.07.11

Was here for brunch after nabbing some cute dresses from a sample sale.  I was definitely on a shopping high, but the wait at BSB brought it down low.

It was packed inside, so we were seated outside.  Took a few minutes for the menu and water.  Another 10 or so for the bread.  Another 20 to get our order.  I get it, it's a small restaurant, and you're not used to all this traffic.  You have one busboy and one waitress.  But...I was hungry.

What seems like an hour later (and probably was), we finally got our food.  Florentine benedict and an omelet.  Not hard, but the kitchen was obviously backed up.  We devoured the dishes in less than 15 minutes and asked for the check.

In fear of another half hour late, we dropped cash and got out of there as quickly as we can.

Definitely a different experience this second time around.

Damage for two: $30

excerpts: I came here  with my mom once when I was younger and decided to go with my friends now that I live in SF.
.author: J R.
.review:
I really like this place. I came here  with my mom once when I was younger and decided to go with my friends now that I live in SF.

The food was really good. I got the salmon tartare and the cassoulet, and they were both hella good. It's a bit overpriced for the regular items, but the prix fixe menu is damn good deal.

The desserts are all really good, too.

It has a "a small, intimate Parisian bistro" atmosphere, which is cool for going on a date. Unfortunately for couples having dinner that night, we were being pretty drunk and rowdy =)

excerpts: I had the french toast, and most people had the eggs benedict (which, strangely enough was served with fries.
.author: Izzy A.
.review:
Recently had brunch here on a Sunday morning. There were 7 of us, but at 9.30am we had no trouble getting a nice outdoor table (that would have been difficult had we turned up any later, especially as they only take reservations for groups of 10 or more).

Service was very good and food was great. I had the french toast, and most people had the eggs benedict (which, strangely enough was served with fries.  I thought this rather odd at 9.30 in the morning!).

Water and coffee refills were good, and we never felt rushed. Another bonus to going early in the morning - parking was easy. How often do you get to say that in the City??
The only negative aspect was the dog sat at the table next to us, yes, AT the table - yuck!

excerpts: Saw it on
Check Please Bay Area.
Came for my birthday.
The French onion soup was great...
Not salty like many other places.
The salad greens were fresh with right amount of light dressing.
I had duck...
just right.
My husband had scallops..really good.
Wines are from France,..
Waitress let us taste glass of wine.
Didn't need to order a bottle to taste.
Had a strawberry dessert with balsamic vinegar, black pepper and ice cream...
Delicious!
.author: Cece D.
.review: Highly recommend. Saw it on  Check Please Bay Area. Came for my birthday. The French onion soup was great... Not salty like many other places. The salad greens were fresh with right amount of light dressing. I had duck...just right. My husband had scallops..really good. Wines are from France,.. Waitress let us taste glass of wine. Didn't need to order a bottle to taste. Had a strawberry dessert with balsamic vinegar, black pepper and ice cream... Delicious!

excerpts: Came here before a show at the Palace of Fine Arts Theater.
Pretty small place, so reservations would be a good idea.
It was a cold night and we went early, so they used brought inside the outdoor propane heater which made it pretty warm inside.
Cluttered French-looking decor.
French-accented wait staff.
The steak was great.
The mussels in white wine were not only tasty, you got a pretty decently sized portion.
Nice sliced french bread to start.
Absolutely fabulous fries!
Tough neighborhood parking.
.author: Doctor G.
.review:
Came here before a show at the Palace of Fine Arts Theater.  Pretty small place, so reservations would be a good idea.  It was a cold night and we went early, so they used brought inside the outdoor propane heater which made it pretty warm inside.  Later when more diners arrived, the collective body temperature made things comfortable and they put the propane heaters back outside for winter al fresco dining.  

Cluttered French-looking decor.  French-accented wait staff.  Felt like a bistro.

The steak was great.  The mussels in white wine were not only tasty, you got a pretty decently sized portion.  Nice sliced french bread to start.  Absolutely fabulous fries!  They were not pretentious enough to refuse my request for ketchup for my fries.  

Tough neighborhood parking.  Be prepared to walk a bit from wherever you find parking.  

Another good meal like this, and I'll be awarding a rare four stars.

excerpts: It was perfect.
Huge portions of everything.
great flavor, cooked to absolute perfection.
There are a lot of tasty things to try here.
.author: Rick R.
.review:
So I woke up this morning and I had one thing on my mind.....Steak and Eggs.   I hoped on yelp and searched for steak and eggs along with "brunch" checked and the first review that came up was from a guy claiming the steak at Baker st Bistro was a big as his face.

Sounds perfect.   

While well out of my normal haunt, we drove to BSB and were delighted to find outdoor seating with no wait at 10am.

Win

Ordered the Steak and Eggs.   It was perfect.  Huge portions of everything.   great flavor, cooked to absolute perfection.   There are a lot of tasty things to try here.   I will definitely be back for the croque madame.

Staff was also wonderful.

BSB - You win.

excerpts: Great for business lunches.
Delicious selection of seafood dishes.
Ham and cheese baguette was delectable and came with a fine salad.
.author: Ali B.
.review: Really friendly and professional service. Great for business lunches.  Delicious selection of seafood dishes.  Ham and cheese baguette was delectable and came with a fine salad.

excerpts: Speaking to her in French was a wonderful opportunity to practice the language,  and she was extremely welcoming.
Would definitely go again to at least say hello!
.author: Travis L.
.review:
One of the best decisions I've ever made in terms of wandering into a restaurant. Myself and a friend, after a long walk around Golden Gate, decided to step in for lunch, and I was pleasantly surprised to have one of the best confit de canard that I've ever had. Wonderfully crisp skin yet still tender meat coupled with fried potatoes and a stuffed tomato. My friend was extremely satisfied by the croque-monsieur, which was quite large and prepared exactly as I remember them to be in France. 

Our waitress was wonderful, constantly checking in on us. I felt very at home, especially because she spoke a blend of Creole and English. Speaking to her in French was a wonderful opportunity to practice the language,  and she was extremely welcoming. Would definitely go again to at least say hello!

excerpts: We repeatedly asked to have our cups refilled and it took probably 20 minutes before coffee arrived.
While the food was delivered to the table in a reasonable period of time, no one ever returned to ask us if everything was okay
or if we were enjoying the meal.
I would return to the restaurant in a pinch
but it's not on the top of my list.
.author: Frank H.
.review: The food was really good and the price was relatively reasonable. The restaurant is super cute and the staff is nice.   Overall, the service was lacking. We were there for brunch and ordered drinks which seem to take forever to arrive. Coffee refills were almost nonexistent. We repeatedly asked to have our cups refilled and it took probably 20 minutes before coffee arrived.  While the food was delivered to the table in a reasonable period of time, no one ever returned to ask us if everything was okay or if we were enjoying the meal.  I would return to the restaurant in a pinch but it's not on the top of my list.

excerpts: Baker Street Bistro has been a mainstay for me and my husband.
We came here for our first Valentine's together 10 years ago, and we have been back nearly every year since.
It is such a cozy place, and they have excellent food and service.
At our dinner 10 years ago, we were college students looking for a romantic evening on a budget...and they weren't snobby about it or anything.
Realistically, I acknowledge that there are other restaurants that might a more delicious (e.g., Bouchon has better duck).
However, the food is solid (I'd say 90th percentile) and we know that we're in for a wonderful evening every time we go.
.author: Fontane L.
.review:
Baker Street Bistro has been a mainstay for me and my husband.  We came here for our first Valentine's together 10 years ago, and we have been back nearly every year since.  It is such a cozy place, and they have excellent food and service.  At our dinner 10 years ago, we were college students looking for a romantic evening on a budget...and they weren't snobby about it or anything.  They've never failed to disappoint us.

Minor caveat: Realistically, I acknowledge that there are other restaurants that might a more delicious (e.g., Bouchon has better duck).  However, the food is solid (I'd say 90th percentile) and we know that we're in for a wonderful evening every time we go.

excerpts: I came here regularly for awhile.
This place is cute, but it's really past its time.
Also, the staff here are not friendly.
The only one who is nice is the woman who works here.
.author: Erika C.
.review:
I came here regularly for awhile.  This place is cute, but it's really past its time.  Go to Bistro Central Parc instead; same folks run it, but it's a newer location.

Also, the staff here are not friendly.  The only one who is nice is the woman who works here.

excerpts: "A-OK".
Food was decent -- didn't blow my mind, but it was satisfying.
I had the duck breast l'Orange.
The real annoyances were the service, selection and prices.
Service was slow and our waiter just had that forced, fake style of waiting that makes my skin crawl.
the prices are about $2-3 dollars more than listed on their menu online.
You'll mostly be paying in the $20-$22 range for an entree (more for specials), and this was a bummer for us
b/c
we picked it thinking most would be under $20.
.author: Cersei L.
.review:
This place lives up to the Yelp 3-star moniker -- "A-OK".  That's sort of how I felt after leaving.  

The atmosphere is really nice, intimate and cozy, a good place to have a long casual meal with someone.

Food was decent -- didn't blow my mind, but it was satisfying.  I had the duck breast l'Orange.  Duck was overcooked and lacked a good layer of crispy melty fat that really makes duck knock my socks off.

The real annoyances were the service, selection and prices.  Service was slow and our waiter just had that forced, fake style of waiting that makes my skin crawl.  Many of the items on the menu were not available, including the duck confit, which was my original choice.

AND NOTE BENE: the prices are about $2-3 dollars more than listed on their menu online.  You'll mostly be paying in the $20-$22 range for an entree (more for specials), and this was a bummer for us b/c we picked it thinking most would be under $20.

excerpts: We have been hitting this place for years, but usually for the brunch.
Best eggs bene in town by my account.
Perfect place when the weather is nice, outside seating in a cool neighborhood.
Head over to the Final Final for the big game and some more pre-lunch libations.
.author: Michael B.
.review: We have been hitting this place for years, but usually for the brunch.  Best eggs bene in town by my account.  Perfect place when the weather is nice, outside seating in a cool neighborhood.  Head over to the Final Final for the big game and some more pre-lunch libations.

excerpts: Went here before going to see Cavalia last week and had a surprisingly delicious, authentic French dinner.
The place it TINY
and we had 7 people in our group so the seating was a bit snug
but it worked.
I had the salad with goat cheese to start and the salmon special for dinner.
The salad was huge and the goat cheese was encrusted with walnuts with a delicate dressing that was perfect.
The salmon was cooked exactly the way it should be, tender with lots of butter.
A couple people had ordered the French onion soup and said it was legit
and I did see big, gooey globs of cheese.
My hubby ordered the classic steak with salad and frites and all were superb.
Very cute place with outside seating.
I will for sure be going back!
.author: Sara D.
.review:
Went here before going to see Cavalia last week and had a surprisingly delicious, authentic French dinner.  The place it TINY and we had 7 people in our group so the seating was a bit snug but it worked.
I had the salad with goat cheese to start and the salmon special for dinner. The salad was huge and the goat cheese was encrusted with walnuts with a delicate dressing that was perfect. The salmon was cooked exactly the way it should be, tender with lots of butter. A couple people had ordered the French onion soup and said it was legit and I did see big, gooey globs of cheese. My hubby ordered the classic steak with salad and frites and all were superb.
Very cute place with outside seating. I will for sure be going back!

excerpts: We went to Baker Street Bistro in Sept of 2013 while on our honeymoon.
We arrived there for a late supper about 45 minutes before closing, and were treated to the most amazing meal we have ever had!
Though the other guests had left and most of the staff, our lovely hostess assured us that it was no inconvenience for us to linger and enjoy.
So we did.
We'll into the night.
The pate and escargots were mind blowing.
The quality of the ingredients in the French onion soup was easily the best we ever had.
The duck leg confit, cooked in its own fat, was so tender and delicious, and the duck medallions absolutely brilliant!
We sipped on a bottle of French wine while we dined and were tended to attentively by our hostess.
Each course was timed perfectly, so
no overlapping on the table.
Our hostess watched us carefully, bringing out the next course only when we had finished the previous one.
I wish I had gotten her name... as the service was outstanding.
Once finished with the meal, we asked to finish our wine outside on the patio so they could clear the dining room.
We lingered outside in the lovely night, sipping our wine, reminiscing on the meal we just had, and the excellent service.
Our hostess invited us back to have French toast for brunch over the weekend.
How could we say no?
We returned for a delicious breakfast to the only place in the city we went to more than once.
I could have gone every day if it was up to me.
Next trip to SF definitely includes many visits back to Baker Street bistro.
Thank you for making our trip that much more special.
.author: Sharon L.
.review:
We went to Baker Street Bistro in Sept of 2013 while on our honeymoon.  We arrived there for a late supper about 45 minutes before closing, and were treated to the most amazing meal we have ever had!  Though the other guests had left and most of the staff, our lovely hostess assured us that it was no inconvenience for us to linger and enjoy.  So we did.  We'll into the night.
The pate and escargots were mind blowing.  The quality of the ingredients in the French onion soup was easily the best we ever had.
The duck leg confit, cooked in its own fat, was so tender and delicious, and the duck medallions absolutely brilliant!
We sipped on a bottle of French wine while we dined and were tended to attentively by our hostess.
Each course was timed perfectly, so no overlapping on the table.  Our hostess watched us carefully, bringing out the next course only when we had finished the previous one.  I wish I had gotten her name... as the service was outstanding.
Once finished with the meal, we asked to finish our wine outside on the patio so they could clear the dining room.  We lingered outside in the lovely night, sipping our wine, reminiscing on the meal we just had, and the excellent service.
Our hostess invited us back to have French toast for brunch over the weekend.  How could we say no?  We returned for a delicious breakfast to the only place in the city we went to more than once.  I could have gone every day if it was up to me.  Next trip to SF definitely includes many visits back to Baker Street bistro.  Thank you for making our trip that much more special.

excerpts: I love neighborhood bistros.
Just not this particular one.
Everything about it should work.
The menu reads well, the location is tucked away from all the hubub, it's quaint, it's got a chalkboard with wines listed by the glass...
The wine immediately put me on a different course.
As others have noted here, you'll be sorely disappointed by the pour if you order a wine by the glass.
The food kind of went downhill from there.
The duck alternated between horribly overcooked on one end, to still-squacking-like-Daffy on the other end.
My guess?
They've been doing this for so long that they're just kind of mailing it in at this point...
.author: Laurence W.
.review:
I love neighborhood bistros.  Just not this particular one.  Everything about it should work.  The menu reads well, the location is tucked away from all the hubub, it's quaint, it's got a chalkboard with wines listed by the glass... Everything feels right.

The wine immediately put me on a different course.  As others have noted here, you'll be sorely disappointed by the pour if you order a wine by the glass.  It isn't dictated by the waiter but rather by the thimble-sized wine glasses they use. 

The food kind of went downhill from there.  The duck alternated between horribly overcooked on one end, to still-squacking-like-Daffy on the other end. The seafood stew had its own challenges, featuring way-overcooked salmon and scallops, though the shrimp magically came out perfectly in a rich tasting lobster broth.

My guess?  They've been doing this for so long that they're just kind of mailing it in at this point...

excerpts: I've been meaning to try this place for years.
First off, loved our server.
She was always there, but never intrusive..
The mussels were to die for, and the broth was perfect.
The fries could have been shared; huge portion.
My friend had the lamb chops, and I don't like lamb, but had to try them.
The noise level was low, and it made for easy conversation.
.author: Jennifer T.
.review:
I've been meaning to try this place for years.  Finally went, and am kicking myself for not trying earlier. 

First off, loved our server.  She was always there, but never intrusive..  The mussels were to die for, and the broth was perfect.  The fries could have been shared; huge portion.  My friend had the lamb chops, and I don't like lamb, but had to try them.  They were also great...and again, I don't like lamb.  

The noise level was low, and it made for easy conversation.  The prices were reasonable: glass of wine, shared appetizer, entrée, and 2 shared desserts was about $45 per person.

I think overall, you'd be hard pressed to find a more charming spot with better food.

excerpts: Dinner for 4 started out with the restaurant barely full but bursting at the seams within minutes of our arrival.
A happy buzz in a very pleasing space.
Tables are very very tiny
so it is a bit of a challenge to manage wine bottle, glass, water after the large entree platters arrive.
I had lamb chops which came out perfectly medium and deliciously flavorful.
Hubby had steak grille which was excellent with the most wonderful frites.
Friends had beef bouguignon and the chops and enjoyed them as well.
Split the mereingue in a custardy sauce with my hubby - he liked, I found it too eggy.
.author: Ash A.
.review:
Dinner for 4 started out with the restaurant barely full but bursting at the seams within minutes of our arrival.  A happy buzz in a very pleasing space.  Tables are very very tiny so it is a bit of a challenge to manage wine bottle, glass, water after the large entree platters arrive.
I had lamb chops which came out perfectly medium and deliciously flavorful.  Hubby had steak grille which was excellent with the most wonderful frites.  Friends had beef bouguignon and the chops and enjoyed them as well.  Split the mereingue in a custardy sauce with my hubby - he liked, I found it too eggy.

excerpts: Their menu is somewhat limited, and their portion sizes aren't large, but it's still one of my favorite restaurants in the Marina area.
Why?
The food is consistently good (as long as you're not expecting big portions), and the atmosphere is perfect for a relaxing get-together with your significant other or a few friends.
Seating is cozy.
You don't have to scream to be heard.
Patrons are respectful.
Never had to put up with loud and obnoxious diners.
.author: Robert C.
.review: Their menu is somewhat limited, and their portion sizes aren't large, but it's still one of my favorite restaurants in the Marina area.  Why?  The food is consistently good (as long as you're not expecting big portions), and the atmosphere is perfect for a relaxing get-together with your significant other or a few friends.  Seating is cozy.  You don't have to scream to be heard.  Patrons are respectful.  Never had to put up with loud and obnoxious diners.

excerpts: I came here for brunch and left slightly disappointed, possibly because I had BSB hyped up in my head.
However, the food itself fell short.
I ordered the Steak a Cheval (steak and eggs, and though the steak was large (as long as my hand), I asked for it medium rare, and received a medium-done steak.
It was hard to enjoy after cutting into the big slab of meat and finding not a hint of pink anywhere, and the meat was too chewy.
The eggs were better, scrambled in butter.
.author: Kira K.
.review:
I came here for brunch and left slightly disappointed, possibly because I had BSB hyped up in my head.  I loved the French atmosphere, as the Francophile that I am, and the service was very charming - our French waiter with the piercing blue eyes was very pleasant.

However, the food itself fell short.  I ordered the Steak a Cheval (steak and eggs, and though the steak was large (as long as my hand), I asked for it medium rare, and received a medium-done steak.  It was hard to enjoy after cutting into the big slab of meat and finding not a hint of pink anywhere, and the meat was too chewy.  The eggs were better, scrambled in butter.  My dish came with a side of salad and potatoes, and for $16.50 would have been better had the steak been cooked better.

I'm willing to give BSB another try, and chalk up the steak fiasco to a loss in translation.

excerpts:
Meal: brunch
Service: seated quickly only with a reservation; dessert menu and bill took forever
Ordered: Croque Madame and Crème Brulée; tried others' Oeufs Benedicte and Tarte Tartin à la Poire

Personally preferred the Oeufs Benedicte to the Croque Madame, but only because the latter was a little too oily for me and I realized I don't like Swiss cheese as much as I thought I did.
.author: D. A.
.review:
Meal: brunch
Service: seated quickly only with a reservation; dessert menu and bill took forever
Ordered: Croque Madame and Crème Brulée; tried others' Oeufs Benedicte and Tarte Tartin à la Poire

Personally preferred the Oeufs Benedicte to the Croque Madame, but only because the latter was a little too oily for me and I realized I don't like Swiss cheese as much as I thought I did.  The portions were generous and both desserts tasted absolutely amazing!

excerpts: last night we found one that we will go back visit again when we are in SF.
It is always nice to fine a local neighborhood bistro when you are traveling.
.author: Kyle S.
.review: Last night my wife a friend and I enjoyed a very nice dinner. The service was friendly and not overwhelming. When we travel we always look for the off the beat spot and last night we found one that we will go back visit again when we are in SF.  It is always nice to fine a local neighborhood bistro when you are traveling.

excerpts: Have been here three times after the Presidio 10K, but I swear this review is not in any way affected by eating here after running my ass off.
Cute, small, French bistro on a side street in the Marina with very tasy coffee, bacon, eggs Florentine, and french toast.
The seating is a bit cramped inside but the oudoor patio seating is much more spacious.
.author: Julie M.
.review:
Have been here three times after the Presidio 10K, but I swear this review is not in any way affected by eating here after running my ass off.  At this point it's an annual tradition; 6 years of Presidio 10, last three celebrated at Baker Street.

Cute, small, French bistro on a side street in the Marina with very tasy coffee, bacon, eggs Florentine, and french toast.  The seating is a bit cramped inside but the oudoor patio seating is much more spacious.  Waiters are very French and were probably judging friend and me in our sweaty running clothes and sweet runner's hair.  

Yum.

excerpts: When the reservation was made online, it specifically asked if this was for a special occasions--ie--anniversary, birthday, etc.
I had placed birthday.
But nothing was ever done that evening to honor that occasion-not even a candle on the dessert.
While the onion soup was very good, it was nothing spectacular.
I ordered the lamb chops which came luke-warm, and there was more gristle than meat on the chop.
Also, it came with no green vegetable.
Not once did anyone come over to ask how everything was.
They only did that after we were done.
The staff were too busy either on their cell phone or chatting with some of their "regulars".
We did order dessert which I think was the best thing I had ordered.
I saw no real French in the kitchen.
And when the bill came, it was outrageous.
.author: David P.
.review: When the reservation was made online, it specifically asked if this was for a special occasions--ie--anniversary, birthday, etc.  I had placed birthday.  But nothing was ever done that evening to honor that occasion-not even a candle on the dessert.  While the onion soup was very good, it was nothing spectacular.  I ordered the lamb chops which came luke-warm, and there was more gristle than meat on the chop.  Also, it came with no green vegetable.  Not once did anyone come over to ask how everything was.  They only did that after we were done.  The staff were too busy either on their cell phone or chatting with some of their "regulars".  We did order dessert which I think was the best thing I had ordered.  I saw no real French in the kitchen.   And when the bill came, it was outrageous.

excerpts: I love how cute and unassuming this place is.
The food was great--I had brunch here with my siblings, and it honestly was like being transported to an charming Parisian cafe.
.author: Caroline L.
.review:
I love how cute and unassuming this place is.  The food was great--I had brunch here with my siblings, and it honestly was like being transported to an charming Parisian cafe.  Their french toast and croque monsieur are top notch.  

We went here because we didn't want to wait in the ridiculous line at Mama's (I'm sure it's good too, but I really have no idea because I never have patience for that line), and it was a good call.

excerpts: I definitely was not impressed.
