Baker street bistro is very cute and has a nice location away from the craziness that can be the marina and cow hollow on the weekends, but i just wasn't impressed with the brunch.
service was slow, food was only ok, and they actually didn't even really listen when i asked them to go light on something that would make me sick.
i don't think i'd come back here for brunch.
.author: Lisa C.
.review: I definitely was not impressed.  Baker street bistro is very cute and has a nice location away from the craziness that can be the marina and cow hollow on the weekends, but i just wasn't impressed with the brunch.  service was slow, food was only ok, and they actually didn't even really listen when i asked them to go light on something that would make me sick.  i don't think i'd come back here for brunch.

excerpts: and I went there for dinner at around 7pm on a Tuesday (I think).
Inside seating had all been booked, so we opted to sit on the patio and were seated in seconds.
and it was superb.
The portions were just right although I could have done with more croutons.
Walnut chunks and grapes were provided to compliment the floors of the cheese.
I ordered the pork chops (medium rare).
They were succulent and very well seasoned, but the stuffed tomato stole the show.
I could frankly eat an entire plate of those things.
My friend ordered the steak.
It was about 30% fat and wasn't that tasty.
Overall the experience was very positive.
The service was quick and courteous and the food was quite good.
.author: Julian S.
.review:
Make no mistake, Baker Street Bistro is a nice hidden gem in Northern San Fran, but it's not perfect.

Two friends and I went there for dinner at around 7pm on a Tuesday (I think).  Inside seating had all been booked, so we opted to sit on the patio and were seated in seconds.  The service outside was seemingly as prompt as it was inside.

The wine and beer selection is somewhat limited given the small size of the establishment, but what they have is more than acceptable.

A friend and I split the assorted cheeses for a starter and it was superb.  The portions were just right although I could have done with more croutons.  Walnut chunks and grapes were provided to compliment the floors of the cheese.  It was a very satisfying apeteiser.

I ordered the pork chops (medium rare).  They were succulent and very well seasoned, but the stuffed tomato stole the show.  I could frankly eat an entire plate of those things.  There was also a tasty but forgettable potato side.

My friend ordered the steak.  It was about 30% fat and wasn't that tasty.  Pretty disappointing for a $20 dish.

Overall the experience was very positive.  The service was quick and courteous and the food was quite good.  I might not return here when I'm back in San Fran because of its distance from everything that is cultural and cool about the city, but I would definitively recommend it to anyone looking to grab a bite in that particular area.

Also, one of my party claimed Willem Dafoe was dining inside, but I sincerely don't think it was him (although it totally might have been . . . I mean, who eats alone on a weekday?).

excerpts: French bistro please,  I have been to France, where the servers were pleasant and the food good
, this was a so so restaurant with a guy running around talking in a French accent.
.author: Toren V.
.review: On vacation strolling around our hotel, we come upon a bistro, seems nice so we take a seat. A man comes out and pushes the tables together, because our large party of three needed more room. Menus, bread and water follow quickly. I asked for a Chimay, but i am told their is only Duval ,, ok. so I wait, order taken I order chicken, wife salmon, son burger. Others seated, wifes french onion soup comes, still waiting for the beer, others get wine, refills, still no beer. Finally I ask for it, and the server says "oh" and then brings it out. As the dinner crowd thins out Daniel stares out at our table and then brings the food, My chicken lifeless tastless hunks that anyone could cook up. My wife likes her salmon, son hates the burger. i hate the service most of all, the thing I hate the worst, to be forgotten while others are laughing wine-ing and dining. French bistro please,  I have been to France, where the servers were pleasant and the food good, this was a so so restaurant with a guy running around talking in a French accent.

excerpts: I checked out the menu and was set on ordering the Oeufs Baker Street Bistro which is  ratatouille, poached eggs, w/ tomato sauce.
OMG.. so good.
When (not if!)
I come back, I'm going to order this again..
I don't even want to try anything else on their menu!
.author: Lina W.
.review:
This place is extremely cutesy! My friends and I came here this past Sunday on a rare, beautiful and warm day. We came here right before the lunch rush and was able to secure a seat outside. 

I already knew what I wanted before I came here!! I checked out the menu and was set on ordering the Oeufs Baker Street Bistro which is  ratatouille, poached eggs, w/ tomato sauce. OMG.. so good. When (not if!) I come back, I'm going to order this again.. I don't even want to try anything else on their menu! This is comparable to La Note's Ratatouille/Eggs Benedict.

One star less for the service. It got pretty swamped while we were there, but our waitress/server got our order wrong and took forever with the bill.

excerpts: It's a refreshing change to experience French cuisine without amputating your arm or your leg.
Fiance and I ate here on a Saturday night around 9:15pm
Pros:
I appreciate a French restaurant where the chef and the staff actually speaks French.
The location of this bistro is very unassuming with seats both inside and outside the restaurant.
The menu had enough selections without feeling like they were trying too hard.

While they were out of the oysters (which I was told was delightful), we couldn't help ourselves and ordered 3 appetizers to share - the escargot, a foie gras terrine, and an assortment plate with cold cuts and another pate.
They had a decent wine selection as well.
We also ordered a NY Steak and a seafood stew.
Let's talk about the food.
The foie gras terrine had a wonderfully rich flavor that made me keep reaching back for more bread.
According to the waiter, the foie gras is braised with cognac rather than port, and while the alcohol is faint, it's noticeable.
The melt in your mouth quality is superb, and it took an extreme amount of willpower not to reach over and eat my fiance's share.
The assorted meats and pate platter was very good.
If we didn't already order the terrine, I'd have attacked the pate like there was no tomorrow.
It was so good that I decided we needed to box it up and eat it the next day.
Our main course arrived with generous portions of food.
Tried a bite of fiance's NY Steak and found it acceptable, but not stellar.
My seafood stew on the other hand was wonderful.
Most seafood stews I've had had an overabundance of tomato, but the seafood broth for this dish was flavorful without taking away the individual flavors of the seafood inside.
By the time the profiteroles came along, I was more than pleasantly full.
The ice cream was teeth hurting cold, which made the chocolate sauce harden.
But it was wonderfully good.
Last but certainly not least, the waiters were superb.
It might have to do with the fact
we were the last diners of the evening, but our glasses were always full, never had a moment to complain about.
Cons:
I found Krab with a "K" in my seafood stew.
Now, I'm not an entire snob, but
Krab with a "K" had no place in there.
I'm a firm believer that if you do not have the actual decent ingredient, you don't put it in.
I definitely think it didn't need to be there, and the dish would have turned out equally wonderful.
Also, I was not in love with the escargot dish.
I think it's one of those things where the garlic butter sauce completely overpowered the escargot to the point
I couldn't really tell what I was eating.
To be honest, the size and the quality could have been better for the price they charged.
Slightly disappointed.
And lastly, I was slightly disappointed when they refused to let me get a box for the remains of my seafood stew.
They worried I might get food poisoning if I took it home with us, and did not pack it for me to go.
Was somewhat upset that they made that determination for me.
Which noble in their intent to cover their butts if I die of food poisoning, that was my call to make.
Plus, had I known they wouldn't have let me take it home, I'd have finished all my mussels!
Bottom line:
I would definitely come here again.
And I would skip the escargot.
And not share the foie gras terrine, because it's awesome.
And the best part of the night - despite all the binge ordering, the meal came out before tip, under $100.
Imagine that!
If I live in the city, I'd most assuredly come back whenever I'd like a bistro fix.
.author: Minnie L.
.review:
It's a refreshing change to experience French cuisine without amputating your arm or your leg.  Fiance and I ate here on a Saturday night around 9:15pm after spending the day in Marin.  

Pros:  I appreciate a French restaurant where the chef and the staff actually speaks French.  The location of this bistro is very unassuming with seats both inside and outside the restaurant.  Because of our late seating time, we had a wonderful little table for two by the window.  

The menu had enough selections without feeling like they were trying too hard.  While they were out of the oysters (which I was told was delightful), we couldn't help ourselves and ordered 3 appetizers to share - the escargot, a foie gras terrine, and an assortment plate with cold cuts and another pate.  They had a decent wine selection as well.  We also ordered a NY Steak and a seafood stew.  Finally, because that's the only dessert I can't possibly resist even though I'm trying to fit into a wedding dress, we shared an order of profiteroles.

Let's talk about the food.  The foie gras terrine had a wonderfully rich flavor that made me keep reaching back for more bread.  According to the waiter, the foie gras is braised with cognac rather than port, and while the alcohol is faint, it's noticeable.  The melt in your mouth quality is superb, and it took an extreme amount of willpower not to reach over and eat my fiance's share.  The assorted meats and pate platter was very good.  If we didn't already order the terrine, I'd have attacked the pate like there was no tomorrow.  It was so good that I decided we needed to box it up and eat it the next day.  Which is today, and I can still tell you it was delicious. 

Our main course arrived with generous portions of food.  Tried a bite of fiance's NY Steak and found it acceptable, but not stellar.  My seafood stew on the other hand was wonderful.  Most seafood stews I've had had an overabundance of tomato, but the seafood broth for this dish was flavorful without taking away the individual flavors of the seafood inside.  The side of risotto was also delicious.

By the time the profiteroles came along, I was more than pleasantly full.  The ice cream was teeth hurting cold, which made the chocolate sauce harden.  But it was wonderfully good.  Many restaurants don't serve this, but when I do get my fix, it's most certainly a treat.

Last but certainly not least, the waiters were superb.  It might have to do with the fact we were the last diners of the evening, but our glasses were always full, never had a moment to complain about.  We had wonderful service.

Cons:  Despite the mostly glowing review above, there were a few small things which make me unfortunately give this place a solid 4 rather than the 5 stars I so wanted.

I found Krab with a "K" in my seafood stew.  Now, I'm not an entire snob, but Krab with a "K" had no place in there.  I'm a firm believer that if you do not have the actual decent ingredient, you don't put it in.  I definitely think it didn't need to be there, and the dish would have turned out equally wonderful.  So yes, slightly disillusioned now that the seafood stew was not perfect after all.

Also, I was not in love with the escargot dish.  I think it's one of those things where the garlic butter sauce completely overpowered the escargot to the point I couldn't really tell what I was eating.  To be honest, the size and the quality could have been better for the price they charged.  Slightly disappointed.  But completely forgotten after eating a piece of the foie gras terrine (see the raving positive comments above).

And lastly, I was slightly disappointed when they refused to let me get a box for the remains of my seafood stew.  They worried I might get food poisoning if I took it home with us, and did not pack it for me to go.  Was somewhat upset that they made that determination for me.  Which noble in their intent to cover their butts if I die of food poisoning, that was my call to make.  Plus, had I known they wouldn't have let me take it home, I'd have finished all my mussels!  Argh!

Bottom line:  I would definitely come here again.  And I would skip the escargot.  And not share the foie gras terrine, because it's awesome.  And the best part of the night - despite all the binge ordering, the meal came out before tip, under $100.  Imagine that!  If I live in the city, I'd most assuredly come back whenever I'd like a bistro fix.

excerpts: We ordered mimosas and the mussels and seafood stew.
They were all very good, and the atmosphere was nice and cozy.
However, it took FOREVER to get our food, and the restaurant wasn't even very busy.
We were there for brunch around 2 so it didn't seem like there was a good reason for the wait.
.author: B. Y.
.review:
We ordered mimosas and the mussels and seafood stew.  They were all very good, and the atmosphere was nice and cozy.  However, it took FOREVER to get our food, and the restaurant wasn't even very busy.  We were there for brunch around 2 so it didn't seem like there was a good reason for the wait.  Plus the waitstaff never even acknowledged how long we had to wait.

Other than that, our food was very good, and when the waitstaff served us, they were friendly and helpful.

excerpts: Baker St. Bistro is an adorable, authentic French experience tucked away from too much Marina hubbub - it is so charming that I'm willing to overlook that the food was mostly mushy, creamy versions of protein+starch.
Occasion brought us here for dinner after walking across the GG bridge from Sausalito.
We were cold, very hungry, not so snazzily dressed, and the Bistro fit the bill.
This is a romantic casual dinner spot with excellent service and a great wine selection, unexpectedly reasonable prices (ie, $16.50 prix fixe menu! - weekends from 5:30-7), and country French food.
Hits: heirloom tomato salad, field greens, honey mustard chicken, brandied mousse.
Didn't try the duck, but a few people said this is the best dish in the restaurant.
Skip: Snapper (cooked well but mismatched with the sauce), mashed potatoes (unless you love yours pureed on almost-liquid setting and half composed of cream.
Surely some people do), vegetable soup (hearty and good enough but just not exciting).
I couldn't really decide between 3 and 4 stars - it seems to depend on what you order.
I'm rounding up because I had such a lovely evening.
.author: Jennifer B.
.review:
Baker St. Bistro is an adorable, authentic French experience tucked away from too much Marina hubbub - it is so charming that I'm willing to overlook that the food was mostly mushy, creamy versions of protein+starch.  Add salt!

Occasion brought us here for dinner after walking across the GG bridge from Sausalito.  We were cold, very hungry, not so snazzily dressed, and the Bistro fit the bill.  This is a romantic casual dinner spot with excellent service and a great wine selection, unexpectedly reasonable prices (ie, $16.50 prix fixe menu! - weekends from 5:30-7), and country French food.  Warm and cozy on an overcast day.

Hits: heirloom tomato salad, field greens, honey mustard chicken, brandied mousse.  Didn't try the duck, but a few people said this is the best dish in the restaurant.
Skip: Snapper (cooked well but mismatched with the sauce), mashed potatoes (unless you love yours pureed on almost-liquid setting and half composed of cream.  Surely some people do), vegetable soup (hearty and good enough but just not exciting).  Bread could be better.

I couldn't really decide between 3 and 4 stars - it seems to depend on what you order.  I'm rounding up because I had such a lovely evening.

excerpts: I went to dinner here with a 10 person party.
Service was excellant, and if you like French food, you will be quite happy.
I personally am not a big fan of French cuisine, but my dish was well prepared.
This is a a cozy bistro.
I would give this place a 3.5 stars.
Can't give it a 4, but better than a 3 star.
.author: Tom W.
.review: I went to dinner here with a 10 person party.  Service was excellant, and if you like French food, you will be quite happy.  I personally am not a big fan of French cuisine, but my dish was well prepared.  This is a a cozy bistro.  I would give this place a 3.5 stars.  Can't give it a 4, but better than a 3 star.

excerpts: Went here for brunch, love the renovation.
Really bright and welcoming.
I always felt like this place blended in too much to the street scape and people might not have noticed it.
The outside seating is great on a sunny day.
I had the Bistro eggs benedict
, it was super healthy (no hollandaise) and tasty.
Friendly service and the bathroom was clean and cute, something I always appreciate!
.author: Andrea R.
.review: Went here for brunch, love the renovation.  Really bright and welcoming.  I always felt like this place blended in too much to the street scape and people might not have noticed it.  The outside seating is great on a sunny day.  I had the Bistro eggs benedict, it was super healthy (no hollandaise) and tasty.  Friendly service and the bathroom was clean and cute, something I always appreciate!

excerpts: Any restaurant that puts that few wait staff on the floor when booked to the rafters must be wildly profitable.
.author: Jay D.
.review:
I do enjoy this bistro tucked away in the North-end of Cow Hollow and I'm sure it must be profitable. 

Any restaurant that puts that few wait staff on the floor when booked to the rafters must be wildly profitable.  It's at this point that I must compliment the too-few-on-ground wait staff for giving it their all and attempting to compensate for their thin numbers.

Although some times a bit heavy-handed with sauces, the overall food experience is good and we do enjoy the cozy atmosphere.

excerpts: and it's so nice to stumble into a little French Basque bistro like this.
.author: Romy I.
.review:
I happen to know the owners, which doesn't bias me at all because I can tell everyone how passionate they are about their food and how hard he works. This guy has the same amount of obsession that the owner of Burma Superstar has... (A high school friend of mine is one of her friends and knew her before she started. Wow, she was so attentive to what we did and didn't eat and constantly asking us why or why not... ). 

I can't explain it, but there are a lot of things that are very important that are hard to measure on spreadsheets. It's extremely difficult to recognize when someone's talented at business.  

 It's hard for me to even write a clever food review because it's not my territory. I'm like the truck driver wandering by mistake into the beauty salon. Heck, even I am out of my territory in the beauty salon.

French food is really a cliche in America based on the 1990s superpower Impressionist art shows in all the great museums and weird ideas based on 1890s France. I wouldn't be surprised if most American tourists stumbled out of the airplane expecting French people to be working part time on Serge Gainsbourg style videos and reading Japanese novels, which is the subconscious mentality I had.

 and it's so nice to stumble into a little French Basque bistro like this.  I didn't even -know- there were Basques in France. 

One of my best friends took me to a down-home country style French restaraunt when I was in Paris and it was a mild shock to me, because I'm so used to French food being marketed to a weird market segment, mainly nouveau riche people who like to buy $400 high heels. It was really neat. There are farmers in France and they eat food that's very different from what's usually presented. So that's the same feeling I got at the Baker Street Bistro. 

It's extremely refreshing for an uncouth barbarian like me to find stuff like this, but in truth my friends are all real-deal food and wine maniacs,   so I stumbled on this place only through their great wisdom. 

My friends like to tease me about my bad habits, as I used to never consider food this essential life item (that's what hip hop records and the truly great sneakers are for), so I appreciate them gently guiding me back to the light. 

Thanks for introducing me to this place, it's run by good people who make great food! That's something no corporate powerpoint can ever pull off consistently.

excerpts: Pretty good.
My main issue was that it seemed to take a while to get our orders, they only had 2 people working the whole time, but we just needed to be patient.
Ordered the smoked salmon salad with a poached egg.
Warning though!
their online menu is out of date.
Food items have gone up about $2 each, at least.
.author: Phil J.
.review:
Pretty good.  My main issue was that it seemed to take a while to get our orders, they only had 2 people working the whole time, but we just needed to be patient.  Ordered the smoked salmon salad with a poached egg.  Amanda got the mussels, and both very very tasty.  

Warning though!  their online menu is out of date.  Food items have gone up about $2 each, at least.

excerpts: Dessert was mandatory, of course!
Chocolate cake,
.author: David D.
.review:
I love French accents. In food, I mean. Yeah, food. 

Mom-in-law asked us when we could go to lunch a while ago. My Lady arranged for it on a Friday afternoon, during warm weather, while the markets were slow. Off we went on the 43, just a ten-minute ride! 

At about 1 pm the restaurant was about half full. The diners around us were regulars, and told us what the "good stuff" was, while we browsed the menus over kir royales. 

Not knowing what escargot was, one of us who shall remain nameless asked for it without the snails. This immediately evoked the humor of our host, who owned the restaurant, and we had a lovely time dancing through the menu choices. Ultimately, we did order the escargot and French fries. Wait, we had entrees as well. The bourride, a fish stew, was delicious. The Caesar salad was just right. The croque monsieur brought ham and cheese to a new level of consciousness. Really, it was amazing! 

Somewhere in the middle of all this we decided to order wine. Quelle surprise! Given that we were trying to decide on three glasses, the owner suggested we share a half bottle of the Sancerre 2007 sauvignon blanc. We were delighted to discover it "was fermented without introducing cultured yeasts," and we savored its complexity. 

Dessert was mandatory, of course!  Chocolate cake, creme broulee, and profiteroles graced the table, with 2 coffees and 1 tea. The whole afternoon cost $137.43 + tip, of which $25 was the Sancerre, and $25.50 was the 3 kir royales. 

We engaged the owner in conversation, and found out he was a neighbor of ours! The rumors of a new restaurant opening in NoPa turned out to be true -- lots of exciting changes are happening in our neighborhood this year. We are eagerly looking forward to the grand opening! 

Now I want to learn French so I can speak English with that accent.

excerpts: Delicious food, very cute restaurant and very professional and courteous service.
We ordered a bottle of champagne at the end of  the meal and it was quite sweet when we tasted it; hot what we were expecting.
Our server said, no problem!
Let me have you try this rose sparkling wine.
That was perfect and we had that bottle instead.
Would definitely come back...
the food was fantastic and the portion sizes were VERY generous.
5 stars!
.author: Janelle C.
.review: Delicious food, very cute restaurant and very professional and courteous service.  We ordered a bottle of champagne at the end of  the meal and it was quite sweet when we tasted it; hot what we were expecting.  Our server said, no problem!  Let me have you try this rose sparkling wine.  That was perfect and we had that bottle instead.  Would definitely come back...the food was fantastic and the portion sizes were VERY generous.  5 stars!

excerpts: We discovered Baker Street Bistro one Sunday morning while looking to branch out from our typical brunch locations in the Inner Richmond.
What a find!
The Nicoise salad immediately caught my eye.
Unlike the nicoise salads I've enjoyed at Harry's Bar and at Park Chow, this one was served with "canned tuna."
At first glance, I didn't think the canned tuna would have a chance against a seared ahi tuna.
Well, simply speaking, I was wrong.
The salad, which was huge, came with all the typical nicoise fixings, including olives, potatoes, hard-boiled eggs, and peppers.
The crowning glory was a healthy helping of a flavorful tuna salad which was far from boring.
Well done!
Bottom line, the staff was very pleasant, the service timely, and the food  high quality.
We hope to visit BSB again very soon.
.author: Tim N.
.review:
We discovered Baker Street Bistro one Sunday morning while looking to branch out from our typical brunch locations in the Inner Richmond.  What a find!  It's a great little place with a romantic ambiance and a creative menu of French-inspired dishes.

The Nicoise salad immediately caught my eye.  Unlike the nicoise salads I've enjoyed at Harry's Bar and at Park Chow, this one was served with "canned tuna."  At first glance, I didn't think the canned tuna would have a chance against a seared ahi tuna.  Well, simply speaking, I was wrong.  The salad, which was huge, came with all the typical nicoise fixings, including olives, potatoes, hard-boiled eggs, and peppers.  The crowning glory was a healthy helping of a flavorful tuna salad which was far from boring.  Well done!  Any hope of taking some of it home for leftovers was shattered when I realized I had devoured every last bit.

Bottom line, the staff was very pleasant, the service timely, and the food  high quality.  We hope to visit BSB again very soon.

excerpts: I love this place.
Oh man the food was good.
I had this steak with fois gras on top of it.
I might have cried.
We also had this raw salmon appetizer.
Out of sight.
I thought the prices were reasonable.
Our waiter was all French and nice.
I thought it was a great experience.
.author: Michelle K.
.review: I love this place.  Oh man the food was good.  I had this steak with fois gras on top of it.  I might have cried.  We also had this raw salmon appetizer.  Out of sight.  I thought the prices were reasonable.  Our waiter was all French and nice.  I thought it was a great experience.

excerpts: This is one of my absolute favorites!
I've been here many times and am always impressed with the wonderful French food at reasonable prices.
Bonus:

The last time we were meeting friends here for dinner(two weeks ago or so), we'd made reservations, but when we arrived our table wasn't quite ready, so they offered us complimentary kir royales out on the patio while we waited.
We split salads (the goat cheese was delish), and I had the duck confit, which was absolutely fabulous!
My husband chose the mussels and left not a speck.
I'm afraid we stayed a bit late.
.author: Julia R.
.review:
This is one of my absolute favorites!  I've been here many times and am always impressed with the wonderful French food at reasonable prices. Bonus: the waitstaff and owners speak French, so you feel as though you're on a mini-vacation and may actually have left the country for a brief interlude!  

The last time we were meeting friends here for dinner(two weeks ago or so), we'd made reservations, but when we arrived our table wasn't quite ready, so they offered us complimentary kir royales out on the patio while we waited.  As it was a bit brisk that evening, they turned the overhead heaters on just for us--very nice.

We split salads (the goat cheese was delish), and I had the duck confit, which was absolutely fabulous!  My husband chose the mussels and left not a speck.  The recommended wines perfectly complemented our dinners, but sadly we had no room for dessert.

Conversation was lively over coffee and we hadn't seen our friends in ages.... I'm afraid we stayed a bit late.  Kudos to the staff who were quite gracious as we were the penultimate party to leave the premises that night.

We love, love, love this place! :-)

excerpts: Best mussels in the city - the broth is to die for.
Great service and cute ambiance - feels like you're in France.
.author: Jen N.
.review: Best mussels in the city - the broth is to die for.  Great service and cute ambiance - feels like you're in France.

excerpts: A great place for Sunday brunch on a sun-kissed day.
Heated by the late morning sun, water and mimosas kept me refreshed.
I was one of a few heathens sporting athletic wear, but didn't feel too out of place.
Once the food arrived, I quickly devoured my spinach omelet, side salad and potatoes.
Simple and basic, the food was naturally delicious.
And yet, by the end of the meal I was left with a disappointed reaction to my three halves of white potatoes.
.author: Andrew D.
.review:
A great place for Sunday brunch on a sun-kissed day.  Heated by the late morning sun, water and mimosas kept me refreshed.  The waiter visited infrequently, but brought a congenial presence.  

The food was slowed by a number of large Easter parties donning their Sunday Best. I was one of a few heathens sporting athletic wear, but didn't feel too out of place.  Once the food arrived, I quickly devoured my spinach omelet, side salad and potatoes. Simple and basic, the food was naturally delicious.  And yet, by the end of the meal I was left with a disappointed reaction to my three halves of white potatoes.

excerpts: I live a block and a half from here and every time I go and get Danel as a server-
he is consistently rude.
Liverpool Lil's around the corner has much better service.
.author: Lisa W.
.review: The food is pretty good (3-4 stars) but the service and treatment from owner/chef Danel is One Star or less.    I live a block and a half from here and every time I go and get Danel as a server-  he is consistently rude.    Liverpool Lil's around the corner has much better service.

excerpts: Great french onion soup.
Steak plate was huge and tasty.
Prix fix us always a deal.
Charming atmosphere in a nice neighborhood.
Great staff.
An older crowd.
Nice place to take mom or your auntie.
.author: J S.
.review: Great french onion soup.  Steak plate was huge and tasty.  Prix fix us always a deal.  Charming atmosphere in a nice neighborhood.  Great staff.   An older crowd.  Nice place to take mom or your auntie.

excerpts: After a visit to Paris, I'm upgrading this restaurant to full 5 stars.
Thanks to Sofi O., I was able to discover this wonderful restaurant.
Many say it's a cute neighborhood restaurant, but it's actually more than that.
I say they have the best food out of  other similar-type French restaurants -- namely Fringale, Chapeau, Cassis, South Park Bistro,
The only reason for one less star is bugging flies.
There were one or two flying throughout our meal, and I found a fruit fly in my Sauterne (a dessert wine).
I will have to go back here again and check for flies next time in order to give full 5 stars.
.author: Mami T.
.review:
***UPDATED***
After a visit to Paris, I'm upgrading this restaurant to full 5 stars.  I was very much disappointed by ALL of street bistros/cafes over there.

Food at Baker Street Bistro, in SF USA, is by far better.   At every plain dish served in real France, I couldn't help imaging back this restaurant in the rim of Marina district.

And changed my mind about the fruit fly.    After all, fruit flies make me nostalgic of the good old high school experiment...


***ORIGINAL REVIEW 8/19/07***
Thanks to Sofi O., I was able to discover this wonderful restaurant.  Many say it's a cute neighborhood restaurant, but it's actually more than that.  Went here for dinner, and food was very good.

I say they have the best food out of  other similar-type French restaurants -- namely Fringale, Chapeau, Cassis, South Park Bistro, etc. -- that are noted for cozy Parisian feel, quality food, and reasonable prices.

The only reason for one less star is bugging flies.  There were one or two flying throughout our meal, and I found a fruit fly in my Sauterne (a dessert wine).  I will have to go back here again and check for flies next time in order to give full 5 stars.

excerpts: Honey took me here on our first date, so I have very fond memories of this bistro.
Unfortunately, it wasn't because of the food.
Kinda last minute, so my fave places were booked.
Small and charming.
Right in the middle of a neighborhood.
Foodwise, it was average.
We had the french onion soup, hangar steak, and an encrusted white fish.
Washed it down with a bottle of pinot noir.
It's probably only worth it if you have their prix fixe:  soup, salad, entree, and dessert for around $17.00.
If you're in the area before 7p or during brunch time, I'd say give it a try.
Not worth a dinner reservation and the a la carte prices.
.author: Jennifer H.
.review:
Honey took me here on our first date, so I have very fond memories of this bistro.  Unfortunately, it wasn't because of the food.  Kinda last minute, so my fave places were booked.  Ended up at Baker after reading the yelp reviews.

Small and charming.  Right in the middle of a neighborhood.  Foodwise, it was average.  We had the french onion soup, hangar steak, and an encrusted white fish.  Washed it down with a bottle of pinot noir.  I never saw the bill, but the prices on the a la carte menu weren't on par with the quality of food.

It's probably only worth it if you have their prix fixe:  soup, salad, entree, and dessert for around $17.00.  If you're in the area before 7p or during brunch time, I'd say give it a try.  Not worth a dinner reservation and the a la carte prices.

excerpts: Have you been to bistros in Paris?
If yes, then you know that they are mostly casual, family owned and the food is usually good.
Baker Street Bistro has all the ambiance of a Parisian bistro ..
Good food?
My husband and I enjoyed the chicken in mushroom sauce and the duck breast.
The chocolate cake was great.
This is not a 5 star restaurant that will cost you $100 a person.
.author: Rose J.
.review:
Have you been to bistros in Paris?  If yes, then you know that they are mostly casual, family owned and the food is usually good.  Baker Street Bistro has all the ambiance of a Parisian bistro ..  You are sitting very close to others and depending on what time you are there, it can be romantic, or fun and noisy with a party atmosphere.

Good food?  My husband and I enjoyed the chicken in mushroom sauce and the duck breast.  The chocolate cake was great.  This is not a 5 star restaurant that will cost you $100 a person.  It's a great little bistro that takes you to Paris and that's why we enjoy it!

Bon appetite!

excerpts: Minus a star off the bat due to the eye rolling that I got from the French waitress.
I. kid.
you.
not.
It was a friend's b-day, we order some apps  the assorted pate plate w/ crostini, ordered a nice bottle of Pinot Grigio and start to enjoy the evening.
We got to ordering the entree.
Now though I am a big fan of the meat and love to eat it, very very rarely do I order steak.
I don't really know the cuts of meats etc...
I can be a simple girl at times.
I order "steak" when I'm with the folks
and they want the fine dining of Black Angus, I don't do steak at some fancy sassy Bistro.

So this is how it goes:

Me:

the New York Steak"
Waitress:
"Medium rare.
yes?
Me: "Hmm...medium
, I'm not a big fan of bloody meat.
Maybe...

"
Waitress: She just looks at me like I'm crazy, "how dare she ask for it medium!
Me:
I guess, still not a fan of the bloody meat.
I'll try it.
Medium rare, then.
Thanks.
Okay, so the waitress does one of these Euro type hmmmphs, tilts her head to the right, and ROLLS HER EYES!!!
I know in her head, she is thinking, "Theeese steww-pid Ah-merhi-CAN with their gauche ways!!
I can't beleeeve
she wants it medium.
Sacre bleu!!!
Anyway, it set me off and was unnecessary and rude.
This just further adds to my stereotypes of French people.
, I'm not a hypocrite, it was good, it wasn't too bloody, and it was a nice cut of meat.
However, I could have done without the eye rolling.
The shallot tarragon butter?
It tasted like regular butter.
But who knows, I may not be that discerning in taste since I didn't know New York steak is best served medium rare.
.author: Jenn A.
.review:
Minus a star off the bat due to the eye rolling that I got from the French waitress.  I. kid. you. not.  I was ready to slice and dice with my recently used butter knife.

It was a friend's b-day, we order some apps  the assorted pate plate w/ crostini, ordered a nice bottle of Pinot Grigio and start to enjoy the evening.  We got to ordering the entree.  Now though I am a big fan of the meat and love to eat it, very very rarely do I order steak.  I don't really know the cuts of meats etc...I can be a simple girl at times.  I order "steak" when I'm with the folks and they want the fine dining of Black Angus, I don't do steak at some fancy sassy Bistro.  I digress.

So this is how it goes:

Me:  "I'll have the New York Steak"
Waitress:  "Medium rare. yes?"
Me: "Hmm...medium, I'm not a big fan of bloody meat.  Maybe..."
Waitress: She just looks at me like I'm crazy, "how dare she ask for it medium!"

Pause...

My sister interrupts, "New York steak is best served medium rare, otherwise it ruins the cut of the steak. You don't want it overcooked."

Me:  "I guess, still not a fan of the bloody meat.  I'll try it.   Medium rare, then.  Thanks."

Okay, so the waitress does one of these Euro type hmmmphs, tilts her head to the right, and ROLLS HER EYES!!!  I know in her head, she is thinking, "Theeese steww-pid Ah-merhi-CAN with their gauche ways!! I can't beleeeve she wants it medium.  Sacre bleu!!!"

Anyway, it set me off and was unnecessary and rude.  This just further adds to my stereotypes of French people.  However karma is a bitch, she broke two glasses throughout the evening.

So I got my steak, I'm not a hypocrite, it was good, it wasn't too bloody, and it was a nice cut of meat.  However, I could have done without the eye rolling.  The shallot tarragon butter?  It tasted like regular butter.  But who knows, I may not be that discerning in taste since I didn't know New York steak is best served medium rare.  Whatevah! 

I'd love to try the prix fixe since it's damn cheap, but I found the service somewhat undesirable.

excerpts: I've been here three times now---although previous visits were quite a few years back.
This is a nice little neighborhood place, and being in a neighborhood, even though it's just off the bend where Lombard (the boulevard) becomes Richardson, there isn't a lot of parking---
I'd cab it, if you can find one of those, these days.
The menu is fairly diverse and from my standpoint a delight in that there was NO pizza, NO burgers, NO mac-n-cheese, and NO hangar steak (for the burger/pizza/mac-n-cheese crowd who are evolving).
Whoopee!
The by-the-bottle wine list was decent, with the most expensive bottle at $65.00.
Where Baker Street falls short is in value.
With entrees (main courses) right around $30.00 it's up there with the City's best establishments (or, perversely, right down there with the tourist joints in the Wharf)
yet I didn't think the food was at the same level as the price.
I started with oysters (if the oysters aren't bad, they're bound to be good, and the sauce was spot on), and then had the Foie Gras, just because it's going to be illegal---
I don't see what the attraction is
, it's liver that tastes like very mild liver, but now that it's illegal I'll have to have more of it to fight the Nanny State.
The partner had the warm chevre salad, which he also liked, although I thought it was better at Chez Papa.
For our main course I had
the Boeuf Bourgignon and the Partner had the halibut, which he pronounced delightful.
My boeuf bourgignon was decent;  the beef was flavorful and soft, although the sauce seemed a bit thin and there were no mushrooms, but recipes vary by region and I'm no expert on French cooking.
Still, when my own recipe (Julia Child) tastes better than an expensive restaurant dish, I'm never a happy camper.
We finished with dessert---a Tarte Tatin with pears, and strawberries with black pepper and basalmic, with vanilla ice cream.
The vanilla ice cream was very good, but next time I'd request it on the side of not at all, as the berry/basalmic/pepper combination was a bit overwhelmed by by the ice cream.
The flavors are very subtle and I think that without the ice cream this dessert would have stolen the night's show.
Because another poster brought it up, I'll mention that we were asked if we'd like to move to the window table as it became available (next to us), just as we finished our first glasses of wine.

I had been dying to ask to do so, but since we'd already dusted our table cloth with crumbs I thought, with only one waiter on duty,  it would be rude, so I was most thankful as I don't like having people close by on both sides (what can I say).
Over all, the disconnect between the expense and the level of the food puts this review at two stars.
If the plates had been $20.00, I might have been more enthusiastic.
One can hope the prices are justified by decent wages and perhaps benefits, but still, for that price I expect to be wowed
and Wow! was not a word either of us uttered, all night long.
.author: Paul T.
.review:
I've been here three times now---although previous visits were quite a few years back.  This is a nice little neighborhood place, and being in a neighborhood, even though it's just off the bend where Lombard (the boulevard) becomes Richardson, there isn't a lot of parking---I'd cab it, if you can find one of those, these days.  Baker Street Bistro seems to be very popular among the ladies of a certain age, as for most of our time there the place was divided nearly by half between thirty somethings and posh older women.

The menu is fairly diverse and from my standpoint a delight in that there was NO pizza, NO burgers, NO mac-n-cheese, and NO hangar steak (for the burger/pizza/mac-n-cheese crowd who are evolving).  Whoopee!  The by-the-bottle wine list was decent, with the most expensive bottle at $65.00.  We very much enjoyed our selection, and it was a great improvement over they by-the-glass reds available, and the sparkling wine.

Where Baker Street falls short is in value.  With entrees (main courses) right around $30.00 it's up there with the City's best establishments (or, perversely, right down there with the tourist joints in the Wharf) yet I didn't think the food was at the same level as the price.  I started with oysters (if the oysters aren't bad, they're bound to be good, and the sauce was spot on), and then had the Foie Gras, just because it's going to be illegal---I don't see what the attraction is, it's liver that tastes like very mild liver, but now that it's illegal I'll have to have more of it to fight the Nanny State.  The partner had the warm chevre salad, which he also liked, although I thought it was better at Chez Papa.  For our main course I had the Boeuf Bourgignon and the Partner had the halibut, which he pronounced delightful.  My boeuf bourgignon was decent;  the beef was flavorful and soft, although the sauce seemed a bit thin and there were no mushrooms, but recipes vary by region and I'm no expert on French cooking.  Still, when my own recipe (Julia Child) tastes better than an expensive restaurant dish, I'm never a happy camper.  I want to aspire to restaurant quality, but I want the restaurants to wow me.

We finished with dessert---a Tarte Tatin with pears, and strawberries with black pepper and basalmic, with vanilla ice cream.  The vanilla ice cream was very good, but next time I'd request it on the side of not at all, as the berry/basalmic/pepper combination was a bit overwhelmed by by the ice cream.  The flavors are very subtle and I think that without the ice cream this dessert would have stolen the night's show.  I want to try it at home.

Because another poster brought it up, I'll mention that we were asked if we'd like to move to the window table as it became available (next to us), just as we finished our first glasses of wine.  I had been dying to ask to do so, but since we'd already dusted our table cloth with crumbs I thought, with only one waiter on duty,  it would be rude, so I was most thankful as I don't like having people close by on both sides (what can I say).  We were only asked, it was not a request, and I was thrilled.

Over all, the disconnect between the expense and the level of the food puts this review at two stars.  If the plates had been $20.00, I might have been more enthusiastic.  One can hope the prices are justified by decent wages and perhaps benefits, but still, for that price I expect to be wowed and Wow! was not a word either of us uttered, all night long.

excerpts: I was tempted to give this place a 5, but I might need to come back here again for that.
When I arrived, it was far enough away from the rest of the Marina that I didn't have any trouble finding parking (that or
it was just a quiet weekend).
I just barely missed the pre-mix dinner cut off time (7pm on Fridays) which looked like an amazing deal!
It's okay though.
I ended up ordering a seafood stew (something I can't pronounce and definitely can't spell) with risotto on the side.
The stew was delicious!
Tons of flavor and
it was big
so it was enough just almost fill me up.
Towards the bottom of the bowl the flavor was starting to become a little much which sounds kind of weird
but I don't really know how else to describe it).
I personally thought the risotto was a little bland, but it was a side
.author: Tom Y.
.review:
I was tempted to give this place a 5, but I might need to come back here again for that.  When I arrived, it was far enough away from the rest of the Marina that I didn't have any trouble finding parking (that or it was just a quiet weekend).  Walked in and realized its a really small, cute little place that really has an intimate feel to it.

I just barely missed the pre-mix dinner cut off time (7pm on Fridays) which looked like an amazing deal!  It's okay though.  I ended up ordering a seafood stew (something I can't pronounce and definitely can't spell) with risotto on the side.  The stew was delicious!  Tons of flavor and it was big so it was enough just almost fill me up.  Towards the bottom of the bowl the flavor was starting to become a little much which sounds kind of weird but I don't really know how else to describe it).  I personally thought the risotto was a little bland, but it was a side so I didn't expect that much from it.

This place is very affordable for a very good meal and I will have to come back and try something else!

excerpts: We enjoyed the food.
The goat cheese salad was refreshing and tasty.
My Duck L'Orange was delicious.
My wife's steak tartare was good, but had a slightly catsup-like taste.
Food presentation was good.
We'd go back.
.author: Haig A.
.review: We enjoyed the food.  The goat cheese salad was refreshing and tasty.  My Duck L'Orange was delicious.  My wife's steak tartare was good, but had a slightly catsup-like taste.  Food presentation was good.  We'd go back.

excerpts:
One block from my apartment
Sancerre by the bottle
Croque-monsieur  is the best in SF--ask for it golden brown!
.author: Trish t.
.review:
OMG...

One block from my apartment
Sancerre by the bottle
Croque-monsieur  is the best in SF--ask for it golden brown!
French toast to-die-for!!

VOILA!!!!!!

excerpts: A rather disappointing experiencing at an anticipated dining outing
.author: shaun l.
.review:
A rather disappointing experiencing at an anticipated dining outing  The welcome that our group received was as cold as the steaks that they served that night.  

Definitely not a destination restaurant, but I can see this place being a nice neighborhood joint.

Small glasses if you order by the glass... better to get bottles (..as always), desserts were quite good.

excerpts: I love this place.
Great prices and delicious food!!!
The pate and escargot are to die for.
.author: Ammala B.
.review: I love this place.  Great prices and delicious food!!!  The pate and escargot are to die for.

excerpts: I came here on a quest for Sunday brunch with a girlfriend of mine and was surprised at how many tables were available -- we were quickly seated next to the bar and had easy access to take in the sights.
We ordered the Frittata and the Eggs Florentine -- everything was super very tasty and fresh.
.author: Katie C.
.review:
What a cute brunch spot, nestled right in between the busy streets of the Marina and the quiet and demure neighborhood of the Presidio.

I came here on a quest for Sunday brunch with a girlfriend of mine and was surprised at how many tables were available -- we were quickly seated next to the bar and had easy access to take in the sights.  I simply adored all the framed photography on the walls!

We ordered the Frittata and the Eggs Florentine -- everything was super very tasty and fresh.  The lacking part of my experience here was the service which was a tad on the flighty side, but whatever.

Would definitely come back!

excerpts: 1 star -  Attentive service.
.author: Felicia H.
.review:
1 star - Super duper cute seating and atmosphere. Genuinely felt like a street cafe in Paris. And oh-so-unpretentious! It's a perfect place for lunch/brunch on a beautiful SF day. 

1 star -  Attentive service. Gotta love the cute accents and eavesdropping on the waitstaff as they banter in French - and by eavesdrop, I mean occasionally catching an English word thrown in the furry of French.

2 stars - Delightful food! Croque Monsieur were mmm-mmm G-double O-D good! Each bite left me wanting more. 

I am absolutely looking forward to returning here for dinner! I wish my neighborhood had a gem like this one!

excerpts: Cute brunch spot- try to get a table outside on a nice, sunny day.
For me, my experience here was more about the ambiance rather than the food.
My girlfriend and I shared 2 entrees:
we had the french toast and a mushroom omelette.
The french toast was comforting, savory, sweet, and very filling.
It's served with a delicious cream/fruit sauce and fruit.
Hello sweet tooth!
The omelette was served with a salad and (some) potatoes.
they were good about refilling my water glass, and I didn't feel rushed during my meal.
Good for people watching.
.author: Sarah F.
.review:
Cute brunch spot- try to get a table outside on a nice, sunny day.  For me, my experience here was more about the ambiance rather than the food.  My girlfriend and I shared 2 entrees:  we had the french toast and a mushroom omelette.  The french toast was comforting, savory, sweet, and very filling.  It's served with a delicious cream/fruit sauce and fruit.  Hello sweet tooth!  The omelette was served with a salad and (some) potatoes.  I felt the omelette was a bit too buttery, but hey, it's a French spot.  

Service was pretty good- they were good about refilling my water glass, and I didn't feel rushed during my meal.  Good for people watching.

excerpts: I adore this place.
If that isn't explanation enough...this was
Very local, right on the edge of the Presidio on one side and Marina on the other.
The waiters are actually french (at least some of them), so don't expect hand holding waiters.
The tables are quite close together as the restaurant is relatively small.
I love sitting by the window.
I usually get the rabbit.
It's a heavy meal.
Rich and creamy sauce, delicious rabbit...almost thick soup like.
I also really like the veal dishes.
I've never had a meal cooked badly.
Although sometimes the wait staff can be slow.
Since this is a french restaurant where you are expected to eat slowly and savor your food.
They usually have specials for the new Beaujolais season.
Those are some great meals and good wines.
.author: Emily G.
.review:
I adore this place.  If that isn't explanation enough...this was "our" place and even a very bad breakup can't ruin my love and admiration of the food and ambiance.   

Very local, right on the edge of the Presidio on one side and Marina on the other.  The waiters are actually french (at least some of them), so don't expect hand holding waiters.   The tables are quite close together as the restaurant is relatively small.  I love sitting by the window.   I would go for a nice intimate or romantic dinner where you don't want to spend an arm and a leg.  

I usually get the rabbit.  It's a heavy meal.  Rich and creamy sauce, delicious rabbit...almost thick soup like.   I also really like the veal dishes.  I've never had a meal cooked badly.  Although sometimes the wait staff can be slow.  Since this is a french restaurant where you are expected to eat slowly and savor your food.  They usually have specials for the new Beaujolais season.  Those are some great meals and good wines.

excerpts: Excellent ~ everything was Excellent.
The service was what you dream of - and the food ~ well, I will be back again and again for the mussels and next time we're coming with a group so we can try more.
The portions are so generous that there was no room for dessert - but we drooled as they went by us to other tables.
.author: Kim A.
.review: Excellent ~ everything was Excellent.  The service was what you dream of - and the food ~ well, I will be back again and again for the mussels and next time we're coming with a group so we can try more. The portions are so generous that there was no room for dessert - but we drooled as they went by us to other tables.

excerpts: So delicious, we thought we were back in Paris.
The salmon was perfectly cooked with amazing crispy skin, placed on a gorgeous bed of spinach and a puree of carrots with ginger which was unbelievable.
So well done.
What a wonderful dinner.
For light desserts, the Iles Flottante  is amazing and the balsamic berries are a wonderful treat.
.author: w. r.
.review: So delicious, we thought we were back in Paris.  The salmon was perfectly cooked with amazing crispy skin, placed on a gorgeous bed of spinach and a puree of carrots with ginger which was unbelievable.  So well done.  What a wonderful dinner.  For light desserts, the Iles Flottante  is amazing and the balsamic berries are a wonderful treat.

excerpts: This used to be my favorite restaurant in SF, but the last few visits have been pretty mediocre.
.author: S J.
.review:
This used to be my favorite restaurant in SF, but the last few visits have been pretty mediocre.  I love the manager (owner?), but service is, well, very French.

Note that I've only been for dinner and never for brunch, which people seem to love.

Anyway, go for the prix fixe menu if you're in the neighborhood, but it's not really a destination for me anytime after 7p...

excerpts: The wait staff was very friendly and it's on a great street to watch people walk by.
It's a little bit away from the hustle and bustle
so it provides a nice atmosphere.
.author: Glenn M.
.review:
Ok I think I can honestly say this was the best meal I had in SF. Each breakfast/brunch I would have French Toast and potatoes at every restaurant. They all said they were famous for it and here the french toast was by far the best! Each thick slice of bread was very moist and full of flavor. The orange cinnamon syrup was a perfect combination with the fruit, french toast and fruity french whipped cream it came with. The potaoes were seasoned with just the right amount of herbs and cooked perfectly. The croque monsieur was apparently to die for as well. My partner practically licked his plate clean.

The wait staff was very friendly and it's on a great street to watch people walk by.  It's a little bit away from the hustle and bustle so it provides a nice atmosphere. A++++!

excerpts: Great neighborhood bistro.
Loved the French toast and the benedict for brunch.
The mussels were good too.
.author: J B.
.review:
Great neighborhood bistro.  Outside tables are fantastic in the morning (the place is on the west side of the street, so the front tables get the sun in the morning).

Loved the French toast and the benedict for brunch.  The mussels were good too.

excerpts:
By far, the best Eggs Benedict I have eaten in San Francisco!
Brunch is outstanding.
I recommend  ordering individual plates and the French Toast to split with the table.
This is the best way to go to maximize the brunch experience at Baker Street Bistro.
The service is fantastic, as well.
I love this place.
.author: O G.
.review:
By far, the best Eggs Benedict I have eaten in San Francisco!
Brunch is outstanding.  I recommend  ordering individual plates and the French Toast to split with the table.  This is the best way to go to maximize the brunch experience at Baker Street Bistro.
The service is fantastic, as well.  I love this place.

excerpts: Delightful atmosphere:  bustling, crowded, lively bistro, with attentive, welcoming, knowledgeable wait staff.
The place is jumpin'; go to experience the most authentic French bistro in The City.
Do NOT go for a quiet dinner; you will likely be disappointed.
DO GO for great food at a great price.
Request to sit on the banquette if you want comfort and "a view."
Limited outdoor seating is available for the very special days / evenings.
Having lived in the South of France, I am a fan of confit de canard; it is expertly prepared  and has an absolute minimum of fat remaining on the leg and thigh.
The mâche salade is superbe!
My recommendation, quite simply:  GO if you are looking for affordable, "unstuffy" French fare!
Bon appétit!
.author: Jean Yves E.
.review: Delightful atmosphere:  bustling, crowded, lively bistro, with attentive, welcoming, knowledgeable wait staff.  The place is jumpin'; go to experience the most authentic French bistro in The City.  Do NOT go for a quiet dinner; you will likely be disappointed.  DO GO for great food at a great price.  Request to sit on the banquette if you want comfort and "a view."  Limited outdoor seating is available for the very special days / evenings.  Having lived in the South of France, I am a fan of confit de canard; it is expertly prepared  and has an absolute minimum of fat remaining on the leg and thigh.  The mâche salade is superbe!  My recommendation, quite simply:  GO if you are looking for affordable, "unstuffy" French fare!  Bon appétit!

excerpts: Screw it, you get all five.
I've been here a few times when it opened, but I was kinda too young to care.
Dinner with the 'rents is dinner with the 'rents.
But point is it didn't offend me at 14.
I went here a month ago and it was the shit.
All the food was effortlessly good, the service was fine, the place is cute and nice and pretty and such.
I didn't read the other reviews yet
What I'm here to tell you is that my brother and I were talking about a band, and my mom asked us what kind of music it was.
Sorta like The Clash," I told her.
I don't know them," she said.
Yeah you do, y'know, 'shawee don like it....
rock the casbah, rock the casbah.'
"  (shakes head)
Y'know, 'Should I stay or should I go.'
Right then, old french dude walking by (owner?  maitre d'?
) remarks "aw yees, Ze Clash.
I sow zem in 82, at zee orpheum tseatre.
.author: Nick P.
.review:
Screw it, you get all five.  I've been here a few times when it opened, but I was kinda too young to care.  Dinner with the 'rents is dinner with the 'rents.  But point is it didn't offend me at 14.  I went here a month ago and it was the shit.  All the food was effortlessly good, the service was fine, the place is cute and nice and pretty and such.  I didn't read the other reviews yet but I'm sure they'll tell you all about it.

What I'm here to tell you is that my brother and I were talking about a band, and my mom asked us what kind of music it was.  "Sorta like The Clash," I told her.  "I don't know them," she said.  "Yeah you do, y'know, 'shawee don like it....rock the casbah, rock the casbah.'"  (shakes head)  "Y'know, 'Should I stay or should I go.'"  "Oh THAT I know," sez mommy.

Right then, old french dude walking by (owner?  maitre d'?) remarks "aw yees, Ze Clash.  I sow zem in 82, at zee orpheum tseatre."

One of those moments that just kinda makes a night.

excerpts: Went here for brunch last Sunday.
.author: Kelly R.
.review:
Went here for brunch last Sunday.  It was busy, but we were promptly seated by the window and given a basket of French bread to start. 

It was difficult deciding because several dishes looked good--lots of bistro classics and favorites. I ordered the eggs Benedict with salmon, and the boy ordered the eggs Florentine, which came with a giant butterflied sausage, potatoes and salad.  

Food was simple, but delicious. We used the rest of our bread to sop up anything that dared to remain on the plate. Price-wise, I think this place is incredibly reasonable, especially for dinner, which is next on my list.

excerpts: , i think what would've made it incredible is if they used real Jambon ham instead of  what looked like pre-sliced ham.
The FT my wife had (also made with the Pan de Mie) was incredibly tender and tasty, served with fresh fruit, creme fraiche and cinnamon syrup.
The service can be spotty if they get slammed.
.author: Brian J.
.review:
If you had to get one brunch item here it would have to be the French Toast. As my wifey and me were waiting for our table we must've seen a dozen French Toasts come out. When we sat down and finally ordered, I Iet my wife get the FT and I got the Croque Monsieur which was one of the best CMs that I've ever had in the city, the Pain de Mie was nice and crispy on the bottom and the cheese was melted just right, i think what would've made it incredible is if they used real Jambon ham instead of  what looked like pre-sliced ham. The FT my wife had (also made with the Pan de Mie) was incredibly tender and tasty, served with fresh fruit, creme fraiche and cinnamon syrup.
The service can be spotty if they get slammed.

excerpts:
I had dinner with 2 friends there last night, and though this isn't a fancy place, it rated 4+ stars for the following reasons:
-  though we were very early for our table, we were seated right away
-  service was very attentive
-  the prix fixe meal was a terrific value at less than $20 (fabulous asparagus puree soup, perfectly dressed side salad, flavorful and moist roasted chicken leg with wild mushrooms, perfectly done chocolate mousse with whipped cream and a raspberry)
-  reasonably price wine by the glass
-
I have been here at least a dozen times previously (always for dinner, sometimes getting the prix fixe option), and they are very consistent.

The meals are beautifully (but not extravagantly) presented, the portions are healthy but not ridiculous, the flavors are always complex but not overdone, and the service is European (your plates won't be cleared right away and your water glass may not be topped off often, but on the other hand you won't be rushed to "turn" the table).
They now have a handful of outside tables as well, which are made comfortable on breezy nights with the help of overhead heaters).
This is a great place to have an authentic French bistro experience without overheated prices.
.author: Lana C.
.review:

The meals are beautifully (but not extravagantly) presented, the portions are healthy but not ridiculous, the flavors are always complex but not overdone, and the service is European (your plates won't be cleared right away and your water glass may not be topped off often, but on the other hand you won't be rushed to "turn" the table).  They now have a handful of outside tables as well, which are made comfortable on breezy nights with the help of overhead heaters).
