.review: The best eggs benny in town.  Served on a sunny sidewalk with rosemary potatoes and a mixed green salad.  Seriously, the best.

excerpts: The prix fixe for $16.50 is definitely the way to go here, what a great deal!
The food is good - nothing mindblowing, but you get a bowl of soup, a small salad, entree and dessert.
The service is wonderful and the owner comes around to make sure you are enjoying yourself.
The crowd tends to be an older Pac Heights crew and eavesdropping is always interesting (don't mean to, but the tables are smooshed together).
Be sure to make reservations!
.author: Lisa C.
.review: The prix fixe for $16.50 is definitely the way to go here, what a great deal!  The food is good - nothing mindblowing, but you get a bowl of soup, a small salad, entree and dessert.  The service is wonderful and the owner comes around to make sure you are enjoying yourself.  The crowd tends to be an older Pac Heights crew and eavesdropping is always interesting (don't mean to, but the tables are smooshed together).  Be sure to make reservations!

excerpts: For some, Baker Street Bistro may have a certain charm.

My first dinner there  was off the menu and so unremarkable that I 
can't remember what I had.
On my last visit, I chose the prix fix dinner.
At $16 it  was a "bargain" but the food lacked  personality or appeal.
The  chicken and potato were smothered in a tomato-based sauce and had almsot no taste; the  white pepper available at the table didn't help boast the flavor.
The cheese coating on the lobster bisque was stringy,  making it  awkward to eat.
The finale was a small  white colored  gelatin- based dessert, with a faint coconut flavor.
My companion had the  steak ($24)  and said "It was ok, nothing great.
Another  disappointment was the 5 oz. serving of  unexceptional wine for  $7.50.
The cheesey American music from the 80's playing  in the background became vaguely annoying; it was certainly incongruous.
On the positive side; the service was pleasant; the waitor served us  promptly.
My chicken dish arrived luke-warm and the waitor took it back without a problem to have it reheated.
The french bread was fresh.
.author: susan m.
.review:
For some, Baker Street Bistro may have a certain charm.  It's small and reminiscent of corner cafes in Paris neighborhoods. 

But in the end it's the food that counts and I've been disppointed twice now. My first dinner there  was off the menu and so unremarkable that I 
can't remember what I had.  

On my last visit, I chose the prix fix dinner.  At $16 it  was a "bargain" but the food lacked  personality or appeal.  The  chicken and potato were smothered in a tomato-based sauce and had almsot no taste; the  white pepper available at the table didn't help boast the flavor.  
The cheese coating on the lobster bisque was stringy,  making it  awkward to eat.  The finale was a small  white colored  gelatin- based dessert, with a faint coconut flavor.

My companion had the  steak ($24)  and said "It was ok, nothing great."

Another  disappointment was the 5 oz. serving of  unexceptional wine for  $7.50.  

The cheesey American music from the 80's playing  in the background became vaguely annoying; it was certainly incongruous.  

On the positive side; the service was pleasant; the waitor served us  promptly.  My chicken dish arrived luke-warm and the waitor took it back without a problem to have it reheated.  The french bread was fresh.

excerpts: This classic San Francisco icon keeps on giving.
I have been there for lunch several times and I am impressed to see that the quality of the food and service easily surpasses what it used to be under the previous owner.
Prices are very reasonable, the ambience is cozy and friendly and the chef/owner manages to turn out delicious, classic French dishes without the traditional use of heavy sauces.
A keeper.
.author: Fabrice H.
.review: This classic San Francisco icon keeps on giving.  I have been there for lunch several times and I am impressed to see that the quality of the food and service easily surpasses what it used to be under the previous owner.  Prices are very reasonable, the ambience is cozy and friendly and the chef/owner manages to turn out delicious, classic French dishes without the traditional use of heavy sauces.  A keeper.

excerpts: Baker Street Bistro is an authentic French cafe and is one of my two favorite restaurants in all of San Francisco.
(the other being A16 which is much pricier!)
The food is extraordinary, fresh and delicious with only the best local ingredients.
For those who said the service was sub-par I urge you to reconsider.
This is a true French cafe, by that
I mean that when you come here you should expect that your meal is an adventure in and of itself and that you should take your time enjoying the entire process of French dining.

I think too many of us, myself included, are so used to the rush and hectic pace of the Bay Area that we simply can't enjoy food and a slower pace the way the authentic French staff at Baker Street Bistro expect people to.
I love that I can even bring my dog if we sit outside under the heat lamps on a cool day.
Honestly, you won't get better food for the price here,  it's hard to get better food anywhere in my opinion.
.author: Julia S.
.review: Baker Street Bistro is an authentic French cafe and is one of my two favorite restaurants in all of San Francisco.  (the other being A16 which is much pricier!)  The food is extraordinary, fresh and delicious with only the best local ingredients.  For those who said the service was sub-par I urge you to reconsider.  This is a true French cafe, by that I mean that when you come here you should expect that your meal is an adventure in and of itself and that you should take your time enjoying the entire process of French dining.  I think too many of us, myself included, are so used to the rush and hectic pace of the Bay Area that we simply can't enjoy food and a slower pace the way the authentic French staff at Baker Street Bistro expect people to.  I love that I can even bring my dog if we sit outside under the heat lamps on a cool day.  Honestly, you won't get better food for the price here,  it's hard to get better food anywhere in my opinion.

excerpts: Great fish and salads.
A bit cramped, but with a $17 prix fixe you can't complain.
I almost forgot...
brunch is a hidden treasure here.
Usually no wait and good eggs benedict.
.author: Todd J.
.review: Intimate neigborhood bistro... All the French bistro fare one would expect. Great fish and salads.  A bit cramped, but with a $17 prix fixe you can't complain.  I almost forgot... brunch is a hidden treasure here. Usually no wait and good eggs benedict.

excerpts: You have to like the prix fixe menu.
You can get some great food in the little neighborhood for surprisingly good prices.
Interesting wine list, and the waitstaff gives great recommendations.
Parking is usually not too bad, so if you aren't having an entire bottle, feel free to drive over.
.author: Robert R.
.review: You have to like the prix fixe menu.  You can get some great food in the little neighborhood for surprisingly good prices.  Interesting wine list, and the waitstaff gives great recommendations.  Parking is usually not too bad, so if you aren't having an entire bottle, feel free to drive over.

excerpts: I've been here for lunch and dinner.
For dinner, I've ordered off their regular menu and ordered from their prix-fixe menu as well
and I have to say that everything I've tried has been really good.
Service can be a bit slow when they are busy but otherwise a great place to go for couples, or a friend or two.
This is not a kid place nor a big group kind of place.
Parking can be difficult at times.
.author: Stella C.
.review: I've been here for lunch and dinner.  For dinner, I've ordered off their regular menu and ordered from their prix-fixe menu as well and I have to say that everything I've tried has been really good.  Service can be a bit slow when they are busy but otherwise a great place to go for couples, or a friend or two.  This is not a kid place nor a big group kind of place.  Parking can be difficult at times.

excerpts: A great small french cafe.
One of the best breakfast's
i've found in the city so far.
Order the French Toast or if you like omlette's try the only one on the menu, ham and swiss cheese with mushrooms.
.author: Brian P.
.review: A great small french cafe.  One of the best breakfast's i've found in the city so far.  Order the French Toast or if you like omlette's try the only one on the menu, ham and swiss cheese with mushrooms.

excerpts: the duck confit so delicious and the potato leak soup was really good to.
definitely a great night out,  sit outside order their three course meal, and a carafe of wine.
.author: Joy Y.
.review:
awesome find in the Marina, their prix fix meal was amazing... the duck confit so delicious and the potato leak soup was really good to.  definitely a great night out,  sit outside order their three course meal, and a carafe of wine. Affordable and fun. 

but be prepared to enjoy a leisurely meal, our server seemed way stressed even on a Sunday night, I cut him some slack as they were pretty busy and he was the only one running the front of the house.

excerpts: Ambience: It's a 'hole in the wall' which is great, it was packed and lots of people talking/laughing and having a good time.
Atypical of most french restaurants.
Wine:
We had a glass of the house Syrah and Chardonney.
I had a "mixed greens salad" and that was exactly that.
A plate of mixed greens like you'd find in a bag at the supermarket lightly coated with olive oil.
While I like mixed greens, there was nothing else in the salad and for $7
Duck breast glazed, this was actually quite good, duck was very tender and flavorful.
Dessert:  Peach melba.
The peach had the taste as if it came out of a Del Monte
can with two raspberries and some cream.
For $12 they could use real peaches.
the apple tart was much better, but it really tasted like a slice of apple pie with creme fresh on top.
Not the best pie and many of the apple slices had the 'shells' that surround the seeds still on them.
because honestly, for the high price that we, or rather I, paid for this meal I didn't get much value out of it, nor was the food particularly amazing.
I've eaten in plenty of $50/person places and this wasn't close to delivering what I would expect for dinner.
I wanted it to work out, but there were quite a few let downs.
.author: S M.
.review:
I went there prior to seeing a concert at the Palace of fine arts, I took my gf who's has a better taste for french cuisine, so while I cannot comment on the "frenchness" of the dishes, I'll boil this down for the casual diner.

Ambience: It's a 'hole in the wall' which is great, it was packed and lots of people talking/laughing and having a good time.  Atypical of most french restaurants.  There were even families there with their kids, so as one who knows little about french cuisine, I actually liked it.

Bread was good, crunchy on the outiside chewy on the inside, however, they didn't bring us any bread plates so we had to use napkins.

Wine:  We had a glass of the house Syrah and Chardonney.  The odd thing was that if you ordered a bottle of wine, they brought you larger/thinner wine glasses, while if you ordered just a glass, they filled your the small wine glasses that were already on the table.

I had a "mixed greens salad" and that was exactly that.  A plate of mixed greens like you'd find in a bag at the supermarket lightly coated with olive oil.  While I like mixed greens, there was nothing else in the salad and for $7, it was no worth it.

Duck breast glazed, this was actually quite good, duck was very tender and flavorful.  While the duck confit appeared overdone and there were more lentils then duck.

Dessert:  Peach melba. The peach had the taste as if it came out of a Del Monte can with two raspberries and some cream.  For $12 they could use real peaches.  the apple tart was much better, but it really tasted like a slice of apple pie with creme fresh on top.  Not the best pie and many of the apple slices had the 'shells' that surround the seeds still on them.  Seems the cores were cut a bit to close.

I'm ranking this a 2 because honestly, for the high price that we, or rather I, paid for this meal I didn't get much value out of it, nor was the food particularly amazing.  I've eaten in plenty of $50/person places and this wasn't close to delivering what I would expect for dinner.  I wanted it to work out, but there were quite a few let downs.

excerpts: This place is tiny and hidden and really...really good.
The manager is nice, I went with a few of my friends and we were about...an hour late for our reservation (not my fault) so when we got there our reservation had obviously been given away
and we had to wait.
However the manager seated us in the outdoor area  while we waited for a table and we ordered appetizers and wine while we waited.
The service is great and so is the atmosphere.
I came here with my boyfriend once without reservations and we were seated right away.
I did feel a bit awkward as the crowd around us was definitively older and, well, caucasian but, still, love the food and love the service.
I'll keep coming back.
.author: Tiff L.
.review: This place is tiny and hidden and really...really good.  The manager is nice, I went with a few of my friends and we were about...an hour late for our reservation (not my fault) so when we got there our reservation had obviously been given away and we had to wait.  However the manager seated us in the outdoor area  while we waited for a table and we ordered appetizers and wine while we waited. The service is great and so is the atmosphere. I came here with my boyfriend once without reservations and we were seated right away. I did feel a bit awkward as the crowd around us was definitively older and, well, caucasian but, still, love the food and love the service. I'll keep coming back.

excerpts: This is a terrific neighborhood gem.
Try the mussels.
They are to die for.
.author: Emily M.
.review: This is a terrific neighborhood gem.  Try the mussels.  They are to die for.

excerpts: The waiter was awesome - took our order & had our food on the table in about 15 minutes flat.
Good food, good wine, really intimate neighborhood vibe.
.author: Marjorie M.
.review: Went here with friends when we were running late for a show at the Palace of Fine Arts. The waiter was awesome - took our order & had our food on the table in about 15 minutes flat.  Good food, good wine, really intimate neighborhood vibe.

excerpts: Yummy french food (but more Americanized sizes) and a decent wine selection.
A little Marina gem that shouldn't be overlooked.
There's also a fun dive-y bar across the street if you don't want the night to end after dinner
.author: Allison K.
.review: Yummy french food (but more Americanized sizes) and a decent wine selection.  A little Marina gem that shouldn't be overlooked.  There's also a fun dive-y bar across the street if you don't want the night to end after dinner :)

excerpts: It was my first time at this place, we had brunch on a Saturday morning.
I liked the French charm of the setting and the food was good.
I was a little surprised that there were so few people there
(maybe 3 tables in use), but it was a good experience.
I'll definitely go back.
.author: Chris P.
.review: It was my first time at this place, we had brunch on a Saturday morning.  I liked the French charm of the setting and the food was good.  I was a little surprised that there were so few people there (maybe 3 tables in use), but it was a good experience.  I'll definitely go back.

excerpts: A solid four stars.
This place has great french food.
The portions are the perfect size.
Very French.
I love the moules frites here.
I had a fish dish which had lavender in it.
What an interesting and refreshing combination.
The steak here is also good.
The wine list could be more extensive, but it is in keeping with France.
Most little bistros in France have fairly limited wine lists.
I want to come back here to give a more detailed review.
.author: apple r.
.review: A solid four stars.  This place has great french food.  The portions are the perfect size.  Very French.  I love the moules frites here.  I had a fish dish which had lavender in it.  What an interesting and refreshing combination.  The steak here is also good.  The wine list could be more extensive, but it is in keeping with France.  Most little bistros in France have fairly limited wine lists.  I want to come back here to give a more detailed review.

excerpts: it was actually a lot of soup, so by the time my duck entree arrived, I was pretty full.
The service was great and the food was excellent.
The duck was very tender but had crispiness on the skin.
I took some bites of steak and pomme frites from my companions, those were delicious as well.
Would go back again.
.author: Emiko M.
.review: Their french onion soup was really good....it was actually a lot of soup, so by the time my duck entree arrived, I was pretty full.  The service was great and the food was excellent.  The duck was very tender but had crispiness on the skin.  I took some bites of steak and pomme frites from my companions, those were delicious as well.  Would go back again.

excerpts: Great for brunch.
We stopped in after learning that Curbside was no longer.
I had the eggs florentine, which was perfect.
I enjoy the outside seating aspect of the place.
We'll have to come back for dinner.
.author: Amanda B.
.review: Great for brunch.  We stopped in after learning that Curbside was no longer.   I had the eggs florentine, which was perfect.   I enjoy the outside seating aspect of the place.  We'll have to come back for dinner.

excerpts: Stopped by on a Friday evening with no reservation and was seated promptly.
The place can be considered cozy or cramped depending on your mood.
The tables are close enough where you can hear others next to you speak but it doesn't really matter unless you're trying to listen haha.
The bistro is a small little place neatly tucked off Baker St. on the neighborhood side.
The decor was nothing special but felt very warm and natural.
; I thought the food was great.
The service was decent to good but not great.
Our waiter did try to check up on us as often has he could
but he was clearly busy with many other tables as the whole restaurant only had two waiters.
On the times he did stop by he was very nice and sincere
so I'll cut him some slack.
Oh yeah, back to the food.
Everything was great.
We started off  our dinner with the French onion soup and a wild mushroom soup (puree).
Both soups were great.
The French onion had a nice rich broth with plenty of onions and was topped with piece of bread and slice of gruyere all melted and bubbly from the oven.
It was served in a nice little miniature crock pot which was a nice touch.
For our entrees we had the crusted seared sea bass and the seafood stew
(cioppino like) served with a vegetable risotto.
Both dishes were great except for the side of risotto which tasted a bit undercooked.
We washed everything down with 2 glasses of bordeaux.
Next time I want some authentic French bistro food in a cozy setting i'll be sure to stop by here agian.
.author: Steven H.
.review:
Stopped by on a Friday evening with no reservation and was seated promptly.  The place can be considered cozy or cramped depending on your mood.  The tables are close enough where you can hear others next to you speak but it doesn't really matter unless you're trying to listen haha.  The bistro is a small little place neatly tucked off Baker St. on the neighborhood side.  The decor was nothing special but felt very warm and natural.  Although we didn't need to make reservations it definitely got busy after we came in (around 7:45).

On to the good stuff; I thought the food was great.  The service was decent to good but not great.  Our waiter did try to check up on us as often has he could but he was clearly busy with many other tables as the whole restaurant only had two waiters.  On the times he did stop by he was very nice and sincere so I'll cut him some slack.  Oh yeah, back to the food.  Everything was great.  We started off  our dinner with the French onion soup and a wild mushroom soup (puree).  Both soups were great.  The French onion had a nice rich broth with plenty of onions and was topped with piece of bread and slice of gruyere all melted and bubbly from the oven.  It was served in a nice little miniature crock pot which was a nice touch.  For our entrees we had the crusted seared sea bass and the seafood stew (cioppino like) served with a vegetable risotto.  Both dishes were great except for the side of risotto which tasted a bit undercooked. We washed everything down with 2 glasses of bordeaux.  Next time I want some authentic French bistro food in a cozy setting i'll be sure to stop by here agian.

excerpts: Cute, quaint bistro!
Everyone I talked to before trying this place raved about the great prie fixe menu and
now I see why.
The dining area is tiny, not good for groups, but perfect for a date or meeting an old friend to catch up.
Bonus:  easy street parking!
.author: Katie P.
.review: Cute, quaint bistro!  Everyone I talked to before trying this place raved about the great prie fixe menu and now I see why.  The dining area is tiny, not good for groups, but perfect for a date or meeting an old friend to catch up.  Bonus:  easy street parking!

excerpts:
Here's a snippet I overheard today about one guy's croque  monsieur:
Lady:
Mmmm is that Bay-Cam-el sauce?
Dude:
Oooh
yeah
Lady
: I think it's a caramel sauce
Dude: hmmm maybe
Lady:

Yeah I think it is
Grrr!
I know it's bitchy of me to get irritated over people mispronouncing a widely used French sauce but this couple was sprinkling French all over their conversation like they were oh so sophisticated.
Maybe they are but
it just rubbed me the wrong way.
The correction was fighting so hard to escape my throat that I had to gulp down a bunch of water.
Ah well, that couple being elitist and my own elitism is just par for the course in this area.
Snoot Snoot Snoot!!
.author: JoAnna S.
.review:
Just had lunch here today after a failed attempt to visit the new Academy of Sciences. The mussels and fries were even better than I remembered!! We also had the mixed greens with crusted goat cheese and the cauliflower puree soup. The salad is always satisfying, we can't seem to get enough of that goat cheese. YUM! The cauliflower soup was definitely cauliflower, so I wouldn't recommend it unless you love cauliflower. I do, so it was perfect for me. The mussels and fries were awesome!! For dessert we had the strawberries with balsamic, brown sugar and cracked pepper glaze over vanilla ice cream. TO DIE !! Between us we also had some super strong french press coffee and a mocha...delicious. They seemed to be short staffed today, there was one waitress and the owner/manager and head chef(?) helped out where they could. Even though service was a bit slow it's a nice place to linger. I sympathize with other people on hearing other people's conversations. I hate that!! I try not to listen but it's hard when you're practically sitting on other people's laps. Here's a snippet I overheard today about one guy's croque  monsieur:
Lady: Mmmm is that Bay-Cam-el sauce?
Dude: Oooh yeah 
Lady: I think it's a caramel sauce
Dude: hmmm maybe
Lady: Yeah I think it is
Grrr! I know it's bitchy of me to get irritated over people mispronouncing a widely used French sauce but this couple was sprinkling French all over their conversation like they were oh so sophisticated. Maybe they are but  it just rubbed me the wrong way. The correction was fighting so hard to escape my throat that I had to gulp down a bunch of water. Ah well, that couple being elitist and my own elitism is just par for the course in this area. Snoot Snoot Snoot!!

excerpts: Excellent, cozy place for first class French cuisine.
The owner is always friendly and hospitable, and the food excellent.
On a warm evening it's a great place to sit outside...
Prix Fixe early im the evening is especially good value.
.author: Martin B.
.review: Excellent, cozy place for first class French cuisine.  The owner is always friendly and hospitable, and the food excellent.  On a warm evening it's a great place to sit outside... Prix Fixe early im the evening is especially good value.

excerpts: Great brunch.
I had the French toast - it was amazing.
Came with some fruit and a creamy sauce.
Only word of warning is that the bistro takes a long time.
I personally enjoy that on a nice weekend day, but a word of warning.
.author: Zoran M.
.review:
Great brunch.  I had the French toast - it was amazing.  Came with some fruit and a creamy sauce.  The portion was large, the toast felt fluffy and tasted very light.

Only word of warning is that the bistro takes a long time.  I personally enjoy that on a nice weekend day, but a word of warning.

excerpts: I really like dining at Baker Street Bistro.
They are casual, inexpensive, cozy and welcoming.
I love their prix-fixe meal that happens before 7pm.
You get a lot of food for roughly $15.
You just cant find a better deal.
The restaurant is tiny, but gives you the feeling you are dining in france.
Their wine selection is nice and reasonable.
I recommend this place to anyone looking for a good meal at a decent price.
.author: Lolo S.
.review: I really like dining at Baker Street Bistro.  They are casual, inexpensive, cozy and welcoming.  I love their prix-fixe meal that happens before 7pm.  You get a lot of food for roughly $15.  You just cant find a better deal.  The restaurant is tiny, but gives you the feeling you are dining in france.  Their wine selection is nice and reasonable.  I recommend this place to anyone looking for a good meal at a decent price.

excerpts: Friendly service.
My girlfriend's French toast wasn't cooked all the way through, but for the most part the food was good.
Nice, off the 'beaten path' of Union and Chestnut.
.author: Andrej A.
.review: Friendly service.  My girlfriend's French toast wasn't cooked all the way through, but for the most part the food was good.  Nice, off the 'beaten path' of Union and Chestnut.

excerpts: Very cute little bistro, keeps us coming back.
The food and service are alway really good, never had to worry about anything.
To us it's one of those places that invites people back over and over without an implied invite, you just want to go.
.author: Mike S.
.review: Very cute little bistro, keeps us coming back.  The food and service are alway really good, never had to worry about anything.  To us it's one of those places that invites people back over and over without an implied invite, you just want to go.

excerpts: I recently took over 30 seats in the restaurant for a private party that was a complete success.
Danel the chef was fantastic in helping me design a menu for the event and the staff was wonderful and fun the night of the party.
I highly recommend working with them on private events.
One of the best restaurants in the city for a spectacular quiet dinner and an even better spot for an intimate dinner party.
The food far exceeded our expectations!
.author: Tory P.
.review: I recently took over 30 seats in the restaurant for a private party that was a complete success.  Danel the chef was fantastic in helping me design a menu for the event and the staff was wonderful and fun the night of the party.  I highly recommend working with them on private events.  One of the best restaurants in the city for a spectacular quiet dinner and an even better spot for an intimate dinner party.  The food far exceeded our expectations!

excerpts: this place makes me miss sf even more.
i used to come here for that prix fixe.
come on, you can't beat a prix fixe for under 20 bucks.
anyway.
the ambiance, location, and food are delightful.
not the best french food i've had (that would have to be fleur de lys...
hubert kellers masterpiece), but for a neighborhood french place it's amazing.
.author: paul l.
.review: this place makes me miss sf even more.  i used to come here for that prix fixe.  come on, you can't beat a prix fixe for under 20 bucks.  anyway.  the ambiance, location, and food are delightful.  not the best french food i've had (that would have to be fleur de lys... hubert kellers masterpiece), but for a neighborhood french place it's amazing.

excerpts: I don't think they do anything wrong here for lunch.
Food is fantastic.
They have a broad lunchtime selection beyond baguettes and croque monsieurs -- pork chops, sea bass, pastas, etc.
Great deserts as well.
If you're in the Marina/Presidio for lunch, it's hard to do better.
.author: Tim G.
.review: I don't think they do anything wrong here for lunch.  Food is fantastic.  They have a broad lunchtime selection beyond baguettes and croque monsieurs -- pork chops, sea bass, pastas, etc.  Great deserts as well.  If you're in the Marina/Presidio for lunch, it's hard to do better.

excerpts: Great brunch option in the Marina neighborhood.
Food was perfectly cooked, service was great too.
Not crowded at all, coffee was really good too.
.author: Michael M.
.review: Great brunch option in the Marina neighborhood.  Food was perfectly cooked, service was great too.  Not crowded at all, coffee was really good too.

excerpts: Food is great!!!
On popular evenings the service may be spotty, but the staff is very warm & friendly.
Just had my first brunch there -- will definitely be eating more early meals at the Bistro!
.author: Sharon P.
.review: Food is great!!!  On popular evenings the service may be spotty, but the staff is very warm & friendly.  Just had my first brunch there -- will definitely be eating more early meals at the Bistro!

excerpts: Tres bon!
What I like best is that I really feel like I am in France when I eat here (only the waitstaff is friendly at BSB).
It's cozy here, the food is divine and plentiful, and it has a great neighborhood vibe.
.author: Bette K.
.review: Tres bon!  What I like best is that I really feel like I am in France when I eat here (only the waitstaff is friendly at BSB).  It's cozy here, the food is divine and plentiful, and it has a great neighborhood vibe.

excerpts: A solid, but not amazing bistro.
Very small, friendly service, charming atmosphere.
The tuna tartar was a bit on the tough side.
Had a very traditionally prepared steak frite, which was quite good.
Excellent garlic butter on top (how could it not be good!)
and well prepared, moderate quality new york strip.
The wine recommended by the waiter (and owner I'm guessing) was good, but not great.
Overall, I'd be fine with returning
but it won't be on the top of my list.
.author: Graham M.
.review: A solid, but not amazing bistro.  Very small, friendly service, charming atmosphere.  The tuna tartar was a bit on the tough side.  Had a very traditionally prepared steak frite, which was quite good.  Excellent garlic butter on top (how could it not be good!) and well prepared, moderate quality new york strip.  The wine recommended by the waiter (and owner I'm guessing) was good, but not great.  Overall, I'd be fine with returning but it won't be on the top of my list.

excerpts: The food at Baker is pretty good all around, although we frequent it more for Sat/Sun breakfast.
The french toast is the best in the city, with sweet creme fraiche and excellet fresh fruit.
This place makes you happy every time you go.
.author: Ken M.
.review:
Best French Toast in the city.

The food at Baker is pretty good all around, although we frequent it more for Sat/Sun breakfast.  The french toast is the best in the city, with sweet creme fraiche and excellet fresh fruit.  This place makes you happy every time you go.

excerpts: I really love this place because the prices are great for what you get - great food and excellent service.
It's also a very quaint and romantic place, and it's nice to go to when you want to avoid the restaurants on Chestnut but still want to be close by so you can walk around afterwards.
.author: Karen L.
.review: I really love this place because the prices are great for what you get - great food and excellent service.  It's also a very quaint and romantic place, and it's nice to go to when you want to avoid the restaurants on Chestnut but still want to be close by so you can walk around afterwards.

excerpts: We sometimes walk by on neighborhood rambles and it always caught our eye, but we hadn't yet made it in for dinner.

Then this afternoon I happened to be walking by with my dog and noticed all the other diners outside with their dogs, and I took in the tempting aroma of another diner's steamed  mussels, and it seemed like a very good idea to stop and eat.
The salade nicoise and the moules were delicious.
The service was very good.
The dog slept at my feet.
It was just lovely.
.author: Matilda S.
.review: We sometimes walk by on neighborhood rambles and it always caught our eye, but we hadn't yet made it in for dinner.  Then this afternoon I happened to be walking by with my dog and noticed all the other diners outside with their dogs, and I took in the tempting aroma of another diner's steamed  mussels, and it seemed like a very good idea to stop and eat.  The salade nicoise and the moules were delicious.  The service was very good. The dog slept at my feet.   It was just lovely.

excerpts: My duck leg (Confit de Canard) was the best I have ever had.
We went here for lunch, utterly delightful.
Authentic French.
.author: Allan K.
.review: My duck leg (Confit de Canard) was the best I have ever had.  We went here for lunch, utterly delightful.  Authentic French.

excerpts: We've walked by the place a few times, but never stopped in to eat.
Finally decided to walk over for a taste recently.
1 star ding on the service.
It was a Tuesday evening and there was only one waitress, plus a server/helper.
Not sure if they were short staffed, or the combination of us sitting outside.
Also, we passed on the wine, not really in the mood.
Overall, cozy, off-the-beaten-path neighborhood bistro.
Service was slow, but friendly.
Food was above par.
.author: George C.
.review:
We've walked by the place a few times, but never stopped in to eat.  Finally decided to walk over for a taste recently.  Though there was room inside, we chose to sit outside, given a rare warm evening in San Francisco.

Star each for location, good bistro feel, and food.

They have a good menu with a number of daily specials that appears to rotate regularly, based on the changes we noticed each time we have walked by and peeked at the menu.  

1 star ding on the service.  It was a Tuesday evening and there was only one waitress, plus a server/helper.  Not sure if they were short staffed, or the combination of us sitting outside.  However, it took a while to get our order taken and it was hard to get service (water refills etc...) in between.  

Also, we passed on the wine, not really in the mood.  Plus the glasses looked like they held about 2 shots of wine (no exaggeration here).

Overall, cozy, off-the-beaten-path neighborhood bistro.  Service was slow, but friendly.  Food was above par.

excerpts: I love this little place.
I have been twice.
Once for Sunday brunch and once for dinner and will definitely be going back.

I had a New York steak cooked to perfection while my boyfriend had th prix fixe menu which, first of all, was cheaper than my steak, and second featured the most delicious duck confit I have ever tasted.
I literally wanted to order everything on the menu.
As much I enjoyed my steak, I saw someone at a nearyby table eating french onion and was like, DAMN!
I should have gotten that too.
Next time, and there will be one.
This place is fantastic!
Also, some great friends live a block from here and frequent this place all the time.
They got married last October and they received a set of coffee mugs from Baker St. Bistro as a wedding gift.
They were so touched!
.author: Knitgirl P.
.review: I love this little place.  I have been twice.  Once for Sunday brunch and once for dinner and will definitely be going back.  I had a New York steak cooked to perfection while my boyfriend had th prix fixe menu which, first of all, was cheaper than my steak, and second featured the most delicious duck confit I have ever tasted.  I literally wanted to order everything on the menu.  As much I enjoyed my steak, I saw someone at a nearyby table eating french onion and was like, DAMN! I should have gotten that too.  Next time, and there will be one.  This place is fantastic! Also, some great friends live a block from here and frequent this place all the time.  They got married last October and they received a set of coffee mugs from Baker St. Bistro as a wedding gift.  They were so touched!

excerpts: One of my favorite places for almost 10 years.
Take your dog and sit outside for brunch on the weekend.
Take your partner and have a special cozy weekday dinner.
Not very private, but it is a bistro after all.
I hear the Gettys walk down the hill to eat here.
Wouldn't know them if I saw them, but the rumor adds a bit of elegance to the experience.
.author: Peter F.
.review: One of my favorite places for almost 10 years.  Take your dog and sit outside for brunch on the weekend. Take your partner and have a special cozy weekday dinner.  Not very private, but it is a bistro after all.  I hear the Gettys walk down the hill to eat here.  Wouldn't know them if I saw them, but the rumor adds a bit of elegance to the experience.

excerpts: BSB is second only to Zazie for uber-tasty brunch food in the city.
Their house specialty, the french toast, is to DIE for....thick, rich, a little soggy, and served with fresh fruit and a dollop of sweet yogurt.
The eggs florentine are also absolutely outstanding.
Almost everything is, actually.
Except the service.
The wait staff do try hard
but they always have too many tables to give any of them a high level of service.
So don't go if you're in a rush, but know that the food is ALWAYS worth the wait.
.author: Jennifer H.
.review: BSB is second only to Zazie for uber-tasty brunch food in the city.  Their house specialty, the french toast, is to DIE for....thick, rich, a little soggy, and served with fresh fruit and a dollop of sweet yogurt.  The eggs florentine are also absolutely outstanding.  Almost everything is, actually.  Except the service.  The wait staff do try hard but they always have too many tables to give any of them a high level of service.  So don't go if you're in a rush, but know that the food is ALWAYS worth the wait.

excerpts: The prix fixe dinner is offered between 5:00-7:00 and we arrived at 6:55 and they honored the dinner to us.
It was very good.
Tonight was the pork tenderloin
and it was very tender.
The sauce was tastefully prepared.
The fried cauliflower was not oily or greasy.
They need to update their website to reflect the accurate prices.
The items are about $2-$3 more than the current website.

Much quieter and more intimate then anyplace on Chestnut and Union.
Surely on the expensive side, but pretty much on par with everything in the Marina.

excerpts: I went to this restaurant for dinner with some friends.
We sat inside and enjoyed the cozy and quiet atmosphere.
The waiters and waitresses were friendly and helpful.
I liked the salad with goat cheese.
My friends said the lamb stew was delicious.
We all had desserts which were excellent.
I especially like the sauteed strawberries with balsamic vinegar and pepper with ice cream.
It was a pleasant experience and a satisfying meal.

I especially like the sauteed strawberries with balsamic vinegar and pepper with ice cream.  It was a pleasant experience and a satisfying meal.

excerpts: Approaching the restaurant, you would know immediately it was a French bistro.

The exterior reminded me very much of the Art Deco style of all Metropolitan station entrances in Paris and many Parisian hotels, complete with elegant chairs and tables in the patio for outside dining (on warmer days).
The interior was warm, cozy, with many touches again of French decors and fabrics.
The friendly host and head chef came to chat with us at our table.
We felt instantly welcomed.
But the best part was the food itself.
The menu was a comprehensive map of France itself with so many authentic items to choose from.
The price was shockingly reasonable for a French restaurant.
The four of us ordered different dishes and appetizers, and each dish was impeccable!
The portion was just sufficient yet not offensively large as in many typical American restaurants.
The desserts were perfect and exquisite, as you would expect a French dessert to be.
The servers and the host knew when to check in and socialize with us and when to leave us to our food and conversations.
We had a wonderful time (for a very small price).
We would definitely bring more friends back here for dinner, lunch or brunch.
Baker St Bistro is a gem in a city that's only second to New York City in the number of restaurants.
You get honest, good, authentic French food at neighborhood-bistro prices in a beautiful ambiance among friendly, pleasant staff and patrons.
I highly recommend Baker St. Bistro.
Try it for yourself and bring many friends.

Try it for yourself and bring many friends.

excerpts: love this place.
the french toast and eggs florentine were delicious- my idea of the perfect breakfast!
when we went (sunday morning) we didn't have to wait, which was surprising to me as it is a lot better than a lot of the popular brunch spots in the bay area (in my opinion).

excerpts: I ate with a very large group of people with an overpriced fixed menu.
About half the table got the skate, and unfortunately, most of the pieces reeked and tasted of ammonia (as if the sauce was made of Mr. Clean - that bad).
The shockingly rude waiter, instead of apologizing, said that it happens sometimes (
afterward I read that  ammonia contamination can happen if the fish is handled improperly as its urine becomes ammonia) and didn't want to take them back even after sniffing them.
After some insistence, he did reluctantly.
The chef then came out and said that the fish was fresh, again not taking responsibility for putting out inedible and perhaps dangerous plates of food.
.author: Quincy B.
.review:
Foutage de guele !

I ate with a very large group of people with an overpriced fixed menu.  About half the table got the skate, and unfortunately, most of the pieces reeked and tasted of ammonia (as if the sauce was made of Mr. Clean - that bad). The shockingly rude waiter, instead of apologizing, said that it happens sometimes (afterward I read that  ammonia contamination can happen if the fish is handled improperly as its urine becomes ammonia) and didn't want to take them back even after sniffing them. After some insistence, he did reluctantly. The chef then came out and said that the fish was fresh, again not taking responsibility for putting out inedible and perhaps dangerous plates of food.    No respectable chef would dare have such a vile plate (in this case, about six of them!) of food leave his kitchen, and no decent waiter would dare do anything but apologize profusely and offer some compensation.  

Vous devriez avoir honte, messieurs !

excerpts: Baker Street Bistro is one of the best deal you can find in SF.
The fix price menu should be particularly noted, great food for the price.
We have been having dinner there for many times over the years and are always happy to try new things.
The only downside is the place can get really crowded and it would be tough to have a quality conversation and wait could be long during weekend nights with no reservation taken.

excerpts: The restaurant reopened not too long ago by new owners Danel and Dave.
I like the new decor the new owners brought to this restaurant.
They also designed a chic new logo.
Food was delicious.
We ordered the prix fix menu: I started off with lobster salad, my boyfriend ordered baked oysters with leeks.
Both were really good, but the baked oysters were "out-of-this-world" good.
The leek added a real frenchy taste to this dish.
Our entries were rack of lamb and steak.
Chef Danel is really  an expert at searing meat.
Lamb was seasoned perfectly with rosemary and cooked to perfection.
There was the crispy crunch from the searing of the meat with herb, then the meat inside is juicy, tender and full of flavor.
Same for the steak.
The outside was seared perfectly, and inside the meat was a perfect medium rare.
I also thought it was of good value.
Our prix fix menu was $40.
Serving size was generous.
Make this restaurant next on your list to try and add to your favorites!
.author: Glenn R.
.review: I just had a great Xmas Eve Dinner at this restaurant. The restaurant reopened not too long ago by new owners Danel and Dave.  I like the new decor the new owners brought to this restaurant.  They also designed a chic new logo.  Food was delicious.  We ordered the prix fix menu: I started off with lobster salad, my boyfriend ordered baked oysters with leeks.  Both were really good, but the baked oysters were "out-of-this-world" good.  The leek added a real frenchy taste to this dish.  Our entries were rack of lamb and steak.  Chef Danel is really  an expert at searing meat. Lamb was seasoned perfectly with rosemary and cooked to perfection. There was the crispy crunch from the searing of the meat with herb, then the meat inside is juicy, tender and full of flavor.  Same for the steak.  The outside was seared perfectly, and inside the meat was a perfect medium rare. I also thought it was of good value. Our prix fix menu was $40.  Serving size was generous.  Make this restaurant next on your list to try and add to your favorites!

After that they tried to serve us the wrong entrees...finally we got the right entrees and just as we were beginning to enjoy our meals, a waiter was walking by with plates he had just cleared and a freaking dirty fish knife dropped onto my coat, and fell into the back of my pants, slipping right into my ass crack...perfect spot for a dirty fish knife, right?
Ughhh!
kill me.
so not my idea of a nice night out!
anyway, we already had free dessert and wine, so what else could they do for us?
Well maybe they just gave up because they sure seemed to stop trying to make it better.
You would think after a dirty knife goes into your ass, they would try to make nice, but NO, not these peeps.
I really think that they are good people, but I am just not sure what happened.
I mean come on!
anyway, our free dessert came, but oddly we had no choice in what type of dessert we got.
As we watched the next table over reading their dessert menus, we ate out preselected flan, which I personally don't like.
the waitress, however informed me that "everyone likes flan
" I said, well I don't.
she brought choc cake.
whoopdie doo.

.review: So, here I am with fellow yelper Jacinta J. We ate at the bistro this evening. hmmmm, where do we start.....how about with the fact that there could potentially be fish remnants in my but crack right now. Yeah, you might think this sounds crazy, but I am not kidding. Okay so now that I have your attention, I will tell you about our night......we walk in and the place is looking super cute...not totally full and they tried to give us this table in the corner----but nobody puts baby in a corner!!!!!!! anywho, so we ask for the booth, which they gladly gave us. All is well, and we have fabu glasses of champagne and a nice cheese platter, and THEN, they ask us to move to that f-ing corner table! but they promise us free wine and dessert--a deal we can't pass up. So, we move. Let's just say that the night went downhill from here. We proceeded to wait and wait and wait for some semblance of service, but all we really got was bumped up against, ignored, menus dropped on us, and water glasses left empty....not ideal. then, as we were waiting for our entrees,  they offered us dessert, perfect timing if you ask me ( I'm being sarcastic). After that they tried to serve us the wrong entrees...finally we got the right entrees and just as we were beginning to enjoy our meals, a waiter was walking by with plates he had just cleared and a freaking dirty fish knife dropped onto my coat, and fell into the back of my pants, slipping right into my ass crack...perfect spot for a dirty fish knife, right? Ughhh! kill me. so not my idea of a nice night out! anyway, we already had free dessert and wine, so what else could they do for us? Well maybe they just gave up because they sure seemed to stop trying to make it better. You would think after a dirty knife goes into your ass, they would try to make nice, but NO, not these peeps. I really think that they are good people, but I am just not sure what happened. I mean come on! anyway, our free dessert came, but oddly we had no choice in what type of dessert we got. As we watched the next table over reading their dessert menus, we ate out preselected flan, which I personally don't like. the waitress, however informed me that "everyone likes flan" I said, well I don't. she brought choc cake. whoopdie doo. whatever it is hard to recover from being fish knifed in the butt. Gotta go clean up now!!!

excerpts: In addition, wine prices are EXPLOITIVE.
No bottles for less than $35 and bottles that go for $10 - $20
a bottle were going for minimum of $9 a glass.
In such small glasses, this is a 300 - 600 % markup!
Many clearly better restaurants have wines at $30 or less.
And the service--- we were sitting at a table at which the busboy and waiter could have easily gone to the other side to collect plates, but they asked us to pass them over.
Even a server at Denny's wouldn't do that!
Our conversation was  interrupted each time they had to deliver something.
Who is managing this place?
.author: randy b.
.review: Ditto for Julie S.'s review. The change of hands has not been good for the restaurant. Simply not a good value. Some decent things, but mostly mediocre. For ex., each meat dish was cooked wrong--- supposed to be medium rare for the lamb and duck. Each was medium to medium well; supposed to be rare for the steak, but was raw/not even a warm center. In addition, wine prices are EXPLOITIVE.  No bottles for less than $35 and bottles that go for $10 - $20 a bottle were going for minimum of $9 a glass. In such small glasses, this is a 300 - 600 % markup! Many clearly better restaurants have wines at $30 or less. And the service--- we were sitting at a table at which the busboy and waiter could have easily gone to the other side to collect plates, but they asked us to pass them over. Even a server at Denny's wouldn't do that! And why couldn't the waiter tell the busboy where the 1 cappucino went? Our conversation was  interrupted each time they had to deliver something. Who is managing this place?

Baker St Bistro is a fabulous restaurant for any occasion and I am so glad the staff could be part of my wedding weekend!

The food and wine list are also excellent and the service is attentive, accomodating, and authentic.
I felt I was being served by people who were truly interested in our having a nice dinner.
Small and cozy ... this place truly reminds me of a Parisian cafe.

excerpts: I want to give this place a better rating because i think the food is pretty good and the service is decent considering it is a french place,  but I found the ambiance/atmosphere really lacking.
I think maybe it is more of  a brunch place.
.author: chrissie s.
.review:
I want to give this place a better rating because i think the food is pretty good and the service is decent considering it is a french place,  but I found the ambiance/atmosphere really lacking.

It is not anything like a street cafe in Paris. Don't be deceived by the quaint yelp picture with christmas lights and outdoor seating. The restaurant is located on a residential street so there is nothing to see nearby (no people, no other stores, just apts and parked cars). Definitely not the same lively, bustling, people- watching paris street cafe feel. The interior also needs some remodeling. I noticed some of the seat cushions are ripped and the menus don't look very clean. There was also a huge wasp-bee flying around that kept on bothering us until a waiter killed it. Also, I came around 7:30 pm on a Fri night and there was only one other group there. Not sure if it was just a slow night, but it definitely took away from the atmosphere. I did notice more people coming after 8:00 pm, but considering the overall high reviews, i thought this place would be more popular. I think maybe it is more of  a brunch place.

excerpts: Good local restaurant.
I would not drive to go to dinner here
but if you live in the hood, it's a good staple.
One downside is that they don't mix up there menu enough.

excerpts: Nothing bad to say - EXCEPT- verify your reservation!
We've been here for dinner twice, and twice we made reservations well in advance only to find that they had no record of our reservations, both times.
Fortunately we were eating at 5:50 and they had room.
Great food, and when we asked the owner to call us a cab he poured us free glasses of port to drink while we waited!

excerpts: Since relocating here from LA, I"ve had a difficult time finding a great brunch spot...until I checked out Baker St.
The food and sauces are excellent quality, the service is mellow and the sidewalk dining is reminiscent a a Parisian bistro.
Do yourself a favor and stop by.
.author: Robin n.
.review: Since relocating here from LA, I"ve had a difficult time finding a great brunch spot...until I checked out Baker St.  The food and sauces are excellent quality, the service is mellow and the sidewalk dining is reminiscent a a Parisian bistro.  Do yourself a favor and stop by.

excerpts: My second visit was last night.
This is a cozy little Bistro off the beaten path of Cow Hollow.
My wife and I both had the Prix Fixe dinner and it was excellent.
1st course was a Cream of Wild Mushroom soup that was outstanding.
Tasty, good portion--could have made a meal of it.
Following that came a little green salad--simple butter lettuce and a light dressing.
The main course was Baby Back Ribs in a tasty sauce with a lentil ragout.
Good portion, tasty, done perfect.
For dessert we had a Bread Pudding in a rum type sauce with strawberries and whipped cream.
The cost of this meal wa $16.50 and it was delicious.
The people next to us ordered from the regular menu and one had a lamb steak and the other a chicken breast.
Both looked good and were generous portions.
Service was very good.
For a neighborhood bistro this is a 5 star place.
We will go again.
.author: Wayne E.
.review: My second visit was last night.  This is a cozy little Bistro off the beaten path of Cow Hollow.  My wife and I both had the Prix Fixe dinner and it was excellent.  1st course was a Cream of Wild Mushroom soup that was outstanding.  Tasty, good portion--could have made a meal of it.  Following that came a little green salad--simple butter lettuce and a light dressing.  The main course was Baby Back Ribs in a tasty sauce with a lentil ragout.  Good portion, tasty, done perfect.  For dessert we had a Bread Pudding in a rum type sauce with strawberries and whipped cream.  The cost of this meal wa $16.50 and it was delicious.  The people next to us ordered from the regular menu and one had a lamb steak and the other a chicken breast.  Both looked good and were generous portions.  Service was very good.  For a neighborhood bistro this is a 5 star place.  We will go again.

excerpts: This modest, out-of-the-way Bistro is a real find.
I trek all the way from the East Bay to enjoy its laidback atmosphere and tasty offerings - which come at totally reasonable prices.
On the weekends, when most brunch spots are overrun and have waits of over an hour, BSB seems always to have a table available - and this is not because of poor quality.
I just think it's not that well known or as faddish as other places.
There's outdoor seating to enjoy when the smallish interior gets too crowded.
I always order the bouillabase - subtle, red fishy broth, tender scallops and other goodies, topped with a perfectly toasted slice of baguette and pepper aioli.
The other week, my family and I also tried the risotto for a late brunch - it came speckled with squash, beet, and sundried tomatoes - a perfect summertime dish.
It was delicious - not too mushy or overrun with ingredients.
The fluffy french toast is also an excellent standby.
As for the service, there are several attentive and friendly waiters to assist.
The owner also frequently emerges from the back to shmooze with regulars and newcomers alike.
(I did find it strange when he chose to dump along the street a bucketful of dirty washwater just outside his place - bad choice!).
The only drawback I see for this place, besides its somewhat remote location over by the Presidio, is its espresso drinks.
They just aren't that strong or flavorful.
I like my cappuccinos dry and
theirs was decidedly weak.
Alas, I will return in spite of that.
Again and again.
Sitting outside, with a mellow breeze and fog blowing over, with its quiet atmosphere, gives me images of being at a lazy brasserie in France.

excerpts: We frequent Chouchou in the forest hill neighborhood and can say that, by comparison, there is no comparison.
Chouchou is our favorite.
We will probably still return to Baker Street Bistro for another try in the summer for some outdoor sidewalk dining.
We always give it a couple of trys.
.author: Andrew L.
.review: Went to Baker Street Bistro on the recommendation of someone who lives in the area. French bistro cuisine is one of my favorites, so on my birthday, my wife, daughter and I had to give it a try. At best it was just okay. The ambiance and decor are warm and inviting. The service is friendly and sharp. Our only complaint is the food wasn't so great. I started with the salad with smoked duck, duck gizzard and foie gras. The smoked duck had no smoke flavor, the gizzard was like jerky, but the foie gras was good. The "Julia Child" beef bourginon was salty, the beef was dried out and the sauce lacked complexity. Simply one note flavor like canned stew but WAY saltier than canned. My wife's duck a l'orange was very good. It was served with polenta cakes and she does not like polenta. She asked if she could substitute any other sort of starch and it was made clear that there are "no substitutions" as stated at the bottom of the menu. These days, I would think restaurants would be a little more accommodating with a SIMPLE request like a side starch substitution. My daughter's steak was just that, a steak with fries and a small side of vinaigrette salad. Nothing special. Sad to say, but "you can get that anywhere". We did not partake of the desserts. We frequent Chouchou in the forest hill neighborhood and can say that, by comparison, there is no comparison.  Chouchou is our favorite.  We will probably still return to Baker Street Bistro for another try in the summer for some outdoor sidewalk dining.  We always give it a couple of trys.

excerpts: Again I think I have been transported to Paris.
This charming tiny restaurant is a find and worth driving clear across the City in the rain to  get to it which we had to do.
This is the second time we have been there
and it was just as delightful but even more so because we had the prix  fixe menu.
I thought I was reading the menu wrong when it said $16.50 for a four course dinner.
I read it again
and yes it was true from
I think 5:30 to 7:00, I am not sure of the days
but we were their on a Friday night at 6:30
so it worked for us.
The spinach soup was delicious and not just a cup of it but a bowl.
A lightly dressed salad accompanied the delicious boned trout in a nice butter sauce with sliced almonds and rice.
This was then followed by dessert which I assumed would be a dish of ice cream considering the price of the dinner and the full size servings of each course.
But to my happy amazement the dessert was a wonderful brownie like cake garnished with a strawberry and resting on a delightful sauce.
Some of the entrees go for about $18.00 which is still reasonable  but then when you think a four course for $16.50 it is unbelievable.
And to top all that off the waiters
are nice, efficient and unassuming.
I much prefer this restaurant to one that charges high prices, gives attitude and bad service and then dismal food .
I can hardly wait to go again and pretend I am in Paris at a fabulous  little charming restaurant that I was so lucky to find.
.author: Sally F.
.review: Again I think I have been transported to Paris.  This charming tiny restaurant is a find and worth driving clear across the City in the rain to  get to it which we had to do.  This is the second time we have been there and it was just as delightful but even more so because we had the prix  fixe menu.  I thought I was reading the menu wrong when it said $16.50 for a four course dinner.  I read it again and yes it was true from I think 5:30 to 7:00, I am not sure of the days but we were their on a Friday night at 6:30 so it worked for us.  The spinach soup was delicious and not just a cup of it but a bowl.  A lightly dressed salad accompanied the delicious boned trout in a nice butter sauce with sliced almonds and rice.  This was then followed by dessert which I assumed would be a dish of ice cream considering the price of the dinner and the full size servings of each course.  But to my happy amazement the dessert was a wonderful brownie like cake garnished with a strawberry and resting on a delightful sauce.  Some of the entrees go for about $18.00 which is still reasonable  but then when you think a four course for $16.50 it is unbelievable.  And to top all that off the waiters are nice, efficient and unassuming.  I much prefer this restaurant to one that charges high prices, gives attitude and bad service and then dismal food .  I can hardly wait to go again and pretend I am in Paris at a fabulous  little charming restaurant that I was so lucky to find.

excerpts: I had the eggs with ratatouille and salad with orange juice
everything was tasty!
orange juice.author: Moe O.
orange juice.review:
Solid five stars here. The food was excellent. The service was fast and friendly.  The sun was out so the patio was perfect.

I had the eggs with ratatouille and salad with orange juice everything was tasty!

excerpts: I believe we had 1 coffee and 1 orange juice as well.
Our bill before tip was just over $30.
orange juice.author: Andrew K.
orange juice.review:
Charming French restaurant perfect for your Saturday brunch. They do accept some reservations although their website might claim otherwise. Not very big so I'd recommend it for parties of 4 or smaller, but I did see a group of 7 waltz in without a rez and they seemed to have no trouble getting seated. 

The centerpiece of the menu, I think, is the eggs. I had a poached egg on English muffin drenched in ratatouille and a light tomato sauce. Superb! Came with a side of perfectly roasted potatoes and greens dressed in a tangy vinaigrette. My friend had a similar poached egg dish (called "Oeufs Copenhague"), only this had hollandaise and salmon. She loved it. 

The service is friendly and prompt and the coffee is dark and good. 

I believe we had 1 coffee and 1 orange juice as well. Our bill before tip was just over $30. Not bad considering both the quality and quantity of food! 

Give this spot a try, won't ya?

excerpts: Dings for no bacon, and for saying "fresh-squeezed orange juice" when its just Odwalla.
orange juice.author: Ashley S.
orange juice.review:
Caveat: I get the same thing everytime I go, and it's their killer kick ass delicious French toast.  That's all.  Very good.  Very big portion.  

Dings for no bacon, and for saying "fresh-squeezed orange juice" when its just Odwalla.

excerpts: Fresh squeezed orange juice topped it all off with a delicious finish.
But you just have to get the french toast.
You won't be disappointed!
orange juice.author: Jennifer R.
orange juice.review: You have to get their specialty french toast. It was the best i've had in my life, even better than Mama's!  The strawberry creme fraiche was amazing. Also had the poached egg with ratatouille, which was great as well. Fresh squeezed orange juice topped it all off with a delicious finish. But you just have to get the french toast. You won't be disappointed!

excerpts: Proper tea served in spot with a jug of warm milk.
Can't speak for the coffee.
Our waitress was French and very pleasant and friendly and helpful.
A really lovely experience.
The decor is charming.
And the food didn't disappoint.
Cream of mushroom soup was inhaled- delicious.
And the croque madam was a real treat.
Perfect for a hangover!
Side salad had a delicious vinaigrette as well.
All in all a really lovely, charming experience
milk.author: Kitty S.
milk.review: We came around noon and had the most charming seat by the window. Cushions. Proper tea served in spot with a jug of warm milk. Can't speak for the coffee. Our waitress was French and very pleasant and friendly and helpful. A really lovely experience. The decor is charming. And the food didn't disappoint. Cream of mushroom soup was inhaled- delicious. And the croque madam was a real treat. Perfect for a hangover! Side salad had a delicious vinaigrette as well. All in all a really lovely, charming experience

excerpts: We both got coffee and they brought steamed milk to put in it!
Service was good, food was delicious, would definitely come back if in the neighborhood again!
milk.author: Lora E.
milk.review: Had a fabulous brunch here after the Great Santa Run! My friend and I got the croque madame sandwich and an eggs benedict and shared both. We both got coffee and they brought steamed milk to put in it! Service was good, food was delicious, would definitely come back if in the neighborhood again!

excerpts: I liked that the coffee came with a little jug of warmed milk.
milk.author: Mary M.
milk.review:
Definitely one of the better quaint, French bistros in town. Yummy!

1) Seared Foie Gras
2) Escargot
3) Cheese Platter
4) Charcuterie Platter
5) Steak Tartare w/ Frites
5) Canard a L'Orange
6) Creme Brulee
7) Coffee

We had a huge group for dinner, and split # 1-4 together for appetizers.

1) Value alert: for less than $20, they give you a generous serving of foie gras. Yummy! Foie gras was spot on, and accompanying grapes and apple compote were also delicious.
2) Escargot - Can't go wrong with snails, butter and garlic.
3) Cheese Platter - this was kind of underwhelming - standard camembert, brie, roquefort, and a couple of other hard cheeses thrown in. Not my favorite.
4) Charcuterie - It was ok, but I wouldn't say this was my favorite either - nothing stellar to note except for the tasty pate in the middle. But again, I've had better...

BF ordered the steak tartare, and I ordered the Canard a L'orange (duck with orange sauce).

5) Steak Tartare - this was probably my favorite dish of the night. Generous portion of tartare, seasoned nicely, and the french fries were sooooooo good. I ended up eating most of the french fries.
6) Canard a L'Orange - for a dish with "orange" in its name, there was no orange flavor to the sauce. The duck was cooked nicely, and the sauce was tasty, but no orange. Sauce ran into the crispy polenta so half my polenta was soggy, and the sauteed spinach was also not impressive.

Our other friends had the salmon (two out of two agreed that the carrots served with the salmon were tastier than the salmon itself), the boeuf bourguignon (very salty), and the cassoulet (pretty good.)

Creme brulee was done well but again, nothing special.

I liked that the coffee came with a little jug of warmed milk. Nice touch.

Overall I think we will definitely come back for the steak tartare, and there were some things on the breakfast/brunch menu that looked interesting to us too.

excerpts:
-Warm milk was served with the decaf
-cute outside patio 
-they
milk.author: Abi W.
milk.review:
We didn't have reservations. I did not know that we needed any. The place was half full at the outside patio, all full inside the rstaurant when we got there and by the time we sat down, the outside patio was almost empty. 

It took forever to be seated, We told the staff member (female) that we preferred inside because it was chilly outside. She took our name and asked us to wait outside. OK, the restaurant is small but still, it was chilly. Over 10 minutes later, I went back inside to tell her that we would be fine sitting outside,  but that we were hungry. She said OK, but was distracted (because she was also a server). We went back to waiting outside. There were a few tables available and had I been functioning, I would have just sat in one, but I wasn't, so we continued to wait outside. Another server (male with a friendly smile) came over to us and asked us if we had been helped. I explained and he offered us a seat. We sat down, only to have the first server (female) apologize for the confusion and try to clean off our table for us. 

Eventually someone who I would assume was an owner (female, dressed professionally, French speaker). She took our order  without writing anything down and was very sweet. She and her male server also helped us to push the wasp away from our table when it hovered around us. 

The food was pretty good. I had an egg white omlette with Swiss cheese and onions and a decaf coffee. They did not refill the coffee until I specifically asked for it.  And then, the coffee she used to refill my cup with caffeinated. Besides that, I liked that they had Benedict options (some vegetarian) and parking was not too hard to find. I do wish though that they had had a vegan dish or two and not charged so many extra fees for the eggs. Omlette was something like 8 dollars, egg whites was an additional 1.50, cheese .75, and onions .75.  I felt nickle and dimed. Plus, they claimed they only had Swiss cheese but I saw them give my friend parm cheese for her Caesar salad.  
 
Nice touches:
-Warm milk was served with the decaf
-cute outside patio 
-they offered ketchup (I declined)

Not-so-nice touches
-They did not give us sugar or substitutes, I had to reach over to the unoccupied table next to us to get it.
-They did not give us salt and pepper;  had to reach over to the unoccupied table next to us to get it.

All in all, I was glad to be there because it meant that I was spending time with my close friends. I would go there again, but  perhaps for dinner? It was nice to go to a place so close to the Presidio but not quite in it.
