excerpts: Also, as a tea drinker, I very much appreciated that my tea came in a pot of very hot water (not a mug of warm water and a tea bag).
Nothing stuck up about this French restaurant; I can't wait to go back!
tea.author: Jane H.
tea.review: How nice to pop into a little neighborhood bistro expecting nothing only to be thoroughly charmed by everything about it! I loved the intimacy of it, the French decor, the friendly wait staff (with authentic French accents) and the delicious food beautifully presented. Had brunch there with my adult son. I had the cinnamon french toast with creme fraiche artfully decorated with strawberry sauce, and my son had the eggs benedict, which came with lovely fresh field greens. We both were in heaven! Also, as a tea drinker, I very much appreciated that my tea came in a pot of very hot water (not a mug of warm water and a tea bag). Nothing stuck up about this French restaurant; I can't wait to go back!

excerpts: creme broulee, and profiteroles graced the table, with 2 coffees and 1 tea.
The whole afternoon cost $137.43 + tip,
tea.author: David D.
tea.review:
I love French accents. In food, I mean. Yeah, food. 

Mom-in-law asked us when we could go to lunch a while ago. My Lady arranged for it on a Friday afternoon, during warm weather, while the markets were slow. Off we went on the 43, just a ten-minute ride! 

At about 1 pm the restaurant was about half full. The diners around us were regulars, and told us what the "good stuff" was, while we browsed the menus over kir royales. 

Not knowing what escargot was, one of us who shall remain nameless asked for it without the snails. This immediately evoked the humor of our host, who owned the restaurant, and we had a lovely time dancing through the menu choices. Ultimately, we did order the escargot and French fries. Wait, we had entrees as well. The bourride, a fish stew, was delicious. The Caesar salad was just right. The croque monsieur brought ham and cheese to a new level of consciousness. Really, it was amazing! 

Somewhere in the middle of all this we decided to order wine. Quelle surprise! Given that we were trying to decide on three glasses, the owner suggested we share a half bottle of the Sancerre 2007 sauvignon blanc. We were delighted to discover it "was fermented without introducing cultured yeasts," and we savored its complexity. 

Dessert was mandatory, of course!  Chocolate cake, creme broulee, and profiteroles graced the table, with 2 coffees and 1 tea. The whole afternoon cost $137.43 + tip, of which $25 was the Sancerre, and $25.50 was the 3 kir royales. 

We engaged the owner in conversation, and found out he was a neighbor of ours! The rumors of a new restaurant opening in NoPa turned out to be true -- lots of exciting changes are happening in our neighborhood this year. We are eagerly looking forward to the grand opening! 

Now I want to learn French so I can speak English with that accent.

excerpts: We had light dinner - salads as a main course, wine, dessert and some tea.
Everything was tasty' and the service was o.k.
Greta atmosphere!
tea.author: michelle k.
tea.review: We had light dinner - salads as a main course, wine, dessert and some tea.  Everything was tasty' and the service was o.k. Greta atmosphere!

excerpts: I can't say much about the coffee because I had tea instead
but the couple beside us seemed to enjoy their coffee and brunch as well.
All in all it was a nice place to go to with good food.
The restaurant wasn't completely full on this day but I would hate to see what it would be like if this place were in full swing with the service seeming so weak as it is.
I would still go back though, for the food and the location (quiet, sleepy little street).
tea.author: cora j.
tea.review: My hubby and I came here for brunch on a Sunday. Kinda busy, the servers looked harried and didn't seem like they were communicating with each other. We got a seat outside on the sidewalk. Hubby got the Croque Monsieur, it looked tasty and covered in cheese and bechemel, yum. I had the French Toast. Made with 2 slices of Pan de Mie, it was extremely soft and tender and custardy on the inside and crispy on the outside. On the side was a fruit salad, creme fraiche and strawberry jam and the citrusy syrup was just the right touch. I can't say much about the coffee because I had tea instead but the couple beside us seemed to enjoy their coffee and brunch as well. All in all it was a nice place to go to with good food. The restaurant wasn't completely full on this day but I would hate to see what it would be like if this place were in full swing with the service seeming so weak as it is. I would still go back though, for the food and the location (quiet, sleepy little street).

excerpts: And why couldn't the waiter tell the busboy where the 1 cappucino went?
cappucino.author: randy b.
cappucino.review: Ditto for Julie S.'s review. The change of hands has not been good for the restaurant. Simply not a good value. Some decent things, but mostly mediocre. For ex., each meat dish was cooked wrong--- supposed to be medium rare for the lamb and duck. Each was medium to medium well; supposed to be rare for the steak, but was raw/not even a warm center. In addition, wine prices are EXPLOITIVE.  No bottles for less than $35 and bottles that go for $10 - $20 a bottle were going for minimum of $9 a glass. In such small glasses, this is a 300 - 600 % markup! Many clearly better restaurants have wines at $30 or less. And the service--- we were sitting at a table at which the busboy and waiter could have easily gone to the other side to collect plates, but they asked us to pass them over. Even a server at Denny's wouldn't do that! And why couldn't the waiter tell the busboy where the 1 cappucino went? Our conversation was  interrupted each time they had to deliver something. Who is managing this place?

excerpts: I had a mocha, which was tasty and chocolatey, and the Eggs Copenhagen (i.e., salmon benedict).
The benedict was quite good, the eggs were perfectly poached, the English muffin was fluffy, and the Hollandaise sauce was gooey and flavorful.
The salmon was great, but I would have liked a bit more of it.
The side greens were OK and the breakfast potatoes just tasted like rosemary, which wasn't good.
mocha.author: Jeffrey S.
mocha.review:
A great weekend brunch spot!

I came in on a Sunday at about 11:30am and I was very pleasantly surprised to find the place half empty. I was seated immediately and service was quick. I had a mocha, which was tasty and chocolatey, and the Eggs Copenhagen (i.e., salmon benedict). The benedict was quite good, the eggs were perfectly poached, the English muffin was fluffy, and the Hollandaise sauce was gooey and flavorful. The salmon was great, but I would have liked a bit more of it. The side greens were OK and the breakfast potatoes just tasted like rosemary, which wasn't good.

excerpts:
Yummy French Fries!
Coffee and Mocha
mocha.author: Ariene S.
mocha.review:
Awesome brunch dishes! 
The Croque Madame is great!
We also liked their Eggs Florentine. Their eggs cooked just the way we wanted (we had issues with Bill's Cafe at Pleasanton last week).
Cinnamon French Toast is great! Love the yogurt sauce and fresh fruits. 
Yummy French Fries!
Coffee and Mocha great!

Pretty pricey food, but all worth it!!!

excerpts: Between us we also had some super strong french press coffee and a mocha...delicious.
They seemed to be short staffed today, there was one waitress and the owner/manager and head chef(?) helped out where they could.
Even though service was a bit slow it's a nice place to linger.
I sympathize with other people on hearing other people's conversations.
I hate that!!
I try not to listen
but it's hard when you're practically sitting on other people's laps.
mocha.author: JoAnna S.
mocha.review:
Just had lunch here today after a failed attempt to visit the new Academy of Sciences. The mussels and fries were even better than I remembered!! We also had the mixed greens with crusted goat cheese and the cauliflower puree soup. The salad is always satisfying, we can't seem to get enough of that goat cheese. YUM! The cauliflower soup was definitely cauliflower, so I wouldn't recommend it unless you love cauliflower. I do, so it was perfect for me. The mussels and fries were awesome!! For dessert we had the strawberries with balsamic, brown sugar and cracked pepper glaze over vanilla ice cream. TO DIE !! Between us we also had some super strong french press coffee and a mocha...delicious. They seemed to be short staffed today, there was one waitress and the owner/manager and head chef(?) helped out where they could. Even though service was a bit slow it's a nice place to linger. I sympathize with other people on hearing other people's conversations. I hate that!! I try not to listen but it's hard when you're practically sitting on other people's laps. Here's a snippet I overheard today about one guy's croque  monsieur:
Lady: Mmmm is that Bay-Cam-el sauce?
Dude: Oooh yeah 
Lady: I think it's a caramel sauce
Dude: hmmm maybe
Lady: Yeah I think it is
Grrr! I know it's bitchy of me to get irritated over people mispronouncing a widely used French sauce but this couple was sprinkling French all over their conversation like they were oh so sophisticated. Maybe they are but  it just rubbed me the wrong way. The correction was fighting so hard to escape my throat that I had to gulp down a bunch of water. Ah well, that couple being elitist and my own elitism is just par for the course in this area. Snoot Snoot Snoot!!
